description:
It was mine and my friend's first time checking out Mozzeria and it was great! The restaurant is located on a wider, quieter street so it was very easy to find parking and although we had reservations, it looks like we wouldn't have had much of a wait without one. 

We ordered the bolded menu items (favorite dishes) which was a Burrata appetizer and the margarita pizza. Both were very rich in flavor and delicious. After living in Italy for a few months, it feels difficult to find a quality Italian restaurant. The customer service was wonderful and the food came out quickly. All the waiters were speaking in ASL which was a very new experience for me in a restaurant setting, but it was very easy to communicate. It made me wish I knew ASL. I'll definitely come back again if I'm ever in the area!
author: Anna B.

description:
Mozzeria lost last night what would have been a life long customer. Penny you didn't make things right, you should have though! 

I ordered from Uber Eats, the order came completely wrong, missing items etc. 

1st call with Penny "We're so sorry we'll make things right" 

2nd call with Penny "I can't get in touch with Uber Eats but I found the driver" 

Me: is food coming or not? 

Penny: "Yes we're sending hot food"

Uber Eats calls makes refund and tells me I have to order again! Really I have to order and pay again for Mozzeria's mistake? Meanwhile I'm 1 1/2 hours into this and hungry! 

Sorry there's better food elsewhere from restaurants that can get their to go orders out the door properly.
author: Dave P.

description:
Being an NYC transplant I've become sort of a self-proclaimed pizza snob in the Bay Area.  I can't help it, but I am. 

I've had Mozzeria to go, and Mozzeria to stay and I would say they're perfectly good for either occasion.   The Neapolitan style pizza has a great crust for the bread without being too chewy or crunchy.  Really awesomely made pizza in the Bay Area with some good ingredients.  

Demerits:
Minus a point for forgetting the sauce on our to go order.  The Tomato sauce was a bit too salty on the margarita slice, but that's my snobbery speaking.
author: Justin L.

description:
I started a dinner club with 3 friends. Rules are simple - we have to pick a place that no one has been to before.

I have had this on my list forever.

We ordered the fried mozzarella (small) - not quite as good as I was expecting.  Then 3 pizzas: the mushroom, the peking dick and the margarita.  All were good - but not the best I've had.

For dessert we go the bombolini, served hot.

I will say it is a very quite restaurant - there was a large table of deaf patrons at the next table.

You need to do a lot of pointing to order, and they do leave a few pieces of paper and a pen for notes to your server if you are having difficulty communicating.
author: Amy W.

description: Went here on a school project since I'm learning ASL, and it was a WONDERFUL experience. The eggplant parmigiana was the best I've ever had. Crispy yet soft and very flavorful. The Margherita pizza was divine, and the Bombino dessert amazing. All very delicious. Our waiter Jason was very attentive and tried his best to communicate with me, with the little sign Language I know. He understood everything exactly as I said it, (thank you professor Blair for teaching me). Highly recommend it. I would recommend leading to sign, pizza, cheese, water etc. Loved it, will be back!
author: Nicole D.

description: Fantastic place good pizza
author: anson o.

description:
Anyway, I have only a vague idea how to work Yelp apparently. I'm back in the city and am staying a little while this time. Naturally, I had to get a hotel room both by the location and Mozzeria. Surprisingly, I found one almost right in the middle! Anyway, I didn't get a latte this time, but instead got a Mozzeria Sunrise. It was delicious! I learned how to say water in ASL before going this time, too. Again, it was AMAZING. My dad and I had the dessert, too, and that was also amazing, though not completely my personal preference of desserts (it was still delicious and amazing though). I hope to make it here one more time before I head home!

TL;DR: this place is still amazing.
author: Ari E.

description:
Must try. The duck pizza is absolutely delish. It's a great Asian fusion item. We also tried the Margherita pizza and that did not disappoint either. 

To keep the pizzas authentic, the restaurant uses ancient grain flour for their crust. They have a specially designed pizza oven to get the perfect crispy thin crust on all your pizzas!

This is a deaf owned and operated restaurant, but you'd never know it with how attentive the staff is. You do not need to learn ASL to eat here. However, if you pick up some along the way, your experience just got better!

Full disclosure that it may get quite hot inside due to the fact that the oven sits in the middle of the dining area. Don't let that deter you! Throw on some shorts and order ice water upon arrival and you should have no problem with your dining experience.
author: My N.

description: First time here.  We ordered Peking duck pizza and all meat pizza.  I love duck pizza but my husband didn't.  He love all meat pizza but I didn't.  So it ends up I finish whole 12 inch duck pizza and he did the other.  He felt the pizza was more Italian style and shall call as flatbread.  We also had fruit dessert with Nutella.  The restaurant was very warm due to pizza baking oven was inside. Staffs were very friendly and we got to use body language to communicate.  At one point, we asked pen and paper to discuss food ingredients to check allergy issue.  If around the area again, we will be back.
author: Julie W.

description: Love this place! Delicious authentic pizza, and an awesome, dynamic, and humbling atmosphere.
author: Sam A.

description:
I've seen this place on TV before and have always wanted to try it. 

I finally came here on a food tour and it was great! In the restaurant there is their magnificent oven. We were served the Peking Duck Pizza and the Margherita  pizza. Personally I liked the Margherita a lot because of it's simple taste. Although simple, you can still taste each ingredient.

I learned that what sets Mozzeria apart from other pizzerias is that they use a different type of flour to make their crust. The owners wanted to make their pizzas as traditional as possible.

If you love pizza and happen to be in the mission district of San Francisco, you should definitely make your way to Mozzeria!
author: Mai W.

description:
Such a cool experience dining here. My daughter is studying American Sign Language in college and was assigned a project to visit this restaurant. The restaurant is owned and operated by the deaf, and watching my daughter practice her new skills with the staff was so fun! 

The food at Mozzeria is quite delicious! We started off with veal-pork meatballs. The marinara was rich and flavorful and the meatballs were perfectly cooked. The pizza selections were creative and delicious, and the crust dipping sauce was a fun addition. My biggest complaint is that there just wasn't enough of the delicious toppings on the pizzas. With that said, still amazing and gourmet. Moving onto the desserts, we made the mistake of sharing the Bombolino. Only a mistake because it was so freaking good, that we all wished we had ordered one each. Do not miss out on this dessert, and DO NOT SHARE!!!

As you can see, we really enjoyed our dinner. Maybe the only other thing to note is just that the restaurant is very tiny, so feels like there's a lot going on around you, but it's also a fun and upbeat place.
author: Allison P.

description: Peking duck pizza was excellent! Highly recommended.  My daughter had the Italian sausage and it was great too.
author: Norberto R.

description: What an amazing place!  The staff is all deaf, so it's fascinating to watch how they work and communicate. The Peking duck pizza is devine!!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
My husband is deaf, and was talking about this place forever. For his Bday, I decided to surprise him with a trip to SF and a dinner at Mozzeria. I've made reservations (you really don't need to btw) and put a request for a nice desert or a balloon or something to make my hubby happy. Offering to pay extra, of course. When we arrived the place was half empty, no balloon or any acknowledgement to my request. Didn't think much of it. Then we realized that the a/c isn't working, and that a  tiny (not bad) pizza (12") cost $17 (what??). $3 for oil and vinegar mix, and no hot sauce. Long story short - one pizza (half pepperoni) and one glass of coke cost us $40. Sorry. Doesn't worth the money. 
Restaurant's crew was super nice and tried to do whatever they could to make us happy... but next time if we want pizza, we will just call Domino's. Sorry.
author: Shay P.

description:
Wonderful dinner experience. Started with the egg plant small plate, which was perfect for 2. The eggplant was fabulous. Tuesday is $10 Margharita Pizza night. Delicioso . Reservation highly recommended. Restaurant fills up quickly.
#mozzeria
#sanfrancisco
author: Julie H.

description: Mozzeria is an amazing place. The Margherita and Peking duck pizzas were fantastic along with the dipping sauces and the Bombolino dessert. The staff is very friendly and easy to communicate with, happy to support this community!
author: Sue R.

description: I have been wanting to come to mozzeria for a while now! I'm so glad that I finally made it! It was amazing!!!! Delicious pizza! Wonderful atmosphere and I know zero sign language and I had no issue. Thank you to the amazing staff at mozzeria, they absolutely have a great thing going for them!
author: Krystin I.

description:
I've been following Mozzeria for some time as a Deaf-owned and operated restaurant.

I hosted a disability event last night and I was super excited to support a disability-owned business. We had the soppresata and margherita pizzas and arugula salad. It was great because Mozzeria customized our order to have vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, and lactose-free options.

This is my second time having Mozzeria (first time was a dine-in where a donated a portion of each pizza sold to Hurricane Harvey relief) and the second time our organization has had Mozzeria. Each time has not disappointed.

The pizza went VERY quickly -- will definitely have to order more next time.

Shoutout to Tiffany from Mozzeria for working with us through this order. Will definitely be back.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I had read/seen/heard a lot about the unique background of Mozzeria, and thought what a cool spot, but most importantly was excited about rave reviews of its great pizza. The pizza did not disappoint, and I'd put it up there with my still unranked top pizza in SF list. I splurged for the legit Margherita (the DOP with mozzarella di bufala). Fluffy crust, lightly charged, flavorful tomato sauce - all the ingredients were stars. My one peeve, and I see this is a lot, is that the sauce and oil made the middle of the pizza a little soggy, so it's really move of a 4.5 star pizza. Three slices were plenty for each of us and I took my last slice to-go. I was a little sad that we had pigged out on CREAM before dinner, so I'm gonna have to come back to try that bomb looking Bombolino.

The slight communication challenges reminded me of dining in another country. I don't know sign language besides the alphabet, but it was helpful to spell out a couple words. Don't let it scare you away - pointing and motioning will probably be all you need.

As some others have said, the pizza oven in the small space makes this place hot, so dress accordingly. The plus side is you get to watch the pizza making pros in action.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Impressed and learned that humans can overcome any impairment when given the opportunity to live a regular life.  The individuals who served and took care of my wife and I for our dinner (kitchen staff to waiting staff) were hard working and diligent in their duties.  Food was delicious and made simple.  Restaurant staff amazing in their communication and service.  

I did not know what to expect.  I watch you tube to learn few ASL restaurant edicts before coming.  The experience, to me, cowabunga dude!  Ninja Turtles would make this their regular hang out spot.  

Wife and I will be coming back for another diet cheat date.  

A go to spot, bookmarked. Done.
author: Rich L.

description:
What an incredible experience we had @ Mozzeria! My daughter & friend are taking an ASL class through West Valley Jr College. One assignment was to attend an Event and this restaurant was a choice.

Although our family doesn't sign, the staff was so friendly and eager to understand what my daughter & friend were signing.

We were seated at the beautiful counter- awesome! Got to see all the action of pizzas being prepped, going in and out of the oven. ALL looked delicious!

We started out with the CHARCUTERIE AND CHEESE PLATE . . . 18 (columbus hot coppa, columbus soppressata, smoked mozzarella, brie, garlic stuffed olives, cipolline onion, bruschetta toast. This is my kind of eats!
Wonderful! (My only wish is that the bruschetta toast were plain. They seemed more like a flat croutons-tasty, but plain would have been my first choice)

The pizzas we ordered were the MARGHERITA & ITALIAN SAUSAGE (red onion, fennel, white garlic sauce, fresh mozzarella)

This crust is THE most delicious crust I have ever tasted! Chewy and incredible. Also, we went there on a Saturday, here it is Monday, and eating it cold, was just as tasty.
Thaaat's how ya know
author: BabyG L.

description:
Note: As you have probably noticed from other reviews, they are hearing impaired. There is paper and pen on the table to communicate in the case you do not know ASL. 

Went in as part of a Mission food tour with some colleagues. We had pizza margherita, a cheese appetizer. They brought out some Sicilian wine (forgot the name) and it was pretty fantastic. 

This is a cute and cozy little restaurant. The decor is nice and it's very intimate but still casual. Unfortunately I cannot speak too much to the food selection. 

I'm not a regular Italian eater because I often can make it a bit better and a bit more flavorful at home, and this didn't wow me with flavor either. 

But, I'd definitely go back and hopefully find something with a bit more flavor.
author: Sean M.

description:
To begin with: the pizza here is fantastic. If for no other reason, you should come here because it's good.

But also: I love that it's quiet. There's no music playing. It has long grated on my nerves, this constant drone of background noise that is everywhere always. But here, it's an oasis of silence. The whirr of a fan. The tick-tick of the oven as it expands and contracts. The jingling of utensils being washed. The gentle tapping of the pizza chef perfecting his craft.

This experience makes you appreciate your senses of hearing and taste all the more, and this is what truly makes Mozzeria sublime.
author: Marco C.

description: Deaf owned and operated! This place is super cool. Everyone who works here is deaf and uses sign language! Also, the food is delicious. The eggplant we ordered was exquisitely breaded and crispy. Everyone was very friendly and states busy. Looks like a very well operated and organized place where quality and great service is a must!
author: Daniel G.

description: Excellent food.  We had the spinach and Italian sausage pizzas.  The bombolino for dessert was 'champ'!  The wait staff are friendly and quick to offer help and the ambiance was perfect.   A must visit when you're in SF.
author: Martin K.

description:
We really really liked this great and authentic Italian Napolese pizza place. Also cool that they employ all deaf staff.

Fairly straightforward ordering process with pointing and some improvised sign language making it very easy to order and communicate. One potentially even better opportunity would be some enhanced picture menus or even iPad ordering. Had to Google the sign language word for blue to get blue cheese off of a pizza (kids...) but ultimately it wasn't a big deal.

Really enjoyed the pizzas. Kids loved the cheese and the Salumi was out of this world. Meat was both salty and crispy with the right amount of cheese and a great crust.

Meatballs were also really tender and delicious and the burrata was also a big hit (but didn't need all of that balsamic).

Only real issue was a crusty gluten-free pizza with uncooked toppings that we ultimately had them take off the bill. Also, at one point we asked our server for some extra red sauce - may have been a bit of a communication challenge - but then we never saw her for the rest of the evening. Probably another 20 or more minutes and had to scrape both the bill and a to go box from other servers.

Overall, really great food and some basic service issues that they could clean up to make this place perfect.
author: Bob K.

description: Great pizza, great atmosphere! Their lemonades are really good, too! Nothing else to be said!
author: Amelie-Anna J.

description:
Mozzeria serves up fantastic, fresh, authentic Italian style Neapolitan pizza in a very petite and quaint setting. I found the shotgun style room to be a little difficult to maneuver but nothing I'm terribly unfamiliar with living in San Francisco. The dining experience as a whole was very unique, communicating with the servers via pointing and gesturing but it didn't take away from the well executed pizza. 

The margherita pizza was perfect. Cheesy but restrained with fresh tomatoes, basil, and that beautifully blistered crust that teeters between crispy and chewy. The doughy-ness of the crust was delicious and they know they have a good product on their hands because they offer a number of different sauces for $3-4 you can share to dip the brilliant bread in. 

Although it was still good I was less impressed with the Hosui Pear pizza, which combines some of my favorite things like balsamic, pear, and Brie, but missed the mark but using cubed prosciutto which got tough and almost burnt in the 1,000 degree oven. I would definitely come back here but skip on this one and maybe try their signature Peking Duck instead.
author: Sean S.

description:
What I liked about the place was it creates employment for people who have hearing and speaking impairment. Outside of that was fairly disappointing. 

(-) Dough was undercooked. There was hardly any fluff, felt overly stretchy

(-) The tomato sauce of their Margherita Pizza lacked flavour plus the sauce was very less such that you could hardly taste it

(-) The other pizzas, flavours were not balanced well, was either too sweet (Peking) or bland

(-) They do not have Chilli Oil

(+) They had good service. We were able to customise toppings on the pizzas


Would have loved to have a stronger reason to come back. I won't be going there again
author: Puneet L.

description:
Perfect spot before seeing a friend perform at the Mission Dolores Church nearby. Wow, my friend and I were impressed with the joint on top of the yummy dishes. We shared the eggplant (not usually a favorite of mine, but this one was 5 stars all the way for a non-eggplant eater) and the Peking duck pizza (more like flatbread) was delicious.  Most of the staff is actually hard of hearing, so it's a really warm community for all, and finally a place for all. 

Best of luck, I'll be back, as I have yet to try the home-made mozzarella.
author: Sharon M.

description: I wanted to like this place, I love the concept. The servers were kind. The gluten free pizza was awful, the crust was like cardboard. My husband's pizza was just ok. Maybe we were there on an off night. Give it a try if you're in the neighborhood, just beware of the gluten free crust.
author: Lauraine E.

description:
I went here with a fluent ASL speaker. He ordered for me, but you can easily point at the menu or use the paper and pens on the tables if you need to ask/communicate anything more complex. The service was very attentive throughout our meal!

We shared the Peking Duck and the Salumi pizzas. We weren't expecting much from the Peking Duck (we usually prefer more traditional pizza flavors) but that pizza knocked our socks off! Super delicious. The Salumi was only okay in comparison. I really do like their crust, though.

The restaurant was 3/4 full that evening and I noticed that while there were a couple of patrons who spoke ASL, all the patrons seemed to be hearing. While this place is definitely unique as a deaf-owned and operated business, it's clear that they remain successful because their pizza is good and they run their restaurant well! I will definitely come back.
author: Caz V.

description: I got a gift card from my sister. I would highly recommend to try pork ball that was great! Also, I love pizza here. The service was pretty nice.
author: Pinarat S.

description: Ambiance was nice. Pizza was okay, not a pizza I would go back for honestly. The Italian Red I got was definitely of lower quality. The meatballs were okay and for the size, it did not live up to the $11 price. The place was small and for a deaf place, it sure was loud enough to make me envy my servers. Staff is really nice and attentive.
author: Tony D.

description:
Our boys are taking American Sign Language as a second language and we went here as a school project. First off - seeing two teenagers signing with the waitress was a very proud moment. 

The decor was very nice and comfortable. The only down side of the atmosphere was that we sat near the oven. Hint: sit away from the oven. We were seated right away, we had reservations. There was line at the door at 5:00. We signed our way through the drink and appetizer order. We then signed our dinner order. The waitress was super friendly and had a great attitude. We received our drinks and salad then our appetizer about 10 minutes later. We got the baked mozzarella bar, so freakin good!

They would have received 5 stars but since we ordered the appetizer our pizza order was put at the back of the baking line. We sat for twenty minutes with nothing to eat. I did not mind because I was taking in all of the sign communications between the employees - it was awesome. The pizzas were crazy good. The Peking duck was a little much on the sauce but good. The other two pizzas were sooo good. 

We will be coming back because it was a great experience (and couple more semesters of ALS).
author: Ken A.

description:
I'm currently learning ASL, so of course I wanted to try this place out. I love the concept of hiring all Deaf employees and creating a space for Deaf and hard-of-hearing people where they can use their own language and be understood. However, I think they may need to hire a new chef. 

Very few items on the menu. I ordered the sausage pizza and added mushrooms. Pizza came out with burnt edges (check picture) and the base was soggy. It couldn't hold all the toppings up, so as soon as you picked up a slice, all the toppings slid off the pizza and I'd have to gather them up with my hands. I ended up shoveling toppings into my mouth and then using two hands to take a bite of pizza. Toppings were nice and flavorful, but I wished they stayed on the pizza!
author: Mallory L.

description: Okay, this place is pretty much the reason I made a Yelp account. A couple of years ago Mozzeria was awesome enough to open their doors in the middle of the day for my ASL class. They showed us inside, gave us a cool presentation about the history of the restaurant and the making of the pizza, and served us each up a fantastic margherita pizza. Later, I came back with two of my friends from the class and tried a few other pizzas--the salumi and one I can't remember--and both were mindblowing too!!!! The staff are awesome people and the atmosphere rocks. Loved the Mozzeria Sunrise too. Can't wait to get back up there and bring my folks along!!!! Never found a pizza place so totally worth the Lactaid.
author: Sophie P.

description: Sign me up every week for $10 margherita pizza Tuesday's at Mozzeria. Friendly staff and not a problem communicating with them via pen and paper. Plus, CRUST DIP! I eat the crust normally and the dough is already excellent here. Light and crispy crust. The crust dip just makes it that much better.
author: Samantha L.

description: My son and I had such a fantastic experience here tonight. The pizzas and meatballs were amazing and the staff there were incredibly friendly. Wort visiting again and again!
author: Paul W.

description:
Ambiance was nice and I really appreciated their business being run by deaf staff. That being said, I thought that the pizza was just alright and quite expensive. It also took us 90 mins to get it. We ordered the duck pizza, which is their most popular item... it was unique and we were over it after the first slice. 

I'll come back to this just because this place is in my neighborhood and I'm going to try something else at some point to give it more of a chance because I really want to like it.
author: Spriha S.

description:
My girlfriend and I found this place via Facebook (it was featured on a news page), and we genuinely found it one of the most unique restaurants in history. I guess we were inquisitive to know how communication would work in a condition in which servers use sign language, so we just had to try this place.

It was much quieter than we expected. The place was packed in the video we saw, but we realized the reservation was unnecessary. We sat down, ordered margherita pizza with Mozzeria Sunrise, their signature non-alcoholic drink. It was really sweet and refreshing, and it was just a good starter drink, I thought. The pizza was one of the best we had - they cook it right out of the brick oven, so it tasted really fresh. The cheese was warm, the crust was flakey, and sauce was perfectly sweet. 

I also appreciated how the servers really tried their best to communicate with the guests. Our server not only was trying to tell us which items were popular, but also was making sure everything was okay at our table. It was quite a fun experience actually, since neither of us really had the experience of interacting with the deaf.
author: Paul C.

description:
Mozzeria is definitely a dining experience everyone should try at least once. All of the staff are super friendly and attentive throughout the night. I even picked up a few signs throughout dinner! 

Aside from the experience, the food is just as good. We had the house made burratta, the veal and pork meatballs, margherita pizza and the Peking duck pizza. We didn't get any Dip with the crust which I might have to do next time. 

Burratta- meh
Veal meatballs- bomb
Margherita pizza- bomb, I love when the dough bakes unevenly and parts of it have that burnt toasty taste. 
Peking duck- fresh tasting with the cucumbers, interesting combo. 

I came here with a party of three around 6:45pm and we were seated at 7:35pm. They were super busy on a Friday night. 

Overall, unique place with good food. I'll come back but with a reservation next time or right when they open since the restaurant is pretty small, they fill up quick. Oh and don't wear a big sweater, it's really hot inside. I'm sure that has a lot to do with their huge oven but if you sit toward the back, heh have a fan blowing at least :)
author: Shelly W.

description: I am currently taking an ASL class and I came here for a deaf community experience with my friend who's also learning ASL. We were seated pretty quickly. We ordered one Margherita pizza and one Italian Sausage. There was no problems with ordering our meal. The pizza came out quite long, it took nearly about an hour and 15 minutes for our pizzas. I like the Italian Sausage a lot! It was great, but pizza toppings kept falling off. :( The Margherita pizza was yummy, there was so much sauce on it. They have a dessert menu and we ordered the bombolino. It was delicious! Although, it took long to come out as well. It took about another hour for it to come out. I love the apple lemon curd in it! I wish the waiter would check up on us or refill our water. Overall, this place is good!
author: Kristi A.

description:
I was searching on Yelp one day for pizza places in the city that weren't my usual spots. Mozzeria popped up. It seemed like people were into the food here, it was only later that I found out that Mozzeria only hires hearing impaired people. I found that super cool and I wanted to give it a try. 

Le bf and I made reservations and went for an early dinner on a weekday. He was the first to arrive. He noticed instantly that it was the quietest restaurant he had ever been too. Lots of the people who were seated were hearing impaired. You could see lots of people signing. I thought it was also pretty cool that people who could speak used the opportunity at Mozzeria to practice their American Sign Language.  

Now onto the food. We ordered:
1. Veal Meatballs ($11 for 3)
2. House-made Burrata ($11)
3. Margherita pizza ($15)
4. Peking Duck pizza ($20)

The veal meatballs were my favorite part of the meal. I was forced to share, but if I came alone, I would have no problems scarfing down the meatballs by myself.  The burrata had the texture of chevre. It wasn't what we typically think burrata to be. I prefer burrata texture if I am eating burrata and chevre texture when eating chevre. I have no need to order it again. The margherita pizza was good. Definitely no where close to the best Margherita pizza in the city, but it still tasted good. We got the Peking Duck pizza at the recommendation of our server. I didn't think it was $20 good. The flavor mostly came from the sauce. I was glad I tried it, but wouldn't come back for it. 

They also have Tuesday and Wednesday deals. I think the Tuesday deal is $10 for a Margherita pizza instead of the usual $15. And the Wednesday deal is an app of some kind (I forgot the exact app), Margherita pizza, and Bombolino. I know for sure about the Bombolino, not exactly sure if I got the type of pizza right. It was $25 per person. You can quote me on the price per person.  

The service was stellar throughout. The servers were super attentive. Communication was never an issue. I thought it was a cool experience, but I don't know if the cool experience trumped the food quality enough where I would come back.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: This place was amazing! The food was phenomenal and the service was superb! We had a large party and they accommodated all of us even though we changed our party from 6 to 11!  will definitely be back!
author: Louise L.

description: I love this restaurant!! The food was fantastic. I really loved both pizzas and the dipping sauce. The ambiance was great. The service was phenomenal and the fact that it is run by individuals who are deaf just makes it even cooler. Spread the word- it's a gem!
author: Melanie G.

description:
It's a really small restaurant so I mainly order from UberEats (use code: eats-kathy15 for $15 your first order!) to get my super thin crust/wood fired pizza fix. The unique pizza topping options like peking duck or farm egg pizzas are what set them apart from other wood fired pizza restaurants in the city. I also like their more traditional flavor options like Neapolitan, but the ingredients feel more sparse on these without meat on top. Love the crust - floury, thin, puffed the right amount with just a bit of ashy taste from the oven, but not burnt

Located in the heart of the mission, this is a great option if Pizzeria Delfina is too packed. Both are great, but I think Delfina provides a bit more value with its toppings.
author: Kathy T.

description:
Wonderful pizza. We rate it a go. 

Staff is deaf. So awesome. I'm the minority with a disability ... inability to communicate ! Love this!
Well done. 

Don't let this scare you away. These people are well prepared to handle those of us who hear. Of course they are! 

Besides, it's all about the food, which is worth the stop. 

Make the reservations in the Yelp app.
author: Danny S.

description: Killer pizza.  If you have eaten pizza from  Naples Italy, you will enjoy it.  Great place!
author: Valerie I.

description:
look trick i still enjoyed myself despite my entire visit underscored by an angryazz* msg convo w CNN over yesterday's eatersf owl "wikileak" fthat.

wanted to try this place foreverrrr but todo list always shifted; finally went after chest & back day to calorie up. love that it's a deaf owned & staffed resto how fly is that.

3ish dishes + 1 for cool fresh to deaf crew = 4 overall.

(-_^) House-Made Burrata $11 (http://bit.ly/2mz0Szq)
fun to eat on mini toasts

(-_^) Peking Duck Pizza $20 (http://bit.ly/2mgY9cR)
unique but not so memorable
neat traditional garnishes n sauce

(-_^) Veal-Pork Meatballs $10 (http://bit.ly/2mkxA7b)
could've been minutely tenderer; i'm not trippin

(-_^) Mighty Leaf Orange Dulce $3 (http://bit.ly/2m1INqM)
the full teapot = 1 cup just fyi

$58 (after tip) later not full but not super interested in the rest of the menu. if / when i return it'll be more about supporting their cause vs craving the food.

*CNN asked if i was angry at her. nah heated from the eatersf article. also sorta wrong photo prop - supposed to be ninja turtle bc pizza but had homer instead. doh!
author: Dan B.

description:
Mozzeria offers tasty food AND an awesome dining experience! It's rare to find a place with pizza that I'll actually like (not that I'm a picky eater) since I've had my share of subpar Italian food over the years. My friends and I enjoyed the fact that we needed to communicate to the wait staff without words... though unfortunately I know zero ASL.

We started with the Burrata and Baby Spinach Salad. Great warm-up to the three pizzas that we shared. We got the Margherita, Italian Sausage, and one more that I can't remember the name of. They were all so fresh and delicious, and the best part was getting the warm dipping sauces for the crust! SO GOOD. Especially the white garlic sauce.

This place is great for both groups and more intimate evenings. The only part I did not enjoy was the lack of cell service in this building, which is such a minor complaint but maybe worth pointing out? Then again, this just further emphasizes the need for human connection at Mozzeria to accompany the great Italian food they serve.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Nah! I didn't like their mushroom pizza at all (there is no sauce!!?), and the vegan pizzas are also not good at all. This is definitely not the place for me. There is also too much though and the crust is 35% of the pizza...
Well, I hope our review can inspire them to improve.
author: Sam T.

description: This place is amazing!! My boyfriend and I went while on a weekend getaway in the city. We decided on the Neapolitan and it was the- Best pizza I've ever had in my LIFE. No question. Every single ingredient and component on it is superb, perfectly combined & cooked. The mozzarella cheese appetizer we had (forgot what the menu name) was incredible! Unforgettable! ... All served by the kindest staff, even though I don't know fluent sign language- it was not a problem, and we were pleased with everything! The staff even brought out some delicious donut holes when they found out it was my boyfriend's bday celebration dinner... I can't wait to visit this place again next time I am in the city!
author: Shey S.

description:
I love this place. 
The pizza is excellent and it's a great way to see deaf culture.
author: Tata S.

description: Mozzeria is great pizza! The service is attentive and friendly, even if you don't know asl . Plus it's a cultural experience. Also every time I go the music is the best.
author: elizabeth m.

description:
This place has been on my bookmark list for the longest time. I hard heard and read great things about their pizza and knew I had to try them. 

Making an online reservation was pretty easy and upon arrival we were able to easily check in and were promptly seated. There were pieces of paper and a pen on our table to help with communication as none of us knew sign language. Though none of us knew ASAL the servers were friendly and we were able to communicate well. We ordered:
- Veal and pork meatballs (3) $10: it came with freshly made meatballs topped with fresh mozzarella and savory tomato sauce. The meatball was a tad dry, but perfectly paired with the tomato sauce. 
- Margherita pizza $14. I had been highly craving a margherita pizza and could not wait to try their version. The pomodoro sauce was well seasoned and flavorful and the mozzarella cheese was perfectly portioned and melted. Each bit was heavenly! This was by far my favorite pizza. The only downside was the fact that it was a tad too salty for me, but that is an easy fix.
- Italian sausage pizza $19. This pizza was a friend favorite with their white sauce, Italian sausage and fennel topping. 

The background music was nice so that it wasn't so quiet. Overall, really great experience and a place I would definitely love to eat at again if in the area.
author: Melissa N.

description:
I love the fact that everyone employed here is deaf. I felt good spending my money here, knowing that they give hard working deaf people an opportunity. That is the main reason why I'm giving this place a 4.  When reading this review keep in mind that I grew up in Napoli (pizza capital of the world) and I take Neapolitan pizza pretty serious.

We ordered 2 margheritas, which is the classic thing to get.  The dough didn't seem very aerated and wouldn't fold very nicely. As far as the pizza components, they definitely use high quality ingridients.  What I also didn't like much is that each pizza was only four slices, pretty tiny for the price they charge.  

If I had to rate the pizza alone I'd probably give it 3 stars, however. I really like what they stand for. I may be back, but my favorite pizza place remains il casaro.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Great food and atmosphere! Love it!

Went on a Tuesday so the Margherita pizzas were only $10. Pretty cheap compared to some other restaurants in the city.
author: Dominique V.

description: Wow!! I am not a big fan of the Margherita style pizza, but I am now! I happened to have on a whim ordered a personal sized pizza from their food truck. Like The Ratatouille movie in the scene with the food critic, I was taken aback by how delicious it was. We now monitor when and where the food truck will be so I can get my next fix. We've visited the restaurant in the Mission district and the food did not disappoint. I am hooked on that pizza.
author: C D.

description:
Mozzeria is a legend in the SF deaf community and I have a deaf brother so we headed there one night for dinner.  I made a reservation about 30 minutes before we got there so we could skip the line.

It's smaller than I thought it would be - about 12-15 tables.  All the employees are deaf and speak ASL.  Many deaf patrons, so the place was very quiet.

The food was very good, the service excellent.  I know some ASL, but the servers are able to easily communicate with non-signers as well.

Coming here you get good food, great service and a glimpse into the deaf community.  Truly a great experience and highly recommended.
author: Steve G.

description: Excellent pizza, right up there with Una Pizza Neapolitana but much more reasonably priced and proffessionally run.  Friendly staff. What is not to like?
author: Colin E.

description:
The music was better tonight than the first time I visited. It sounded a little like the hold music for AirBnB ;)

If you've ever read my reviews, you know music is a big deal to me. Tonight the music was quiet, almost too quiet, but much better than the annoying industrial house music they played before. Personally, I like Italian music, especially the soundtrack to the ultimate foodie-film "Big Night." This is a deaf-owned/staffed restaurant, so you can't fault them for what they can't hear. 

I wish the server had told us about the Russian River pinot noir wine special, described as "Stunning, Playful & Pleasing!" I ordered the nero d'avola-- it was a little bitter, but my friend had the regular pinot by the glass, & it was much better. Mozzeria serves mainly pizza Napolitano style, but tonight I felt like eggplant parmigian with the  spinach salad. The pizza oven is gorgeous, round with round black tiles, definitely prominantly featured in the center of the restaurant. 

It's funny--there was a party of around 20 sitting near us, led by the LOUDEST large woman I have ever encountered. When she spoke, she bellowed, I jumped startled, & then smiled to myself how lucky the servers are to not have to hear that voice. Many of her dining companions were deaf, so maybe she thinks she needs to yell. I have noticed that hearing people often shout at deaf folks. It won't help, lady, & in truth, it's obnoxious. A few little boys stomping around were quite loud, too. If I behaved like that in a restaurant, my mom would have grabbed me by the arm & threaten to banish me to Siberia aka "the car"! A fate worse than death to a 6 year-old. Modern parents often don't realize that not everyone finds the antics of their rambunctious spawn as adorable as they apparently do. 
Back to the food-- the eggplant was sublime. Tender, spicy & garnished with fresh basil. I had the appetizer size at $10 & it was perfect, 3 large rounds of aubergine topped with tasty cheese. 

I never did get the salad--I think she forgot. But no big deal. The eggplant was very rich & filling enough. Curious about dessert, my pal ordered the bombolino--basically an Italian donut with apple-lemon curd, chocolate, cinnamon & sugar. No dessert wine, but we really didn't need it.
I would definitely come here again. I hope the owners read these reviews. Not sure if they do, but if they do, thank you for a nice evening.
author: Scott F.

description:
I had seen this place for quite a few weeks and really wanted to try it. Every month or so, I get to choose a nicer place to try with a friend so for this month I decided to we would come here. It started off okay. They seated us really close to the other couple at bar seating which was a bit weird. Normally restaurants would put at least one stool between people. Regardless, it wasn't a big deal. We ended up ordering drinks and the burrata and duck pizza to share. 

The pizza was definitely a great - with duck on top, adding some green onions and hoisin sauce. The amount of duck was not really enough, but it was good enough for the pizza and everything else. 

We ordered some dessert, but it took forever to get. I will admit, I was going to give this place 4 stars, but the dessert situation was just not great. Right after we ordered dessert, there was an accident in the restaurant where they placed a pizza on a table and it accidentally flipped over and spilt on the ground. It created chaos in the restaurant understandably, but it still took almost half an hour to get the dessert. It makes me unhappy since I just wanted to get out of there. This part of it which feels guilty since it wasn't really their fault, but part of me feels like my dessert shouldn't have been forgotten. 

Regardless, the food here is good even if the service can be spotty. The deafness of the waiters are not an issue, but I could see where the small problem created a large problem which affected my dinner significantly. Overall, great place and great service. This place is really 4 stars, but the service at the end decreased it to a 3.5.

Protip: duck pizza!
author: Nina Y.

description:
I think this place is pretty cute as a concept and I am completely supportive of more local businesses, especially those that accommodate an often oppressed community. I am glad that there is a place that people of the deaf community can go to communicate comfortably with the staff and other diners.
However, from an objective point of view of the food itself, I'd say that it was slightly disappointing. I ordered the Italian sausage pizza w/ added mushrooms. The toppings themselves were really delicious and the garlic sauce tastes pretty good. However, the very thin base could not hold such a heavy sauce+all the toppings so most of the toppings ended up falling off the pizza itself. My suggestion is to build a stronger thicker crust to ensure a better structured and less messy pizza. 
Overall, I would come back for the ambiance and atmosphere, but the food is ehhh...acceptable.
author: Edmund L.

description:
As my children are learning a bit of ASL, we thought visiting Mozzeria would be a nice opportunity to try out their skills.  We were going more for the experience than the actual food, as we didn't read any reviews beforehand.  WOW!  Were we impressed!  Being seated was easy, despite the language barrier.  Nice ambiance!  Clean, modern look.  Music was awesome!  I annoyed my kids with my singing because I loved every song!  Service was quick and the waitress was very patient and understood my daughter signing, ordering our meal.  We ordered a Margherita pizza.  IT WAS DELICIOUS!  We had to order a second pizza because the first was so good!  

Their customer service was superb!  Everyone was warm and friendly.  We appreciated having a welcoming environment for my daughter to practice ASL with others.  

We will most definitely return for more delicious pizza!  I wish there was a Mozzeria near us in San Jose.  

*Parking on the street was impossible.  However, we found an inexpensive garage 2 blocks away.
author: Sandra A.

description: This was our first dinner after flying in from Chicago. We had the Burrata appetizer, Margarita style pizza, and Apple pastry dessert. Everything was well seasoned and tasted very fresh. The pizzas are Neapolitan style cooked in a wood burning oven. Delicious!
author: Don G.

description: I made reservations for a group of 11 and everything was just great!  The family style menu worked out perfectly and we ate until we were all stuffed.  They were so thoughtful to remember dietary limitations.  We liked their truffle oil mushroom pizza, salami pizza the best.  Would def come back!
author: Fanny Y.

description:
What a great experience this was! I promised my daughters BFF that I would go with her to this restaurant as she was a little intimidated by the fact that restaurant is owned and ran by all deaf people.
She is currently taking classes but it has been 10 years for me,but I'm down.

We had a reservation and we sat right away! Well after I signed my name! I suggest you have one or be there early because it's small and fills up quick! The staff were all great! They help you along the way if you are "attempting" to sign and if you can't, fret not, there's pen And paper on the tables. It came back like it was 19..nvm, back in the day! Ok, so like I said, the place is quaint & we were sat right next to the 800 degrees(I believe that's what I read) oven and on a cold night in SF, that was perfect! We also were able to see all of the different pizzas come right out of the oven. I tried to snap a pic without getting up from my table, but the duck pizza and the farm egg  looked really good! We had the Italian sausage with sweet red onions on garlic sauce! It was delish! The crust was thin and crispy and just like I like it! The one 12'fed us 3 , but That was because we started with the burrata. I'm not going to lie..had I not just seen this on Triple D hours earlier that day, I would have had no idea what it was and would have passed it up! It was yummy! I love cheese and this was no exception! The creaminess of the cheese with the balsamic and wonton twists.. yummy! I would have preferred the wonton to be warm, but either way- it was good!  They have a dessert menu but I couldn't and drive home!! 
That's my excuse for going back and trying more pizza as well as the dessert! Oh did I mention they have a great wine selection, lots of RED! 
Give it a try! It's amazing!
author: Erika W.

description:
I'm surprised that Mozzeria doesn't normally have much of a wait, but at the same time, I'm thankful for anything tasty in this city that doesn't require serious strategic planning hours in advance. The pizzas here are all really unique and delicious! The first time coming here was solely after checking out the yelp reviews and realizing they had peking duck pizza!! The only odd thing about it though, is their menu indicates which things on their menu are spicy, but the peking duck pizza isn't marked that way despite definitely having some chili oil or something in the sauce they pour over. ): Makes me sad. I'll be sure to request they keep the sauce on the side or something next time. 

The pizzas are a little on the small side, so I suggest getting one per person!
author: Stephany L.

description:
My first time trying this was from the food park with their awesome and beautiful food truck. In fact their food truck is too beautiful to be called a food truck. This is a super delicious pizza. One of my all time favorites. At the food park I had my friend do the ordering. I believe it was written on a piece of paper and then handed to the cashier.... This is a deaf - establishment. Is that the politically correct way to say it? 

Their store is beautiful. Patrons talk to one another but of course you cant talk at this restaurant to get your order across either.

The restaurant seems to be centered around their oven and this is part of what makes the pizza so special. All ovens are not equal. The dough is top notch... and the toppings are high end and super flavorful. 

I wonder if its possible to order a pizza here that I don't like? Hmm sounds like a great personal challenge that will result in many happy evenings here trying their every type of pizza.
author: Stefan T.

description: This place is awesome! Great pizza and friendly staff. But the bombolino (dessert) really stole the show. It's like a plate of mini donuts with lemon custard filling. If you're in the mood for Italian and want to go somewhere quiet, yet hip, this is the place to be.
author: Neil S.

description: Can't speak on the food because I didn't actually get to eat any. Walked in with a party of 4 asking for a table. The waitress signed we would need to wait a min. I than asked where the restroom was for my daughter to which the employee said we could not use until we ordered. Feeling I had not presented my question properly I again asked to use the bathroom before we sat down as we were waiting for a table, she again insisted that we could not use the bathroom until we ordered. I assured her we were going to sit and eat and she still told us no. With that I grabbed the rest of my party and left. I'm not a crackhead or dope-fiend asking for the bathroom, I was there with family to patronize their restaurant as recommended by school faculty. I will not return to this business and have advised faculty to direct students to businesses that value our attempt to integrate with one another.
author: San A.

description:
Before I paid a visit to this restaurant in San Francisco, I decided to explore how deaf-owned restaurants would be successful in downtown. I found and watch their videos on YouTube about how cofounders opened the restaurant by studied abroad in Italy to learn of make an arithmetic pizza. When I came to SF for my cousin's graduation in Berkeley. It is so eventful that deaf customers have simple communications with deaf employees. Most deaf customers are friendly and often place note and pen on table in case of customers who are not use ASL. 

I was impressed with my community who can do anything except hear. Although, this restaurant is located in below of downtown San Francisco. I decided to explore my community's opportunities what they can do with their life and career. My community already awake of this deaf-friendly restaurant, which not only service to deaf customers. I decided to invite my family and relatives to try out authentic pizzas and realized of their atmosphere and culture.  

This restaurant service authentic Neapolitan pizzas, which come from southern Italy, wines, small plates, family style dinners, and desserts. Although, this restaurant is worth in prices for pizzas . Despite the red wine is pricey since it's imported from Italy, it has better taste of wine. It is Principato Pinot Noir. It also offer variety of pizzas such as Peking Duck, Italian Sausage, and others: we ordered two pizzas: Peking Duck and Marinara. 

I have plans to eat in this restaurant again when I'm in SF. If you want to try a pizza there, go to the restaurant or keep an eye on food truck on its schedule. They have food trucks now.
author: Chris C.

description:
Pretty picky with my pizza but loved this place! Got the mushroom/truffle pizza, the margherita pizza and everything tasted fresh! A bit salty on the sauce but that is also a personal preference. The restaurant also has some official designation/approval from some official pizza certification board. My company took that seriously, but for me it tasted fresh enough.
Also ordered eggplant parm appetizers and that was breaded and cooked close to perfect. Looking forward to trying the other pizzas on the menu.
author: Ishraq A.

description:
Absolutely loved this place. The concept of an ASL-primary restaurant is fantastic; though I had no idea walking in the door that this was the case.

Turns out "thank you" was all I remembered from years back. Turns out that's primarily what I say to a server in a restaurant, after all.

Look at my pictures. Seriously. Look at them. If that isn't the best-looking pizza you've seen, I'd love to hear what is.

Reasonably priced, delicious pizza, and sort of tweaks my social justice vibe in a good way that the hearing are in a minority here, reminds us the important lesson that ability/disability is a construct that we take for granted and make a lot of assumptions about on a daily basis.

My new favorite pizza place, not accounting for 3am close-times at the other pizza shops near that Castro gay bars.
author: Sean B.

description:
Really, really great. My sister is deaf and this place was a-ma-zing for her. Everybody signs, voices off, and the atmosphere is warm and friendly. 

The food was good. Very different, but yummy! Somewhat small pizzas for the prices though. 

This deaf friendly restaurant is a must go to.
author: Amber C.

description: We sat by the huge Stefano something (forget the name) oven and ordered the margherita and spinach pizzas, the two house made drinks - lemonade and ginger, bombolino, and Pinot Noir.  The margherita was good and spinach (w/mushrooms, less the red onions), was interesting because the nut topping was a bit too sweet for my liking.  I loved the glass of Pinot I had.  The only down was time it took for the pizzas to come out, but probably because of the two large parties and looked like a lot of To Gos being filled as we sat by the oven.
author: Becca D.

description:
This review is based on my daughter's experience since she is a Yelp reader but not writer!

She visited with three people who sign so that part was easy.  She liked the fact the entire pizza is made in front of you and the ingredients are fresh and not processed.  It was also "cool watching everyone do ASL."

She powered down a Margarita pizza on her own and said it tasted great.  Interior was modern and clean but small.  

The furnace was right next to her table with no separate kitchen so she could see all the action.   I asked if there is anything else I should add to the review and her response "No, it was just really good" and "after eating this pizza, I don't really care about eating any other pizza."
author: Greg S.

description:
Do you want to try a new and unforgettable dining experience? 
Mozzeria is the place to be!

The servers at Mozzeria all speak ASL. Most, if not all, are deaf. I came here to practice my ASL for my sign language class. Even if you don't know ASL, it's very easy to communicate with the kind servers without making you feel inadequate. You can write your order on paper and their gestures are easy to understand.  

The service is efficient and I cannot stop raving about the food! I came here with a group of 7 and we ordered the Family Style dinner. It comes with salad, 3-4 appetizers, four pizzas, and dessert. The appetizers with cheese tasted PHENOMENAL. Their pizzas are hand-thrown and baked in the oven - SUPER DELICIOUS. Every person paid about $30 for the whole meal. That price was well worth it for the food you get and how amazing everything looked and tasted. Everyone was quite stuffed at the end. 

Ambiance is clean and quiet, but has this peaceful vibe to it. It's a perfect environment if you want to learn more about the ASL culture. This is also a great date spot or if you just want a quiet dinner! 

I suggest coming here at least once. You won't regret it!
author: Kristal D.

description: It certainly was a unique experience as the establishment is operated by deaf folks. We got the Peking duck pizza, and while the first slice was delicious, the sweetness of the sauce got overwhelming very quickly. We got 3 tiny knots of scallions and two matchstick sized cucumbers to go with the entire pizza which I found to be humorous...They did give us more when we asked, but it did make me question if the chef had any clue or understanding about how scallions and cucumbers are used to cut through the sweetness of the sauce and the fattiness of the duck. Just wondering...
author: Jin Z.

description: A small pizzeria that's big on flavor!! You'll definitely want to come early or make a reservation because this place fills up fast. Come let your fingers do the talking while you're noshing.
author: Michael B.

description:
What a great story there is behind this low-key but obviously popular Mission pizzeria on 16th off Guerrero. It was founded about four years ago by a deaf couple, Melody and Russ Stein, and in fact, most of the staff is deaf. Jamie W. and I have passed by it before, but I didn't know anything about it until a friend in my yoga flow class told me about it knowing I was always looking for interesting places to eat. Yes, I take yoga, what of it? Anyway, she told me the backstory and highly recommended it. When I got there a bit earlier than Jamie, I immediately started talking when the server looked at me and told her I made a reservation.

She motioned to me that she didn't understand what I was saying at which point I felt like the Anti-Miracle Worker. I wrote my name down on her clipboard, and she confirmed my reservation with no fuss. Their specialty is a selection of fourteen 12-inch Neapolitan pizzas fired up in their Stefano Ferrrara wood-burning oven which looks to be in constant operation (photo: http://bit.ly/1LpRkfd). Jamie and I were discussing whether we should share one. Who were we kidding? We both ordered our own. He went for the daily special, the $15 Meatball Pizza with pomodoro, grana padano, red onion, meatball, roasted peppers and mozzarella (photo: http://bit.ly/1V3v4Og).

It had a sturdy thin crust that held all those ingredients with conviction and a puffed, blistered crust that acted almost like appetizers in themselves, In fact, they offer four dipping sauces for $3 each if you need it. I went a bit more exotic with the $20 Peking Duck Pizza, which was a bit wetter with an ample ladle of hoisin sauce along with cucumbers, sesame seed and spring onions on the side to add some crunch (photo: http://bit.ly/1KBamP8). It was a bit out there, but the duck was pretty succulent and the taste was not overwhelmingly sweet. To alleviate our collective conscience, we also ordered the $11 Roasted Vegetable Plate (photo:  http://bit.ly/1OmDnk0).

It was nice mix of charred Brussels sprouts and cauliflower and peppered with currants for sweetness. No Diet Coke here which bums Jamie out every time, so he had a $3 Boylan Ginger Ale (photo: http://bit.ly/1JiaI82), while I had one of their housemade drinks, the $4 Ginger Iced Tea with Lemon (photo: http://bit.ly/1YpJs2I). Refreshing. All the while, the staff worked quietly and seamlessly, signing to staff back in the kitchen through a monitor at the bar, and some of the customers knew enough ASL to hold conversations with them. I want to learn some fundamental signs the next time I visit, so I don't come across as the Anti-Miracle Worker again. A most worthwhile in the Mission.

FOOD - 4 stars...well-executed thin-crust pizzas with a variety of toppings
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...simple, modern space with ample seating
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...efficient and kind, especially to each other, Melody came in and out of the kitchen to make sure everything was running smoothly
TOTAL - 4 stars...how do you sign 'thank you'?...you put your flat hand to your lips and move it forward and down
author: Ed U.

description: We absolutely loved our experience! We each had a different pizza and shared slices to experience them all. In my opinion, pizza is all about the crust and the crust was amazing. No grease, chewy with a small crunch. Definitely recommend it!
author: Amalee C.

description:
I want to say that our experience with the restaurant was good, however I gave Mozzeria 2 stars because the waitress was so nice. 

We ordered the Appetizer which was the Mozzeria Bar which was fantastic I could have just eaten that and would have been satisfied but then we ordered our pizzas my twins ordered the Salumi $20 which they did eat and finished there only complaints were, that it didn't have much cheese. Then my sister ordered the Italian sausage $19 and she didn't care for the sausage and the white garlic sauce. She thought it was just to over powering. I then ordered the Mushroom pizza $19 and I didn't like it, it was dry with not a lot of flavor. They offer dipping sauce for $3 more which I found ridiculous. 

The Appetizer had the most flavor of all three pizzas in my opinion. We probably won't try it again. But if I do I will probably stick to the Appetizers.
author: Jennifer G.

description: Delicious food, great customer service, much respect! This is my new favorite pizza place! It makes me want to learn ASL!
author: Eric P.

description:
Amazing!!!! I have been wanting to come eat here since I learned of this pizzeria. I am from out of town, but come here often, but somehow my availability and Mozzeria days open did not connect... until today! The food was amazing! We enjoyed the Charcuterie Cheese plate and the Hosui Pear Pizza. My husband got the white garlic sauce for dipping his pizza... amazing! Perfect complement to the balsamic on the Hosui Pear pizza. 

The wait staff were so kind and helpful. I even bought a t-shirt. Plus, I had beignets as a birthday dessert! Delicious!

Oh yes, totally enjoyed the ambience. Pleasant music was playing. We were there on a warm day but fans were going to keep it cool. I had made a table reservation in advance through Yelp. The artwork all through the restaurant is so great and I was told it is all done by local deaf artists. My one suggestion for Mozzeria is... you should sell some of that amazing artwork! Or make prints of the artwork to sell! Thanks so much for a wonderful birthday experience. I will send all my friends your way.
author: Pam M.

description: The restaurant is amazing. The food is delicious and the best part about the restaurant is it is sign/deaf friendly. One can only order in ASL as all the employees are hard of hearing or deaf. It's awesome and I would deaf-initely go there again soon.
author: Tony T.

description: Fantastic service and a very delicious pizza. Came for a school project and will definitely be back again for leisure.
author: James S.

description: My wife and I ordered the Margherita D.O.P. and the Peking Duck pizzas. Both were delicious. Our server was friendly and attentive. We would definitely go back there if we're in SF again.
author: Tom N.

description: Amazing food! If you dont know ASL dont even worry the staff is so welcoming and helpful. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone thats looking for a fun date night spot. I absolutely loved my experience here!
author: Isabela L.

description: As always, excellent food and outstanding service. It's really much more accessible when the staff converse in ASL. Little side conversations between staff help us feel truly included as a part of the total dining experience.
author: Charles-Darla H.

description: Amazing place to eat authentic pizza. One plus about this pizzeria is ASL 1 friendly to learners like myself who want to have an outside experience practicing their ASL with an all-deaf staff and most costumers tend to know how to sign. This place is also great for hearing people as the waiters also provide notes and pens.
author: Karin P.

description: Let's start by saying if you are in San Francisco it's hard to find any good parking. Anyways to the food, the place is small and chick really nice can't take anything away from  the decor. The severs were all deaf and nice, took a while for them to get to us and food took a while too. HAVE TO MAKE A RESERVATION TO EAT HERE. No walk ins sad... Anyways to the food not what I expected from a deaf owner but hey selections are very minimal desert ummmm not impressed with it it fried and hard... the pizza was suggy and no flavor.. unfortunately for my taste buds it didn't work for me.. price tho for a 12inch  wow..$18 dollars I had 2 kids a toddler and my hubby we spent over 89.00 ummm no... drink selection for those that don't drink alcohol 3 drinks coke ginger n lemonade.... n it's not ur regular coke some brand from some other place... weird.
author: Jessica M.

description:
One of the best authentic pizzerias in SF. Is owned by a deaf couple and operated by deaf staff.

FOOD: 
- Mozzeria bar: an upscale mozzerella stick! Yum! Comes as a golden bar (1 should be a good portion for 2-3) with marinara sauce drizzled atop
- Fantastic pizzas! The dough had a great balance of flavor, give, and char (I don't even like super burnt crust). I appreciated the little touches like making the pizzas into hearts for Valentine's Day :). 
- Margherita di bufala was a classic and my favorite. Just as good as many of the pizzas in Naples. No wonder... they are Vera Napoletana certified (by American Delegation of the Associazione Vera Pizza Napoletana... basically it means you make authentically Italian pizza by flour, etc. regulations), with a beautiful oven from Italy you can watch your pie enter. 
- Peking Duck--though apparently a staple in the UK, I really disliked this. I do love Peking Duck, but this pie was overwhelmingly sweet with the sauce. I didn't think there were enough spring onion sprigs to offset the heaviness. 
- Ginger iced tea with lemon--so refreshing and not too sweet... you'll need it with the heat of the pizza oven

SERVICE:
Servers are friendly and look like they're having fun signing with each other. No need to be conversant in sign language to come here--there are small pieces of paper and pens on the table if you need to communicate somethign unique. With just 4 minutes of prep though, you can be a lot more excited to go: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Raa0vBXA8OQ

AMBIANCE:
Wear some light clothing beneath whatever you wear out, as it can grow quite warm in this cozy restaurant where the pizza oven takes up more space than any table. The space is well decorated in a homey style. Music plays softly in the background for the hearing. This was a lovely place to be for a date or with a friend. It is a little tightly packed, as the restaurant is narrow, and with the oven in the middle, basically a shrine to the art of pizza :)
author: Helen W.

description:
We were looking for a restaurant that offered food the three of us would all eat, and saw the reviews for this place. I am a disability and sexuality educator, so I was surprised and thrilled to learn that this business was owned and operated by deaf people.  I downloaded an ASL app in order to use some quick signs, but that isn't needed. 

We ordered the mushroom, arugula, and goat cheese pizza, along with the meatballs, a bottle of wine, and the garlic dipping sauce for the crust.

The pizza was the star of the meal. I love wood fired pizza, and the crust and taste didn't disappoint.  The crust had that right amount of chew and crispness.  The toppings were a delicious combination, and we enjoyed every bite. We didn't need the crust dipping sauce, but I liked it. My fiance wasn't a fan, but he prefers marina style sauces. 

The meatballs were kind of dry, like people mentioned. I think maybe an egg needs to be added to make them more moist, or serve it with more sauce. The flavour was there, but the dryness made me only want to eat one.

We split a bottle of the house red, which complimented the pizza and meatballs. We were surprised at how good it was for a house wine, and definitely would order it again.

I will be back, especially as I want to support my community, but the food is the actual reason I will return. I want to try some of the other pizzas, and I look forward to bringing friends here.
author: Robin W.

description:
Late-night home pizza delivery by Caviar. https://www.trycaviar.com/r/pxvvd5 Free $15 when you sign up! 

The margherita pizza was good but not the best I've had. Bombolino really isn't my thing, and now I know. Overall, 4 stars for qualify, not so much my palette biases.
author: Paulina F.

description: The pizza was good but not so tasty at all. The service was generally lacking. Very hard to order here from the waiters!
author: Dominic B.

description:
My oldest daughter is deaf and during a recent trip to SF she wanted to try out Mozzeria, a deaf owned pizza restaurant.  It's a small, hole in the wall restaurant located in a cool Mission neighborhood and by small I mean it's the second smallest restaurant I've been in with maybe seating for 30 tops.

I ordered their spinach salad and house specialty burrata, a kind of mozzarella cheese made a special way.  My wife had their meatballs and spinach salad while my oldest had the salami pizza and mozzaria bar.  Our other table mates ordered the Peking Duck pizza and a Margherita pizza.

The burrata was pretty good with a nice mild cheesy taste and buttery texture once you got past the mozzarella skin.  However, the gnocco fritos that came with it were wrong and looked more like fried won ton strips then the little pillows I expected.  I'm guessing the oil was too cold but they might have missed adding yeast to the mix and letting it rise.  In any case, it just didn't go with the burrata IMHO.

Their spinach salad also had problems.  While the ingredients were very fresh and well presented, the lemon vinaigrette had separated and I essentially got pure lemon juice making the salad almost inedible.  This happened to my wife's salad as well.

Now one note. The server hardly ever came over to our table to check on things after our original order.  We had to flag down, literally, someone else to help us with stuff.  They were very helpful.

The other dishes: meatballs, pizzas and mozzaria bar were all very good.  They know good pizza!  I was impressed with the meatballs which were good and meaty, firm but not hard and cooked in a light marinara sauce.

Overall, it's a decent restaurant which needs a bit of attention to the side dishes like the gnocco fritos and spinach salad.  With both of those, it's a technique issue - knowing that vinaigrette needs blending before use and having the proper oil temperature when making fritos.
author: Carl K.

description: I'm sure this place is better for dine in but I would absolutely not recommend for pickup or delivery  Waited over 15 minutes past the expected pickup time sith a Grubhub delivery guy ahead of me complaining he had been waiting 30 minutes already.
author: Anthony N.

description: I've always had a fascination with sign language & to find a spot with employees who only communicate through this beautiful language was definitely a must to go. This small establishment had a very intimate setting and casual ambience with a nice selection of thin crust, gluten-free pizza. The beer & wine selection wasn't so bad, but the pizza selection was simple & tasty. We ordered the spinach salad with lemon dressing that was a bit sour but refreshing. We also ordered the Margherita pizza & the Peking Duck, which was an interesting combination but definitely filling. Next time I hope to make it to dessert. Our waiter was extremely friendly and helpful. I hope to learn more of sign language & come back again. If you haven't gone here, you definitely should give it a try. Support the small businesses & community!
author: Kristina R.

description: All the appetizers and the pizza were fantastic. Pretty cool on the staff being deaf and there were no issues ordering. Would definately go back!
author: Anuj T.

description:
This review is for their food truck/trolley.  Reminds me a lot of the Pizza Politana tent at the Ferry Building Farmer's Market during the week.  Pretty solid within the genre of pizza fired to order.  Since the NY-style pizza game is so weak in San Francisco, might as well stick with a style that works.

Burrata: Mild and fresh cheese, you can definitely tell it was made recently by hand.  Served with some tasty fried dough chips whose fattiness helps enhance the natural fattiness of the cheese.  A little bit of balsamic vinegar, basil and heirloom cherry tomatoes to add a tangy contrast.  Perfect for an extra cheese fix in addition to a pizza, but don't forgo a pizza just for this.

Salumi Pizza: About what you'd expect from a quickly fired to order pizza.  The fresh mozzarella is melted, but not gratinéed.  Lots of fresh tasting tomato sauce.  A few thin slices on salumi, that do get crispy on their edges.  Pretty doughy crust though, I probably would have preferred the pizza to be thinner with a bigger diameter using the same amount of dough, because who is a fan of crust?

Ginger Iced Tea: Refreshing.  Not too spicy an amount of ginger.  Also, not bitter for tea.
author: Adam B.

description: Mozzeria is excellent. The pizza is delicious. Almost every time I've come here there was no wait, or a short wait. The entire staff is very friendly and accommodating. The restaurant is peaceful and quiet, I really enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Nicholas P.

description:
PROS:
Love that everyone was fluent in ASL. 
Service was kind and attentive. 
The dough was charred to perfection, chewy and tangy.
The creamy garlic sauce was rich and balanced.
Amazing ginger tea that is slightly sweetened.
House wine is about $6.

CONS:

The butter lettuce salad with kumquats, cranberries, scallions was good conceptually but the execution was not.

We had the truffle and goat cheese with arugula pizza. It was balanced but needed more cheese and maybe some of that creamy garlic sauce to add some interest. The mushrooms were raw.

The radicchio, truffle honey Gorgonzola, mozzarella with some kind of nut pizza should have been a touch sweet and savory. The bitterness of the radicchio was drowned out by the funkiness of the Gorgonzola. A touch of gorgo goes a long way. The mozzarella was texturally weird because of excessive dousing of honey. The dough soaked through and was dripping with honey and yhe nuts on the pizza tasted like they were better suited for cereal.

The reason I'm giving it a 4 is because I probably ordered the wrong thing. We should have gotten the deep fried mozzarella in marinara. A margarita or Salumi pizza. An eggplant Parm.

Oh well. Next time.
author: Tara P.

description: Such a great experience! I recommend it to anyone in San Francisco. I was so impressed with the quality of food and the service!
author: Kashton S.

description:
While we were at the Civic Center Off the Grid we stumbled upon this food truck. It was adorable how it was designed in the outside. Which was a small little trolley with brick oven in the back of the truck. The menu was very simple with picture of each item and descriptions. The way to order was to sign language the item you'd like, but don't worry it had picture of how to do that as well! This experience alone was ultimately the most unique we have ever had. 

We ordered the Quattro Formaggi pizza and it was aaaammmazzzinngg!! We loved how rich the flavors of all the cheeses were and how delicate the bread was. I couldn't believe it. It was so fresh and toasty!! I seriously couldn't believe this delicious goodness came from this little truck! 

If this is what they can make from the little food truck, I can't wait until I go into their actual restaurant and try some more items! In the mean time if you stumble upon them at "Off the Grid" you must stop by and grab a pizza!
author: Lindsay S.

description:
Highly recommend trying this place! Both the food and service were top notch. The restaurant is deaf owned and operated which makes for a unique experience. I was a little worried it would be hard to communicate without my group knowing ASL but hand gestures and pointing at the menu were all we needed. Learn how to sign thank you in ASL before coming here if you can!

The place was pretty crowded so I would recommend getting reservations in advance. It's a good place to go to if you want something more intimate and quiet. 

We had a group of 6 so we ordered the family style set menu for $25. What a steal! It came with several appetizers, different types of pizza, and dessert all of which were exceptional. By the end of it we were so stuffed and there was plenty of leftovers. The most memorable ones for me were the house made burrata (so creamy) and eggplant parmigiana (very flavorful). Every pizza had a perfectly thin and crispy crust. I really enjoyed everything here!
author: Linda X.

description:
All I've tried here is the Peking duck pizza but just based off that one pizza I have to say mozzeria is now one of my favorite pizza places in SF. The pizza isn't that similar to actual Peking duck but it is still a delicious pizza. The spring onion and hoisin sauce obviously go perfectly with the duck. 

Service is a little slow but it didn't detract too much from the experience. The waitresses are also deaf but I don't think that detracted from the experience either! There is a pen and paper on every table if you need to communicate something for which pointing won't suffice. The restaurant has a quiet atmosphere, people talk fairly quietly and it is dark inside.
author: Rica Z.

description: Charcuterie and Cheese Plate, Margherita Pizza, Peking Duck Pizza, Mushroom Pizza, Hosui Pear Pizza, House Made Bombolino, two Tap Beers, one Latte, and one Mozzeria Sunrise. Mozzeria is a  deaf couple owned Italian restaurant. I brought my family here to have a dinner in supporting the Deaf community. Their Neapolitan Pizzas were exquisite, full of freshness, and flavorful! Highly recommend if you're in a mood of having gourmet pizza with your family!
author: Ting L.

description: Pizzas were too salty and overpriced. $19 for a 12inch pizza? Then again it's SF. But if you're gonna charge that much it better be good. Wouldn't come back here it's below average, in addition pizza was too greasy.
author: Kai A.

description:
Me and my friend decided to try this place yesterday.
We entered at 5  pm and left at 6:55 pm . Too expensive to leave with your stomach empty.
Ordered an eggplant parmigiana and a pear pizza. Communicate it was not easy. No paper on the table.
