By body language I can tell the waiter was saying something about us not knowing Asl language to a girl who was sitting there and they were looking at us like we were supposed to know Asl or we were stupid, I don t know..?
They forgot our pizza, water,everyone who came after us left before us and got served before us.I' m Italian and I can tell that is not real Italian pizza, not even close.so anyone who say otherwise is a liar or don ' t know anything about food. 
That pizza was not cooked enough and too tiny. More like bread topped with ingredients .
Not Neapolitan pizza!!The 
eggplant consisted in 3 slices of eggplant, oily and topped with marinara and cheese. Are you kidding me ? This is American food. Non scherzate quando lo chiamate cibo italiano!
author: Maria s.

description:
A unique experience topped with great food. This joint's owned by a deaf couple as it turns out, and most the servers are deaf. There's no music here and everyone's so super friendly. 

Their pizza dough was bomb: chewy tasty crust that's also crispy and crunch on the edges? YUM. 

- Margherita pizza: so good, with juicy fresh tomato and the perfect amount of cheese
- Burrata: sorry but cowgirl creamery has won my heart in burrata. this one's interesting as it's served with fried wonton crisps, but I'd pick something else next time

Overall? definitely would come back, loved the pizza.
author: Kristie C.

description: Margherita Tuesday is the best as pizza is just $10. Excellent service and food. Will be back
author: Johnson H.

description: Great food, friendly staff, comfortable relaxed room, homemade burrata was amazing. Good times!
author: jsn R.

description:
Great pizza and atmosphere! The pizza was good but my Italian sausage was raw which was disappointing because I had to take off more than half the pieces. Watching the pizzas being made there was a lot of inconsistencies meaning some pizzas were given more cheese/sauce than others (the differences were big).

Great experience but service could be better
author: Jonathan B.

description:
My wife and I came here for Mozzeria's 5th anniversary on Sunday night.
The environment and spirit is nice and a bit too dark to read the menu with my bad eyes.  I can handle it.
The IPA beer ran out.  Disappointed.
Little pour of wine for $8.  Could have pour some more.
Since mobile has low reception (3G), I asked for Mozzeria WIFI, I cant use it.  Oh ok.
The pizza has some burning and messy but delicious.
The bill is very high.  Cut off dessert.
The experience is SO-SO OK.
So, overall I gave it three stars.
author: Tom M.

description:
I would be a real curmudgeon to give this place a bad review and luckily I don't have to because the pizza's are pretty good with fun toppings outside of the usual Italian or Californian combos. The crust is nicely charred, chewy and bready (in that yummy way where you don't need any extra dips because the bread is good on its own). 

We got the pizza of the day - farm egg, braised pork belly and leeks. It was a very asian tasting pizza. Was there hoisin sauce? The egg was hard boiled and sliced like a tea egg. The pork belly was cut up into small chunks and sprinkled over the pizza with slices of raw leeks. No cheese, garlic or tomato sauce. Interesting but I'm not sure I'd order it again.

Also got the brussel sprout pizza which we loved! The roasted brussel sprout leaves combined with the sweet tart cranberry and savory brie and pizza crust. This is a winning combination. 

We got the polenta pudding for dessert but it wasn't like pudding in the American sense in that it was two polenta patties. I'd pass on dessert next time.

Yes, the place is run by a deaf couple and staffed with deaf people (is that the right term?). But it wasn't a problem to communicate. When you arrive there's a white board where you sign in. We used pointing and thumbs up to communicate with our server. I felt a little bad that I didn't learn any ASL before coming but it wasn't a problem.

They have $10 Margherita pizzas on Tuesday and a $25 prix fixe menu on Wed (pizza, dessert + glass of wine).
author: Jean K.

description: Pizza was amazing- service was impeccable!!! Great experience all the way around. Came all the way from Georgia to eat at this restaurant and it was totally worth it!!!
author: Ashley M.

description:
This is my favorite pizza shop outside of Naples and New York. Really amazing quality food. Very authentic napolitan pizza.

All the employees when I went there were deaf, which made communication a bit difficult but it was well worth it and I was happy for the nice quiet atmosphere which is the opposite of what I expect in anything aiming for an Italian authenticity. But it was a great improvement, just like them cutting the pizza for you instead of wasting the best 2 minutes of the pizza's life trying to cut it with inadequate utensils as required in Naples.

I'll come back here every time I go to San Francisco! It's great!
author: Chad M.

description:
Trying to earn "Pogi Points" (basically earn good graces from not only your GFs sister, but her mom), I wanted to take the L ladies somewhere good and hopefully a different experience.

Using trusty old Yelp, I looked up something Italian as the Mrs., her sister, and I didn't want Asian again (have to change it up), so I found this place via the app. I skimmed through some of reviews and decided to call right away as it was last night reservations.

So I call and a "person?" on the other answers. Almost delayed and robotic sounding voice. So I say, good evening, I'd like to make a reservation for four people. Long pause, then robotic voice responds saying that reservation has been made and see you there. So I thought for a second, what was the deal with the long pauses and robotic voice. *shrug

We get there and luckily find street parking literally right across from the front door. Mom doesn't walk too well, so we were blessed we didn't have to walk too far. 

We walk in, and I notice on the greeter's booth, a sign that says, "Do you have a reservation? Yes  or No?" So I think, oh, the waitress must be deaf. That's cool, so I basically nodded to her (very well lip reader by the way) that I did.

She takes us to our table and I notice on all the tables, there's pencils and paper...so I'm like, hmm..is everyone that works here deaf? (of course, again, just skimming through the reviews and not knowing anything about this place but the good reviews)

That's when it hid me like a ton of bricks. Everyone here is deaf. I'm glad I wasn't a jerk on the phone (with the whole pause and robotic sounding voice). 

The first thing I noticed walking in was the wood(?) oven that yummy things were appearing from. Excited, I didn't know exactly what to order, but dove right into the menu.

We started things off with the "special appetizer of the day"? It was a little bit on the fancy side, so I'm not 100% what deli meats/cheeses were actually on the plate (refer to pic).

We shared two of their "flatbread pizzas" which everyone liked. We started off with just one and ended up getting a second one. Mom loved it and so did Ate Weng and the Mrs.

What a great food experience and I would love to return on my next visit to S.F. Keep doing what you're doing Team Mozzeria!
author: Wes S.

description:
Certified "Vera Pizza Napoletana", this is the first pizzeria I've been to that has this certification, which has very strict rules, for example the wood fired oven must be 900 degrees and cook the pizza in 90 seconds. I watched my pizza go in and out since I was sitting at the bar and it was that quick! There are also rules for ingredients and technique. Never mind that the staff is all deaf, this is a great pizzeria! Everyone is very friendly and it's very easy to communicate with them, even if you don't know ASL. 4 stars because service was on the slow side, even though they were not a full house and they had a lot of staff working for a small restaurant. There were times nobody was making pizza and there were orders, including mine. They seemed to be socializing instead, but I don't know ASL. The pizza (I had the Margherita, one of the most popular items) was perfection. The food deserves 5 stars. 
Parking is very difficult in the area. I parked in a garage in another part of the city and got there via Uber.
author: Kristen K.

description: OMG This was a really good place to come and have a great pizza. This place is also for the deaf and my daughter has learned to sign so we came here on a outing together. The customer service is excellent and they have a beer/wine bar. 5 stars.
author: Chris L.

description:
This place is incredible. We've never had a bad experience here with the food or wait staff. We feel like it's our hidden gem in the city that we tell everyone about! 
The pizza is to die for, the crust is chewy and flavorful and has just the right amount of crispness to hold everything together. Margherita Pizza $10 Tuesday is a must, dare I say this is the best Margherita in the city! You can never go wrong with their Meatball or Burrata appetizers either. Overall this is a place you must check out if not for the pizza but for the serene cozy atmosphere. Thanks Mozzeria for being our favorite date night in the city!
author: Victoria T.

description:
Delicious pizza! Why go to Delfina and wait 40 min when you can have pizza that is just as good here with little to no wait?!

Because this place is run by a deaf couple, many of the patrons are also deaf. For me, it makes for a pleasantly quiet evening where I don't have to shout across the table to hear my dining companion. 

Love this place and will definitely be back!
author: Jaching H.

description: Freshly made to order pizzas! Absolutely delicious-and you can add toppings to the preset menu items. I ordered the Margherita and added roasted garlic. Everyone at my office was drooling after getting a glance of my pizza. Really novel idea - The workers use ASL to communicate which is a great way to brush up on ASL or to learn some! They are super awesome and cheerful and write your order on a board to confirm before you pay. I went to the food truck they have at off the grid but will definitely make a trip to the brick-and-mortar location some time!
author: Saachi G.

description: Our first time, even though it's our 16th anniversary. The pizza was okay. The waitresses are awful slow. Was not impressed for the price we paid for it. Would not come back again.
author: Michael K.

description: My favorite Pizza Place. If you are looking Pizza like they make in Italy, this is the place to go. The best thing is, usually you do not even have to wait in line. Also the staff is super friendly!
author: Klemens W.

description:
Everyone is deaf, and know sign language! It was so quiet, yet pleasant. Nice to see such diversity; this is what I love about SF.

Pizza is gluten free and very delicious!  I got the Salumi, my friend had the margherita
author: Sarah F.

description:
Not only was the food delicious, but also a great overall experience. Learned a bit of ASL, and visiting the website before our visit prompted me to download The ASL App so I could be prepared with a few words and phrases. The waitstaff was great with communicating with us in a way that didn't compromise the service or their mission. 

But the food is really what people should come for. Had the classic Margherita pizza, which was stupendous. It was so simple, but showed off the best version of each of the ingredients. Melty, creamy cheese; fresh, sweet tomato sauce; refreshing basil; soft yet crispy-bottomed crust...truly a great example of what Margherita should be. Also had the bombolinos for dessert, which I highly recommend. I love all forms of fried dough for dessert, and this was a delicious plate of donut, apple-lemon curd, and caramel sauce. Thumbs up!!!
author: Laura R.

description:
For the uninitiated, Mozzeria is an Italian-style pizzeria that is run and operated by folks who are deaf. This restaurant truly proves the universality of food as a common language and bond, which is truly a beautiful thing to experience.

That being said... I wanted to love this place so, so very much. I went in with high expectations (given the 4.5 Yelp rating) but was left disappointed after unsatisfactory food and extremely slow order-to-table time - hoping to come here again, though, to give it another shot.

I would, however, give glowing reviews to the following: eggplant parmesan (appetizer), margherita pizza, and the waitstaff.
To expand on the latter, the wait staff were super accommodating with my group; they constantly checked on us, refilled our water, and apologized for the lateness of our food. Although no one in our group knew ASL, communicating with them was seamless and easy.

Overall, low marks for the wait time after ordering food and the Farm Egg (it sounds good on the menu...but trust me, skip it!). High marks for the service, eggplant parmesan, margherita pizza, and location. Hoping to come back soon.
author: Olivia C.

description:
This is my first time visited a deaf restaurant. The service and foods was amazing! I really like the fact that this place is a mix of deaf and hearing staffs. For those of you who can't sign, don't worry they're easy to communicate with their gesture and write with paper and pen to facilitate communication. 

I ordered a small plate of Mozzeria Bar, it is a huge like mozarella stick. It was sooo good! That time I wasn't really hungry so I ordered it something small. I'll definitely come back to order with pizza. I heard they have the best pizza. :)
author: Helen Y.

description: This place is amazing! The server was so nice and patient with us. I think her name was Lupita! Thank you! The food was amazing! My asl teacher recommended it!
author: Lilibeth Z.

description: Very tasty, authentic, Italian style pizza. The crust is to die for. All employees are deaf which is super cool. Highly recommend!
author: Tucker A.

description: The pizza was good but I was not blown away. The server was friendly, but the service was generally lacking. Drink glass was empty for most of my meal, and I was sitting at the bar directly in front of the cash register.
author: scott h.

description:
After having a few drinks in the area, my husband and I wanted to grab a bite before we went back to our Airbnb. I searched Yelp for what was open around me and we came here based solely on the 4.5 star rating without reading any reviews. So naturally I was a little confused when we got there and the server pointed to a sheet that said "Reservation? Yes or No." It didn't take long to realize that every employee was using ASL. It was awesome. 

Ordering was simple. All of the staff were very friendly and looked like they really enjoyed working there. We had the Margherita pizza. It was delicious and tasted SO fresh. I wish it had been a little bigger but it was the perfect amount to share for a late night snack.
author: Kaitlin F.

description:
Mozzeria is fantastic! I've Yelped about pizza before, but wow! I think this takes the cake (or pie, in this case). We loved everything about it--atmosphere, servers, food, and wine. As for the pizza itself, I've often seen the wood-fired ovens, but I've never tasted the flavor like I did here. You can taste the woody flavor baked into the crust. It's remarkable.

We'll be back, regularly.
author: Shelley C.

description: it's great place to eat. very good pizza. also feel really good for help the coz. I highly recommended to go and check out awesome place to eat. staff was so friendly.
author: Laduram V.

description:
The pizza is absolutely exquisite. There's no other way to describe it. I've only had the pies here, not any of the appetizers. But why would you come here and not have the pizza? So good.

The crust is just the way I like it - thin and crispy. It's all hand-thrown and baked in a wood oven. They use unusual assortments of ingredients; these are certainly high-end pies. My favorites that I recall are the mushroom pizza and the hosui pear pizza, the latter having an unexpected balsamic drizzle that adds wonderful depth.

The staff is always courteous. I'm not sure if the entire staff is hearing impaired, but everyone signs. I've never found it to be difficult to communicate our orders and such. It's kind of cute, actually.

It's a wee bit pricey, but it's well worth it for the supreme ingredients and preparation.
author: Kelsey S.

description: Excellent food, true Napoli style pizza.  Friendly, attentive and relatively quick service. Would definitely come again. Only drawbacks were the drink selections- only had one beer to choose from and the wine was served too warm.
author: Molly M.

description: Tucked away along a row of unassuming homes, this pizzeria lives up to it's reputation. We came here for the food and ASL experience prompted by a classroom assignment. It's small, intimate, yet modern and inviting. Loved the Peking Duck and Margherita pizza. Loved the Bombolino dessert even better (baked bits with apple-lemon curd, chocolate, cinnamon sugar). Very tasty, and very creative! The area around Mozzeria deserves a mention as well. Very vibrant and eclectic community of restaurants, bars & cafe's. Great scene and eateries all over the neighborhood. The only challenge is finding a parking spot so go early. Bottom-line, Mozzeria may be partial silent but it's a colorful pizzeria not to be missed.
author: Eric T.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner at Mozzeria. I have a deaf son and am learning ASL. Enjoyed signing with with the staff. They were very friendly!  We got a Margherita pizza and added Italian Sausage. 
I will definitely be back. I would recommend making a reservation ahead of time just to be sure. It was super easy to make the Reservation on Yelp. 
It is decorated nicely and the pizza oven is prominently displayed. 
I can't wait to return and bring my family with me.
author: John A.

description:
Amazing Deaf-owned restaurant!! 
Staff is super friendly even for those that don't know sign language. We arrived 5 minutes before they closed, and they were gracious enough to stay open for us and were super friendly and inviting! 

I loved the pizza- and they have the great Mexican soda. Overall a wonderful experience and I would recommend it to everyone!
author: Ashley S.

description:
My family and I traveled from Michigan and Colorado to see this place. We are a mixed deaf / hearing family as well as multiracial (black white Asian Indian). Upon entering the restaurant the greeter was not very friendly. The dining experience went down hill fast. We ordered but they forgot my kids pizza. My eggplant was disappointing. The eggplant undercooked and cheese over cooked to rubbery consistency.  The cashier however was a bit more attentive and friendly. I asked that the kids pizza be removed and she did. We ordered 3 pizza and the eggplant. The pizza was good it was just the service and forgetting the kids pizza no one came back to check on us. 

We really wanted to support a deaf owned business but left disappointed.  gave it a 3 because of the cashier and the pizza we did get was good.
author: Sheryl E.

description: Everyone was friendly and yes all is in sign language the pizza was delicious highly recommended the Spinach if u don't know how to sign u can always point on the menu or better yet . LEARN the signs
author: Mii R.

description:
A long time on our pizza radar, Mozzeria has been on my shortlist of pizza spots.

I love the concept, but having a cool concept does not always translate into a great product. But their pies have nailed a perfect 10! Well in this case a 5.

A crust that by no means is just a crust, salted by Angels and dusted by unicorns and topped by fairies this is one serious pizza pie.
author: V B.

description:
Have I really not reviewed this amazing pizzeria?

One of the best pizzerias I've been to in a long time. Although not DOC, their Neapolitan style pizzas are very, very good. I had the margherita and it was superb. Not the best I've had, but memorable to say the least. I suppose I'll have to deduct a quarter of a star for that. 

The gnocchi was actually pretty darn good, too. I did, unfortunately, chomp right into a piece of bone in the sauce. I actually thought I smashed my molars into pieces, but luckily came out unscathed. Minus half a star for that. 

They also offer some really great local beers. I had the pleasure of trying Pacific Laboratory Brewing's Nautilus, which is a hibiscus saison. Simply put, it's probably one of the best craft brews I've ever tried. 

It can be a bit expensive for what you're getting, though. It's just pizza, right? MINUS QUARTER STAR! Maybe they have a happy hour menu - who knows. For sure, I'll be finding the time to visit more often in the future.
author: Aren A.

description: Had reservations at 7:30- still waiting for our table at 8 pm. This place is a complete - this place is a complete shit show. We finished eating and then took 45 min to get our check. Not sure how this place stays in business
author: Kristin S.

description:
We had reservations for 8 pm on Sunday.
We were seated within 10 min of checking in. The pizza took a while but it was well worth the wait.  Overall a great place and great pizza in a cozy atmosphere. Definitely going back.
author: Ange P.

description:
Ok, so we've sampled quite a variety of pizza places purporting to serve "pizza napoletana", which is quite specific and delicious when done right.  For me, this place is tip top. Chewy dough, correct "leoparding" of the crust, and absolutely fresh and delicious toppings.  

It's an interesting dining experience as well, since the owners and much of the staff seem to be hearing impaired, which I hadn't been aware of!  So communication was a bit awkward at first, but my wife and I were soon able to lock into their rhythms and we had no trouble communicating (I once learned the alphabet in sign language, but have long since forgotten it).  Pointing at what you want on the menu, some simple hand gestures, and one's meaning can be conveyed surprisingly well! 

Still, the star of this establishment is definitely the pizza. We'll be back!
author: Timmy G.

description:
I was like a BOSS ordering for the table and catching glimpses of other tables' conversations.  What do I mean?  ASL is used here.  I travelled all the way from Australia and on top of my "must do" check list was "visit Mozzeria".  

My parents, husband and I got in a NYE booking.  First thing, it was very quiet. ("OK, nice observation, Kristen, for a deaf gal"). Then apparently they put on some really good classic rock and roll, my folks were groovin' it must be good.  

We all ordered individual pizzas, my husband got two Gluten Free ones.  Mom and I also shared a salad.  All around FABULOUS!  The pizzas are authentic, with varying bubbled bases. Heck Mozzeria got an Italian certification proving their authenticity!  Way to go, guys. 

The one-pizza folks took left overs back to the hotel, the husband ATE all of the two pizzas he ordered.  What a ....  

My husband, the Aussie, asks me "how do you sign ("Thank You")?"  I nodded and stated he just did it (Auslan and ASL's "Thanks" are the same).

Note: they prepare/cook the gluten free pizza separately, so it is nice they are conscious of this practice.
author: Kristen M.

description: One of the most pleasurable dining experiences we've had to date. The all-deaf staff were so pleasant and, by default, patrons were obliged to keep conversations at an intimate volume so the setting was romantic and quiet. Great neapolitan-style pizza accentuated by a killer garlic sauce made this one of our favorite destinations in the city. Though by no means perfect neapolitan (real neapolitan nerds could geek out on the lack of bounce and airiness in the crust), it was delicious and served with absolute charm.
author: TwoIfOverland -.

description: The food was amazing! My girlfriend and I ordered a couple pizzas, beers, sauce dip, espressos, and shared dessert... All was superb. The pizza isn't greasy, we had Italian sausage and pear pizza, and the crust/dough had a great taste. My gf normally doesn't eat the crust of pizza but made an exception for this place. Service is warm and courteous. Melody was a server and she made us feel more than welcome. We were able to have short sign conversations/chat. What an experience. I have a deaf uncle who I wants me to take him here after my post on FB. We'll be back :)
author: LJ V.

description: Best pizza I've had outside of Naples.  House wine is excellent for the price point and great service.  Definitely will be back.
author: Grant C.

description: At Mozzeria for my early birthday! Pizzas really good the crust tastes like buttered toast. Margherita pizza is BOMB and they're lemonade w/ thyme is super good too. Definitely gonna come back and thank you to our server Leah! Super sweet also another thank you to the other workers for signing happy birthday to me :)
author: Merinna P.

description:
Loved this place!  My daughter is fluent in ASL but is hearing. It was beautiful to watch her communicate while the rest of the family stood in awe.  Service was great, waitstaff friendly and kind.  Food is delicious.  

Terrific experience for my grandsons and for me as well.  I've signed up for ASL classes in the fall and I'm 65!  I'll be back.
author: Ana Z.

description: Their Mozzeria bar and ducking pizza is die for! It's a must for you all to try these both! Kudos to the owner and their staff for their awesome and friendly service! Clap! Clap!
author: Tom D.

description: We went here for restaurant week and ordered one prix fixed menu and off the regular menu as well. The appetizers were half assed, the spinach salad was basically just spinach with a little dressing, cubes of cheese, and halved tomatoes. The charcuterie board was quite pathetic, just a few pieces of meet and cheese, and olives stuffed with raw garlic. The burrata is good but more like mozzarella. The pizzas were quite good but very salty.
author: Ally S.

description:
I don't think I've ever had a more amazing experience at a pizza place before. For anyone reading the comments and not too familiar with Mozzeria, the restaurant is own and run by a deaf family. All of its workers are deaf too. The workers and our waiter especially were so friendly, patient, and charismatic. My friends and I had a great time together learning some new signs and interacting with our waiter. It was such a fun and humbling experience like nothing I've ever had before. I'd absolutely recommend to anyone going to Mozzeria!

Aside from the friendly people and great service, the food was super great! I walked in as one of 7 people late in the evening. We all ordered pizzas, and they all came out at the same time too. We shared all around, and each pizza had its own character. They were amazing! I ordered the Margherita D.O.P. The cheese was superb, the sauce was tasty, and the crust was awesome. For dessert, the table shared the bombolino by our waiter's recommendation. Oh, if I could only have more!
author: Jen A.

description: From the food, service and staff....this place deserves 19 stars but I can only give them 5!!!!  This is a must!
author: Sophia M.

description: Small pizza 14$ ?!?!??? Way to much and on top of that a standard soda is 3$. Went here with a party of 6 and only bought one pizza everyone had regular drinks like soda/ beer, 1 beer even had pizza sauce in it(nasty as fuck). Bill came out to almost $60 and they add there own tip + take 18% out of the bill with out informing you first. Bad customer service, pizza wasn't even very good quality, very salty/ soggy. First time here with 4 members of my family members who are deaf as well, and will never come back. Fully support the deaf community but this place I say is a no go.
author: Audrey S.

description: Was one of the most amazing pizza experiences that I have ever personally had. The sauce, oh my god it was spectacular. My questions is how does one make pizza sauce that special. I believe god would know the answer but unfortunately he is not around to answer such a pressing question. The cheese was great as well. I'm a bland and boring food lover and a uninteresting person but your food made me rethink the start of life. I've eaten hundreds of cheese pizzas in my life but never come upon the one pizza that was the fantastic blend of them all. You made me understand why I love the stringy cheese and tangly sauce. Loads of cheese dishes have graced my platter but yours was the one that made it an experience. You are the pizza master. Thank you. I had a wonderful time.
author: Sophia L.

description: We brought a group of 16 to Mozzeria for dinner.   A mixed group of high school seniors and adults.   Family style B was served and was incredible.   We ALL loved it and had a wonderful time.  Amazing food and generous staff.   All in a quiet environment.    Our favorite pizza was the spinach pizza.   Crazy good.     Thank you Mozzeria staff.
author: M H.

description:
Optimal location in the mission. Quaint interior space. Friendly waitstaff (who many happen to be deaf). Wood fired oven. Hot fresh pizza. Dipping sauces. Yum!

TIPs: 

- The 12 inch pies are pick enough to split with two people

- Get the dipping sauce!

- On the menu, they charge a $10 cutting fee. I don't know what that is about but that is what it says. 

- Had a little problem communicating a custom order and recommend you use the paper and pencil if you had any out of the ordinary requests.
author: Tu V.

description: Great food, service, and it is pricey for a Neapolitan Pizza. Nero D'Avola and Burrata are highly recommended!!!
author: Denis I.

description:
Really like this place. Recommend the burrata appetizer, pizzas - especially the meat ones ...
skip the spinach salad , too bland ... Enjoy the unusual ambiance ...although in the heart of hipster land , i have never had a long wait .
author: Susan P.

description: The Margherita pizza I had was excellent. We really enjoyed the atmosphere and the service was great. The only complaint that I had was the wait time for the food. Overall I would recommend it and I will be back:)
author: Rick P.

description: The house burrata with balsamic reduction was very creamy and amazing. The server was super attentive to us, and I appreciated them making extra effort understanding us for not knowing ASL. Amazing DOP margheritta pizza! Melanzane parmigiano was amazing as well.
author: Yukiko W.

description:
Between lip reading, hand gestures, & writing out how we wanted the bill split, communicating with Mozzeria's deaf or hard of hearing staff was just as simple as communicating with any other person. Our waitress with the gorgeous curls was warm & efficient -- 5 stars for her!!! 

We ordered: 
-- spinach salad: liked the use of unique ingredients such as kabocha squash, pepitas, & pomegranate. Wonderful idea to leave the gorgonzola off to the side for diners to incorporate as much or as little. 
-- charcuterie plate: I can't comment on the hot coppa or prosciutto, as I didn't partake, but I sampled everything else -- sticky medjool dates, toasted hazelnuts, tellegio (a semi hard cheese). If i didn't practice some restraint, I could've easily gorged myself on burrata spread on fried dough all night. 
-- hosui pear: what I enjoyed most was the sharp & pungent brie, to which the pear, balsamic, garlic, & spinach took a backseat. Mouthwatering on paper, but disappointing in reality. 
-- farm egg: perusing the menu while waiting for our table to be ready, my two dining partners & I immediately agreed on this pizza. Yes, it would be amazing with millionaire's bacon, yukon potato, spinach, shallot-brown sugar, & a runny egg, we thought. For me, it was the worst thing we ate; the overwhelming sweet taste & an unidentified flavor (like cinnamon or anise?) overpowered all other flavors. 
-- pomodoro crust dip: a tomato-based sauce with much flavor depth. We kept spooning it onto their chewy, bubbly crust. A great accompaniment. Get this! 

Mozzeria's crust is on point, so I can be persuaded to return for a different pizza, perhaps one with more classic toppings such as the Margherita or Mushroom. Their eggplant parmigiana also calls to me. Three stars for my first visit with the hope of more deliciousness next time; their pomodoro dip alone deserves a second visit.
author: Fancypants X.

description: We came in during our vacation to California. The food was fantastic! The dipping sauces were delicious as well!
author: Laura L.

description:
It seems like most of the complaints here are in regards to some Gilt thing, idk what that is. I'm here to do one thing, drink some beer and write some reviews, and it looks like I'm all out of beer.

1. This place is owned and operated by deaf people. It was interesting to communicate in sign language/write on the pieces of paper given
2. It was hot in there. Like change your shirt hot. They seated us next to the pizza oven on a really hot day, so I was dying.
3. However, the pizza was really good. It had a slightly charred taste from the blistering oven. The arugula-goat cheese one was fantastic, it had a little bit of honey on it to add some sweetness. The margherita and 4 cheese pizzas were good too, a little safe but really good.
author: Samir K.

description:
Dinner at Mozzeria was a fantastic, unique experience. Our server was just wonderful and our dishes exceptional. 

We had: 
* Margherita pizza - chewy crust, great slight tangy sauce, slightly wet - just the way I like it
* Potato Gnocchi w/ bolognese ragu - the gnocchi's exterior had a slight (very slight!) crunch but it was fluffy and chewy. Bolognese ragu was flavorful and just simply perfect.
* Panna cotta (vanilla flavored) w/hazelnut and spiced chocolate. I am not a huge fan of panna cotta but we enjoyed this one immensely 

We typically try and dine in on Tuesdays for the Tuesday Special. You choose two small plates, a pizza, a pasta and a Bombolino dessert for only $39. What an incredible deal! This is quite a lot of food for two people so it's perfect if you're both famished. 

I've probably passed Mozzeria by a thousand times and regretfully never been before last Thursday. This has definitely become one of my favorite Mission restaurants.
author: Esther A.

description:
Mozzeria's @ eat real feat 2014. couldn't  resist. s.f. pedigree. a direct challenge to Forge? nada. styles are distinctly unique. 

locale: eat real fest 2014(9/19)

eats: margherita pizza slice (3)
-looked  iike 1/2 slice, toppings: fresh mozzarella, pomodoro cheese, basil
-didn't taste crust at all, it was so thin (sober but exhausted)
-tasted basil, creaminess of cheese, easily 5 stars BUT
just a few bites so 4 stars until an upgrade is possible.

crumbs:
-didn't look busy but they are so efficient
in and out within a minute, literary.
-fab service with a smile for lost eaters like me.
-pricey? maybe. worth it.
author: Victor G.

description: ASL friendly! They were able to accommodate with a senior citizen in my group with the seatings (she needed a seat with the back support)
author: Marsha H.

description: This is definitely one of the best restaurants I've been to in San Francisco. The food is absolutely amazing. We had the house made buratta, meatballs, Hosui Pear pizza, Mushroom pizza, and Margherita pizza. It was all TO DIE FOR. The restaurant is owned by a Deaf couple and the staff is Deaf, so all of the communication is through Sign Language or gesturing. It's a great experience!
author: Kaitlin J.

description: Food was okay,  ASL signing (we speak ASL) with our two,kids was much better than the food.  We had a signing night out and ecpveryone loved it, and that made the night special, because the food was not memorable.  Pizza was probably the highlight of our selected menu items.  The meatballs were tasteless and the mazarella log was cold but good.
author: M. R.

description: Three of us had a dinner here on Sunday, Oct 9th. My daughter is studying ASL so she wanted to practice her skills but communication with staff is really easy; you don't need to know ASL. Plus, everyone working was just friendly and fun. It is very refreshing to eat in a quiet environment! Menu is short but creative. We had two pizzas and eggplant parmigiana. Eggplant was great. I like my pizza a bit more done at the edges (crunchy) but the taste was subtle and simple. I capped it with two glasses of red house wine, affordable and tasty, and an order of Bombolino desert. I recommend Mozzeria to everyone who would like to have a nice, quiet, romantic dinner with quality food and affordable prices. I'll be back.
author: Savas T.

description: Mozzeria all employees fully Deaf very friendly more nice .one employees suggest select mostly popluar food list, perfect eat pizza.
author: F H.

description: I'm stuck between giving them 4 stars for the concept or 3 for the actual pizza but really I'd give them a 3.5. When I use to work at hiller aviation museum I worked with melody to book the truck for our Wednesdays food truck days. They were always great to work with and people working in the surrounding area loved the concept. I told my brother and sister who are both learning ASL about mozzeria and they both wanted to try it when they were home for the holidays. Even on the truck their pizzas were a tad soggy. The base of the pizza would get too wet and then made the cheese and toppings slip off. I was hoping the physical location would be different but unfortunately it was not. It happened to the pizza they ordered too. They did compliment them on their flavors and toppings but wished they all stayed on the pizza instead of them having to pick it off their plates. I ordered those little deep fried balls with the apple lemon curd and they were delicious!!
author: Yvonne L.

description: Wow, such great food and such good service.  My friends and I in my ASL class went to Mozzeria tonight (our ASL teacher suggested the restuarant), and boy was it worth it!  The food to was to die for and the people who worked there were super friendly and even conversed with us.  I got the radicchio pizza, and the truffle honey on it with the blend of cheeses was sumptuous, to say the least.  I was too full to order dessert, but it looked divine, so I'll have to order that next time.  Can't wait to go back, thank you, Mozzeria!  :)
author: Señora M.

description: The pizza was great but I cannot give this place 5 stars because the burrata appetizer was not good. I've had fresh burrata dozens of times and the burrata here seemed old and packaged like it came compacted out of a can. Ultimately the pizza saved the day.
author: Phil A.

description: Love this Italian restaurant! Their inspiring owners came into my hospitality class at SFSU. The waitresses/waiters speak ASL and they're very friendly.
author: Katie P.

description:
Finally seized the opportunity to check out Mozzeria with a friend of mine. I've studied ASL in the past but have not practiced enough to be fluent. Still, I applied what signs I knew which I think our waitress appreciated. You definitely don't need to know ASL though, as they're perfectly happy taking your order as you point to the menu (don't we all tend to do that anyway?) and they provide note paper and a pen as well to communicate. 

At first I was unsure about talking at the table, wondering about how deeply to immerse myself in a world without sound. But there's no pressure here at this restaurant, and my friend and I quickly resorted to talking and catching up over our meal. Perhaps it would have been different if she knew ASL too, it would have been nice to attempt a silent meal! Maybe next time. 

Try the house made burrata, I can't get enough burrata in my life! So delicious. Can't make a mistake with any of their pizzas, just choose your favorite toppings. We tried the mushroom pizza with gluten free crust which was super delicious.

I look forward to going back, hopefully with someone I can practice my ASL with! :)
author: Meredith S.

description:
An amazing little gem between Pizza Delfina's ridiculous lines and the indecisive group of friends who couldn't figure out how to use the Yelp app.

We were a bit caught off guard when we greeted by a waiter that points to a sign that says, "Do you have a reservation, yes-no?" but we went with it and we were glad we did.

Pizza is just plain delicious. Radicchio is a pizza we've never heard of, but it was the perfect blend of sweet, salty, filled with variations in texture and vegetarian. Enough for us to have room for ice cream later.

In the background, we have friends of the owners having a blast, smiles all around. A feel good place, though a tad quiet for those unfamiliar with the concept.
author: Anthony N.

description: Love this place. My husband and I go here frequently, both take out and dine in. Definitely a unique experience dining in. Love their pizza, especially the Raddiccio pizza!
author: Julie H.

description: Cozy little place. The pizza here was absolutely fantastic. It came out quickly and it was delicious. There were fresh ingredients and a few unusual options on the menu that made for a unique pizza experience.
author: Annalise S.

description:
It's a unique experience. Even if you do not sign, the staff is really friendly and make sure you have an enjoyable meal. 

The pizza is fresh and delicious. We ended up overeating. Go for the basics, though.
author: Neha M.

description:
4 stars for the food, +1 star for the concept. I don't usually like to boost my reviews for any reason other than quality and taste of food but Mozzeria was an amazing experience and concept. I had been meaning to try this place for a while because I had heard about it, but I finally got the chance to recently. 

It's amazing how when you walk into this place, it's so quiet and peaceful. Even though the waiters are deaf, they are so friendly and smiling all the time. It is surprisingly very easy to communicate with them! 

We came in on a Thursday evening and were seated immediately. We ordered the margherita pizza and the white peach pizza. The margherita was standard, but tasted great because of the wood-burning oven that they use. The crust tasted smokey and added a great flavor to the pizza. The white peach pizza was a super unique combination of ingredients - peach, cherve, cilantro and a balsamic topping. It was great and I definitely recommend it to those looking to try something new. The peach was just the right amount of sweet, and the cheese balanced out the sweetness to provide a delicious taste. 

I love this place and will definitely be back again; their salads and other pizzas looked delicious as well so I'm going to need to try them too! Whoever thought of this concept, it's great! So nice to see these people getting a chance to work in a job like this!
author: Malika R.

description: Very good pizza. Very busy resturant, so service was on the slow side. Ordered peking duck & Italian sausage pizza's, both very good. Also had butter leaf salad. Dressing was different but good. Price is a little high for the portions given, but definitely quality ingredients.
author: Keith L.

description:
We came in here one evening for a group dinner of sixteen folks. I believe we had made a reservation - as this place is not very large. It's a long, narrow, rectangular shaped joint.

We were given two tables - across from each other as they did not have a way to accommodate all of us at one table - which was fine.

As others have noted, the restaurant employs a number of folks who are deaf and/or hearing impaired. A couple of folks in our group knew sign language, so we had someone who could converse in sign language with the wait staff - which was better than just pointing to menu items.

I ordered their Italian sausage pizza, which comes with Italian sausage, fennel bulb, red onion, mozzarella, fennel leaves, and white garlic sauce - and a "Brew Free or Die IPA" from 21st Amendment Brewery (San Francisco, CA).

The IPA came out fairly quickly - we were all taught by one of our group how to say "thank you" in sign language so we could sign to our servers. So I signed "thank you" for my Ale.

The pizza came out fairly quickly - and it was oh so delicious! A very thin, crisp crust with fresh, delicious ingredients! I've never had fennel on a pizza before and very much enjoyed it! And the IPA hit the spot. A very balanced IPA - with nice crisp hop notes, and the right balance of citrus and pine, and a nice bitter finish.

Service was very good. My only complaint about this place is the temperature. The pizza oven is right there - heating up the place. They had the front door propped open and a couple of fans running - but the place was to warm and on the verge of being overly uncomfortable.
author: Neal E.

description:
I know that I must have been the envy of every man in San Francisco this past Friday night. 

Accompanied by two beautiful ladies and three gorgeous pizzas, an epic night was in store. Joanna M has been on a pizza scouting mission for months now. She has a knack for scooping pizza hot spots all around the Bay. Ever since she first forwarded me the details on Mozzeria we knew that would have to form a pizza protest strike and head over there and sample their pies.

Mozzeria has an interesting background. Owned by a deaf couple, they have one of the few real Neapolitan ovens in San Francisco. If you have ever had the chance to dine at Una Pizza Napoletana and gazed upon their oven, then you would know what I am talking about. It's the center piece of the restaurant and a thing of beauty. These ovens give birth to some of the worlds most tasty pizzas. 

The pizzas are traditional thin crust Italian style. All your favorites are included which makes it difficult trying to decide what to order. There were three of us on this night, so 3 pizzas for 3 people just made sense. We started with one of the specials, asparagus and blue cheese. We were told initially this pizza would have black truffle, but we did not see nor did we taste any. But given that the pizza had blue cheese it was probably best that no truffle was included and the pizza was quite tasty. Next up was the classic Margherita. We went with the mozzarella di buffala for $3 more which was the right call. I loved this pizza, and was my personal favorite of the evening. The clean up hitter of the night was the Pancetta. Another pizza hit! this pizza included a generous amount of carmleized onions. The onions added a hint sweetness which reminded me French onion soup. 

The pizzas are similiar to those you would find at Tony's and Una Pizza Napoletana. The only difference is that the crust is not quite as charred as the other two, but many of you might actually have a preference to this style. I loved it, but probably would give a very slight nod to both Tony's and Una Pizza Napoletana.

We were a hungry bunch and obviously could not pass on dessert. Two words here, Panna Cotta. This was a real surprise and did not expect to be nearly as good as it was. We ordered a bottle of Conn Creek cabernet and for $40 I thought it was a good value and worked well with our pizza choices. 

My wife, Joanna and I all agreed that Mozzeria is a true winner of a pizzeria and worthy of future pizza protest strikes. The service was spot on perfect and friendly. The servers and hostess were warm and eager to offer helpful suggestions. 

Mozzeria is located in the heart of the Mission which is one of the most vibrant neighborhoods in San Francisco. It's within easy walking distance of some of the cities best bars and nightlife. Parking can be a pain, but if you time it right and arrive around 6:00, you have a good chance of scoring a metered spot (Free after 6).

4.99 Stars
author: Rene C.

description: Love it!! The food is great! The staff is great and i love that it is deaf owned and operated! My signing is a little (more like a lot) rusty but hey were patient with me as i ordered and asked questions. I'm definitely coming back! I got the Margherita (which comes with fresh mozzarella, grana padano, pomodoro, and basil for $14). It is a 12" thin crust pizza that was full of flavor. It wasn't very filling (as is true of most flat crust pizzas) but it tasted great! DEFINITELY COMING BACK
author: Jayd S.

description:
The pizza is great,  You receive 4 slices per pie which is perfect for two.  Toppings are fresh.  Our little gem in the neighborhood.

The bombolini was amazing with the chocolate dip.   It's addicting
author: Mark S.

description:
I had no idea there was a society that sets the standards for Neapolitan pizza, but apparently there is, its called the AVPN and there are only 3 pizzerias in SF that are certified - Mozzeria is one of them.

Until now, the best pizza in SF for me has been indisputably Pizzeria Delfina. I'm feeling a bit slutty now that I'm thinking of cheating on my tried and true with Mozzeria. My litmus test pizza is Margherita - nothing beats the crisp thin crust with the slightest bit of chew at Mozzeria, but Delfina's sauce and cheesiness still wins for me - but we're really splitting hairs here.  The Margherita D.O.P. is  DOPE. 

And also, by the other reviews, you already know about the deaf owners - Maybe I'm an old fogey but I really loved how quiet and peaceful it was here. It was really cool to realize that we can communicate and have a good time without saying a word.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
A modestly decorated, unassuming spot in the heart of the Mission that serves great pasta, pizza, and has no wait at 8pm on a Saturday?? Bring it on - I love finding undiscovered gems like this!

Think plain white walls, minimalist black wood paneling. The only thing about the decor that slightly throws the atmosphere off are the gaudy modern metal lights. There is a nice relaxed pace to this restaurant, helped especially by the fact that it's not packed like just about every other spot on the block (please please keep Mozzeria a secret...) and by the mostly 2-tops and just couple of larger tables in the back. One of the owners herself, who's deaf, served us and she was very sweet. It was fun communicating with her by hand gestures and resorting to her notepad when needed.

The food was fantastic, but the dessert we ordered was a major fail =(. Still, I'd love to come back and try the butternut squash ravioli and margherita pizza!

* Potato Gnocchi - 4.5 stars
(pork bolognese ragu / ricotta / roasted fennel. $12)
This was fantabulous. You get a huge serving of pork and a deliciously savory ragu, and the gnocchi a fantastic addition. Minus 0.5 stars only because the absolute best gnocchi I've had was at Campton Place Restaurant in Union Sq where the gnocchi had an additional slight crisp, which I have since held to my new standard for 5-star-gnocchi. The cold ricotta was a great neutralizing counter to the intense flavor of the ragu.

* Pizza Special of the night - 4 stars
(green garlic, housemade sausage, yukon potato, thyme, white garlic sauce. $15)
One of the better thin crust pizzas in SF! (Best ever still goes to Una Pizza Napoletana in SOMA) The crust is super, super super thin and very light. Done very well, but the outer crust is a little airy - at Una Pizza I could eat the crust alone it's so delicious. I'm just being picky, I still really liked it. The sausage was a tiny bit disappointing as 1) there wasn't very much of it and 2) it's more ground-up and homogeneous than I thought. I like when italian sausage has a lot of texture, almost like chorizo. There were also only about 5 slices of potato, and they were a bit undercooked. But overall all the flavors + the thin crust worked together really well!

* Hazelnut Panna Cotta - 2 stars
(hazelnut / biscotti / aged balsamic. $6)
Big disappointment. Should have gone with the limoncello truffle. I'm a huge fan of panna cotta and was so excitd to see this on the menu; however, this dish was just off in so many ways. The texture was way too stiff, it was almost like cheap jello. The balsamic flavor was completely overpowering, and the crumbles on top way too sweet. It was really hard to get a right balance of the two flavors in a bite. The biscotti was stale, ie. soft and not nice and crisp as it should be. The flavor was off somehow too.. probably it was just the stale flavor.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
This is a neat restaurant. I was excited to practice my ASL, but then realized I forgot quite a bit of it. 

The pizza was just okay. My favorite was probably the fig one (which I tried to recreate, but it wasn't as good). The pizza may have been only just okay because we asked for it without the meat, so perhaps this review is really more of a 3.5 star review. The appetizers were just okay, but the service was great. Although there is a bit of a communication barrier, it was very easy to order. 

I would only go back for the experience and the fig pizza. Everything else, was just okay.
author: Julie L.

description: New Yorker here - This is unquestionably the best pizza on the west coast. I just had the standard Margherita pizza and the Veal and Pork Meatballs. Holy crap. Utterly blown away. I will be returning here.
author: Sherry Z.

description: This place is awesome!!!!! It's a nice cozy size & the staff is really friendly, even tho my ASL is minimal. The food is great & it's walking distance from BART! The prices are great as well. So in the words of the wise......I'll be back
author: Erika B.

description:
Dreams DO Come True...

I wanted to save my 700th milestone review for something special. I'm a true believer in giving back to the community but more importantly following your dreams. For this I would like to dedicate my 700th review to Mozzeria.

Mozzeria is owned by Melody and Russel Stein, the first deaf couple in SF (possibly the nation) to open a restaurant. Mozzeria is an Italian restaurant serving traditional and non-traditional pastas and pizzas. 

Its official grand opening is this Friday, 12.9.11, however, they are offering two tasting dinners this week with net proceeds going to charity. Dining for a Cause? I just couldn't give up the opportunity to do so.

Last night, my friend and I came to Mozzeria's 7:30 PM tasting dinner to benefit the California School for the Deaf and the Deafhood Foundation. Here's the tasting menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/chZfJOs022rr8DufI4r3Uw?select=Cqspz6xpcaOIoVNp2BC-mw (sorry I couldn't enlarge it further). Full menu will be available on opening day. Beer and wine only until they get their liquor license at the end of the month. 

F O O D
*MOZZERIA BAR ($7)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/chZfJOs022rr8DufI4r3Uw?select=hczuoWWfS0NP-I-4x_BcNA
The panko crusted jumbo mozzarella stick was fried to a light golden brown and laid atop a tangy marinara sauce and topped with a fried basil leaf. It was lightly crunchy on the outside with a stretchy oooey goooeyness on the inside.

*PORCINI SALAME & SHERRY JELLY ($6)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/chZfJOs022rr8DufI4r3Uw?select=qVIGXrQCyJvw_iXzPHNGyQ
Lacking in substance, there were just two small crostinis with a thin slices of salame forming a half sphere. I wasn't keen with the jelly as it had more of a liquid consistency.

*FRESH MOZZARELLA PIZZA w/ Neapolitan Sauce & Basil ($12): 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/chZfJOs022rr8DufI4r3Uw?select=cgvC_Io22hnw-Utzzc_31w
Served piping hot out of the oven, the slightly blistered crust was crunchy with a toothsome chew. The crust was sturdy throughout the center; neither soggy nor crisp. The Neapolitan sauce was fresh, vibrant, and tangy and the mozzarella was milky with the basil giving a touch of herbaceousness.

*CARAMELIZED ONION, FRESH MOZZARELLA & PANCETTA PIZZA ($14): 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/chZfJOs022rr8DufI4r3Uw?select=RCR3JjBSLhr3uKDm2ADyZg
Our favorite dish of the night, this pizza also had a slightly blistered crust that was crunchy with a toothsome chew. It was more cheesy than the Margherita and had more of a flavor profile with the salty richness from the chunks of pancetta and the sweetness from the caramelized onions.

Both pizzas have 4 slices each and are more individually sized.

*ARUGULA PESTO w/ Trofie, Milk-Braised Pork & Pinata ($8): 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/chZfJOs022rr8DufI4r3Uw?select=F79PlDgNruncUGa4hzoMng
Our least favorite dish of the night, the pasta dish was underseasoned and lacking in texture especially with the mushy peppers. Although the trofie (Ligurian gnocchi) was cooked to a perfect al-dente and the pork was ultra soft with a creaminess from braising in the milk, it could have benefited with a more assertive pesto and toasted pine nuts for some texture contrast (just my overcritical two cents).

S E R V I C E
Given it was a tasting dinner, it wasn't your typical dinner service. All 30 or so diners arrived at the same time so orders did take some time.

I have to applaud that Mozzeria employs an entire staff that knows sign language and all their servers were very friendly.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Casual elegant chic with crisp white walls, bright red furnishings, and retro chandeliers and lighting fixtures. The highlight of the restaurant is the Stefano Ferrara wood-burning pizza oven from Naples displayed in the dining area.

It's a small restaurant with about ~26 person dining room (good for parties of 2 only) and seating for 6 at the bar. My only gripe was the tables were lined up too close to each other so your chair is basically hitting your neighbors in back of you.

P A R K I N G
Difficult street parking.

With some minor tweaks and refinement with the food, I think Mozzeria will be a solid addition to The Mission, one of SF's foodie centrals. 

Mozzeria is truly a one-of-a-kind restaurant that has given me a new outlook in life. The Stein's dream of owning their own restaurant came into fruition this week which is a testament that dreams DO come true.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: The Food was delicious. We did not know how to sign, but the staff were great and patient as we wrote what we needed and communicated. We were next to the oven and the staff were thoughtfully to have a air cooler next to us. It was a such lovely evening and thank you for the very delicious food and recommendations and great service.
author: Sujatha S.

description:
Amazing shop. cute and clean  establishment. They have pretty good pizza and i liked their salads too. 

I am learning ASL at sac state and for one of our project I stopped in here since i was in SF. damn they are good. great customer service, even tho i couldn't sign much, they understood me. had great experience and i will definitely stop there when i go back to SF.
author: Nomaste A.

description: My wife and I are SF Jazz members who live out of the area. Mozzeria is one of our favorite spots for a nice pre-show meal that does not break the bank. Unpretentious, straight forward  presentations and quality ingredients. Good service as well. We like doing business with an establishment that supports the deaf community. And we have always been able to find parking nearby, which is a big plus when you are a visitor.
author: Dennis H.

description: The food is amazing, wonderful service. I don't speak ASL because I'm very bad at it but communication was fine. The restaurant is clean and inviting. LOVE IT!
author: Tree C.

description:
So Sunday afternoon, both owners are working. And the Farm Egg pizza had all the brunch requirements: soft-cooked egg, pork-products, toast, and veggies. Mozzeria is just damn good all the way around.

Most "gourmet" pizzas are just mediocre pizza crust with expensive stuff dumped on it. Here, they compose a dish that happens to be on a fantastic, thin bed of wheat (g-f available).

The ginger iced-tea itself is a composition, not just adding a flavor to iced-tea.
author: Richard H.

description: The Neapolitan pizzas are delicious, there is rarely a line, the staff is very kind, and then let you stay after dinner for as long as you want. What's not to love?
author: Lonnie S.

description:
I went to the Fremont Eats in downtown Fremont and had a wonderful discovery. The pizza Margherita. What a great pizza. It reminded me of the pizzas I had in Naples, Italy in my youth.
The idea of having a brick oven inside a food truck is remarkable. Such quality, such flavor. 
Thank you, I haven't had pizza this good in years.
author: Richard D.

description:
Chewy, doughy crust. My FAVE! 

I love Mozzeria, I just wish the portions were bigger!
author: Jess C.

description:
Bad customer service!

Added the pomodoro sauce for an extra $3.  Mozzeria in turn charged me an additional $3.26 for for the pomodoro sauce on top of the original $3, bringing the total to $6.26 for pomodoro sauce.

Upon complaining to grubhub i was refunded the $3.26 that Mozzeria added.

When the pizzas arrived THERE WAS NO POMODORO SAUCE!  Maybe it was by accident, or maybe it was deliberate i'm not going to point fingers.

The menu says 12" ours measured in around 10"

Really nice pizza boxes though, probably the best part
author: Steve G.

description:
We tried this place on a whim, looking for new pizza places in the Mission. The space is nice and it's conveniently located.  We quickly learned about the admirable hiring policy of only deaf staff.  They are very pleasant people and attentive...at times.  But we had an overall bad experience and mainly due to the food.  
Unfortunately the system of taking orders and calling a staff member over is not well thought out.  You end up either in a guessing game, Googling sign language (which was actually appreciated) or pointing to menu items on tiny font.  We did get everything ordered but when only one item comes out every 15 minutes including water, and staff walk away each time without waiting for 5 seconds, you end up feeling like they are not considering the situation at hand.  You can't pay obviously high prices for high end pizzeria food items and get this kind of inexperienced service. Granted this was our first time!
But onto the food...unfortunately we ordered the salumi pizza amd meatballs app. The pizza was blackened on the outside and hardly browned underneath.  The sign of too hot an oven and not cooked long get enough. FYI  It was not hat busy of a night.  The sauce lacked body. You have complex sauce at delfina, zero zero and others but this was flat.  the toppings were bunched together in patches creating islands of grease.  The meatballs which came 20 minutes after the pizza were bland.  Not enough fat, salt and herbs.  
Again, I appreciate the concept and hope this was isolated to one night or the owners wake up and realize the key elements are off.  But the high prices coupled with the food and service we experienced put us off.
author: Darius D.

description: This is a place manned by a bunch of slow pokes. There were 5 people behind the counter yet It literally took one whole hour for our pizzas to arrive, and there were hardly any diners around. When we inquired about the status of our orders after 45 minutes, we were told (by smartphone) that "next time tell us if you're in a hurry." Duh you serve thin crust pizza that takes 7 minutes to make.. why do we have to tell you we only have one hour? And what next time? We're not coming back... there are dozens of other terrible pizza places in this town!  The appetizers were meh-- blah salad and very mediocre meatballs.   By the way, the pizzas weren't worth the wait-- they were soggy centered and unappetizing, but you already know that from other Yelpers.
author: Ulysses L.

description: Great pizza!  Great service!  A little surprise. I had a pizza and it was as good as any. All the servers have a smile and it makes a real difference in the experience. I recommend this place.
author: Sean M.

description: Service was really poor. They messed up.our order, and gave our pizza to someone else. It had been 1 hour already at this point. It's ok to mess up, but atleast you can say that you are sorry.. not going back
author: Ashish M.

description: This review is specific to the gluten-free pizza. It's horrible. It's overpriced. You would do better with a frozen pizza made by any company that actually cares about gluten-free pizza. I got the margarita with the buffalo mozzarella and it was basically starchy dry cracker with a little bit of red sauce and four pieces of melted mozzarella. For $21. Meanwhile my friends around me were eating what looked like really good regular pizza. If you want gluten-free pizza, don't come here. It may be gluten-free, but it's a sad excuse for pizza.
author: Benjamin S.

description: First time trying this place was by Eat24. Saw the reviews and figured we should give it a shot. 48$ later for two personal pizzas we were really disappointed.  Maybe this place really needs to be eaten dine-in only because by the time they are delivered and even gently reheated the pizza is not good.  Mushroom pizza was pretty tasteless. Margherita de buffala was a bit better but still nothing to rave about. Crust dried out by the time we ate the pizza so can't really say much about it. I'm all for artisan pizzas, but we were really not happy about this delivery experience. Plus it was really pricey. I think the great reviews must be the "entire experience" thing... sadly just getting delivered pizza didn't add any of the magic.
author: Faisal Q.

description: Originally came here for an ASL project, and I definitely must say that I will be coming back for more. My group and I arrived at 5:30 on a Friday and there was already a line at the door. Even with this, the employees were very friendly to each and every group. We were all created with sign language and had a bit of small talk before deciding on what to order. It's amazing that there's a place like this that is comfortable for both deaf people and hearing people. Both deaf and hearing people came into the restaurant and seem satisfied. Just a note, the establishment is a bit small so I suggest making a reservation online before coming over. Also you'll have to park on the street you might have to circle couple times for finding a space to parallel park on. But it is all worth it, the pizza and the service are amazing. They also take to go orders and they do deliveries in the area, all of this can be found in their yelp info. Don't just listen to me, come try this place out!
author: Lianne W.

description:
I came here to hang out with a friend on a quiet Sunday afternoon and was first greeted with a sight that was completely unfamiliar and uncommon to me. The host was signing with one of the customers very rapidly while writing something down.

Only later did I find out that this pace was actually run by some members of the American Sign Language society and thus cater to sign languages, how cool!

I wasn't too hungry, but my friends' pizza looked appetizing so I had a slice. Definitely reminiscent of these wood fire oven pizza places making very very thin crust pizzas down in the South Bay. I guess it's a thing now!

It's all self serve so you just walk up to order, and find a place to sit. The water and utensils are laid out for you to take as needed. Great little joint and quite reasonably priced!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
They say they're open till 11 on Saturday; went by at 10:30 and was turned away. Wish I had known they take it upon themselves to close early when they feel like it. 

Still, the food has been good when I've been able to get in.
author: Bosie M.

description:
What a uniquely awesome restaurant and experience! We stumbled upon this place and didn't know that it was run by hearing impaired staff who communicate entirely in ASL. This just amplifies the experience and the great food. 
We had the meatball starter and then the pear pizza with a bottle of red wine they had recommended. Really brilliant food. The meatballs are a must. 
The communication gap made everything a bit more interesting. Highly recommend.
author: Abbadabbas L.

description: Great little Italian/pizza place in Mission.  It was a unique experience having to communicate with our server via ASL and gestures.  The pizzas were delicious and pretty filling for 12 inchers.  I also got the eggplant parmigiano,  be aware that it doesn't not come with noodles, Only 3 eggplant slices.  Would definitely recommend this hip join to anyone looking for great pizza.
author: Chelsea P.

description: Was awesome. Loved the veal pork meatballs... gotta check it out. Deaf owned and deaf servers it was interesting to watch the patrons there. I know sign language and it was so cool to watch. Check the place out!
author: Kanela L.

description: I took my teenage son and two of his friends all of whom are currently taking ASL class. They wanted to get get first hand experience with people who use ASL. Well, not only was that aspect of Mozzeria interesting, we loved the food, atmosphere and wait staff. This is a great place whether you sign or not. One of the teen girls loved it so much she said she wanted to come back for her birthday! Food is fresh and delicious! We will definitely be returning.
author: Jen R.

description:
This is the coolest restaurant I've ever had the pleasure of supporting with my business. How freaking rad is their mission? It was a very humbling experience when you remember that looking people in the eye and saying thank you with genuine expression is still very powerful. 

Onto the food, straight up- the margarita pizza rocked. EXCELLENT crust, thin, chewy, with the right amount of puff. The sauce was tangy, too, just the way I liked it.

I had two glasses of primavito and was pretty much knocked on my butt for a good hour afterwards- it was some really good, really strong, wine!!

Can't wait to come back for some handmade pasta!
author: Emily D.

description: Nice concept but bad pizza. The staff was very attentive and nice. I wish I woulda read the reviews before I paid $100 for a dinner that was not filling. Bread and Ragu sauce.
author: Stephanie B.

description: The food here is amazing!  My favorite item is the Mozzeria Bar off the appetizer menu. The food here is fresh and the service is usually pretty good since it's a small restaurant which is well staffed. The atmosphere is nice as well. The one thing I would change is the red chairs, I personally find them uncomfortable. Some tips: make a reservation and allow extra time to find parking because it's on street parking only.
author: Angi M.

description: Mozzeria is the best! I've been here many times, and have loved it always. I only know a little bit of sign, but the staff is always so sweet and patient with me. The food is incredible!!! Highly reccomend the burrata, margherita pizza, and the Peking duck pizza. You can't leave without getting the bambolino for dessert. Thank you Mozzeria for a wonderful date night! :)
author: Sarah K.

description:
We ordered the eggplant parm, house-made burrata, and the marguerita pizza. It was all gobby with melty cheese and delicious. 

Not so sure about the outsized pile of wonton strips that came with the burrata. I do need something to help me shovel the cheese into my mouth, but something so fried doesn't lend itself to the task. 

It was not difficult to navigate getting what we wanted. There's a pad of paper and pen on the table if you're having a hard time. We don't usually hang out with the deaf community. Most of the diners were deaf as well and at some point we realized we were the only people in the restaurant talking. 

If you're afraid of people who are different than you, then you probably should eat somewhere else. Otherwise, you'll probably enjoy the experience here on many levels.
author: Jason D.

description:
Excellent food, great service and great attitude!  Excellent pizza and appetizers. Your heart has to go out to them for being deaf and having such a great attitude and entrepreneurial spirit. Their service is great and I believe they have a hearing person there helping with the orders, etc. 
PLEASE check it out, you will not be disappointed.
author: Dave N.

description:
What makes this place unique is the mix of staff - hearing and deaf. Don't worry if you can't sign, there's paper and pens on the table to facilitate communication. No muzak to drown out conversation! 

OMG, the food! The veal & pork meatballs, mozzarella bar covered in marinara, radicchio pizza and dessert. The dessert was doughy cinnamon sugar dumplings filled with apple & lemon curd with a little Nutella on the side. 

Great friendly service. Worth many return visits. Too bad I live in L.A.
author: Toni R.

description: Great oven-baked pizza! Nice and quiet until more groups started coming.  I loved trying to figure out the non-verbal communication between employees.
author: Sfbay N.

description: I have been looking for authentic Napolean style pizza for a long time. This is the place! Everything about it reminded me of pizza in Italy and how it should be. The staff was very courteous and sweet. The place itself has a good feel and the food is amazing, even the drinks! Would definitely recommend this! :)
author: Mira U.

description: Food and service was wonderful! We had the mozzeria bar and the margherita pizza shared between two of us. Both were very good. Loved the atmosphere, would definitely go back!!!
author: Ellen H.

description: This is such a cool place. We didn't know until we showed up that all of the employees at the restaurant are hearing impaired. I guess the owners are hearing impaired and they hire people who are also hearing impaired. Even if you don't speak sign language it isn't much of a barrier at all but it's a unique feature to endear you to the place. The food was very good. We got the eggplant Parm appetizer and the marguerita BPO pizza with garlic dipping sauce. All are highly recommended.
author: Adam B.

description: Very solid pizza and kind staff.  Enjoyed the burrata very much as well. Would definitely go there again.
author: Trevor C.

description: Honestly can't believe how overrated this place is. I'm highly trusting of and dependent on Yelp to choose restaurants and was let down. Maybe we ordered the wrong thing but the salad was boring and bland and the pizzas were not good. The mushrooms on the mushroom pizza were raw (a no go for me) and the radiccio was just sugary/cheesy. For these prices ($13-20 for a personal pie) I expect better. The crust was notably good, 4 star. I would stick with the classics here.
author: Taylor J.

description: Really good napolitana pizza. Loved the great service. One star off for the less cozy interior
author: Ili V.

description: The food and service was fantastic. All of the different pizzas were amazing. And our server was so patient with us trying to eek out some sign language. My only complaint and the ONLY reason this is 4 stars is because the temperature was SOO hot, we were all sweating at the table. Get the temperature fixed and I'll give you 4 stars!
author: Kelly M.

description: I have been meaning to try this spot for years, today I finally got some delivery (via Grubhub) and WOW! I wish I knew sooner how amazing the pizza is. The bonus for me is you can order extra sauce for dipping your crust. I usually prefer a really thin crust, the middle of their pizza is perfect and the edges are a little chubbier - perfect for dipping. This will become a regular spot for me for sure. Nomnomnom...
author: Colleen B.

description: This place, so very very tasty. I've been there both times, they were both tasty experiences. Amazing appetizer of a mozzarella bar coated in some panko-like coating, super good. Pizza was excellent, crust is best dipped in their white garlic sauce.
author: Christina B.

description:
I noticed within about two minutes after arriving that were the only diners at Mozzeria who had stumbled upon the restaurant accidentally. While walking towards the bathroom, I passed a party of about twelve speaking in sign language to the waitress. Wow, I thought, what a talented waitress. And then I saw the waitress sign to another waitress, and to the chef, and finally, even the man dining alone signed on his way out. What an amazing discovery. I have to admit, I had never really thought about the challenges that the hearing-impaired must have in communicating with strangers. Whether one signs or lip reads, having to identify yourself as hearing-impaired in every first interaction must get really tiring. I think it's awesome that there's a restaurant in San Francisco where the hearing-impaired and their friends can go without having to worry about that. 

But please do not skip Mozzeria if you are not hearing impaired! The pizza was really, really good. Mozzeria specializes in Italian-style pizza with crackling thin crust and fresh toppings. I recommend the roast duck pizza with hoisin sauce and green onion. It's like an Italian twist on Chinese duck pancakes. (Have I mentioned that I'm a big fan of anything half-Asian?)

Mozzeria is also family-friendly. That's actually how we ended up there. We had plans to meet friends who were bringing their two young children at Chow. Except Chow had a sewage problem and had to close for the evening. Our friend did a yelp search for "family-friendly" nearby and Mozzeria popped up. And I'm glad it did.
author: Susan S.

description: This place is LEGIT! It's has thin crust pizza with the perfect amount of char to the bottom and the toppings are fantastic. Besides the stellar food and service, you're also doing good by not only supporting small businesses, but the deaf community too. Mozzeria is a winning combination of food done right and doing good.  Plus, they get bonus points for delicious beers on tap and solid wine choices. My only complaint would be that they need to add MORE basil to their Margherita Pizza. (However, that could just be me - a huge basil fan.)
author: Lisa R.

description: Went here for Dine for Life night, and liked the idea the restaurant was staffed by Deaf employees.  The pizza was mediocre but most appalling was the rush we experienced in dining, having arrived at 915pm.  True, the restaurant was much busier earlier and we were the last people seated.  In the middle of our pizza, the Waitress gave us the bill, and if that wasn't rude enough, she asked if we could take our dessert to go instead of eating it in the restaurant. The time was 9:55pm.  She also then asked us to pay the bill.  This is a good example of terrible service.  We wont' be back and feel bad it happened on a night to underscore the importance of dining for a purpose.
author: Jamie M.

description: House red wine, appetizer and pizza were so delicious! Worth of our money spent at this restaurant. The waiters were awesome, too!
author: Darline G.

description: Hello I love the pizza champ ... I seen some of waiter who work on cashier. ..check out the pizza without glove and serve the pizza...I would recommend use glove or wash hands before put something on pizza before hand to customers thank you for being deaf workers I'm impressed
author: David M.

description:
My "little bite" today was from Mozzeria

I ordered their Peking Duck Pizza ($6), it was an interesting combination, since duck is usually served with rice instead of bread. 

I have to say that the pizza was a little disappointing, since you were unable to taste the natural flavor duck has, like in duck confit. Their poor duck was drenched with the sauce, it was as if the duck was swimming in an oil spill. It was sad. 

However I liked their curst! It wasn't too crunchy and it wasn't too doughy!
