It was sad that they just covered their duck with too much sauce.

Go to my profile to find my blog!
author: Food G.

description:
We decided to have dinner here before a show last weekend. With so many great options in this neighborhood, it's hard to choose.
Since I was able to get a reservation, and I knew that thin crust pizza wouldn't take too long, and we had liked our food here before, this was our pick for Saturday night.

Neapolitan style margherita pizza is one of my favorites right now, so we shared that and their homemade bucatini with  tomato, escarole, grana padana and meatballs. The pasta could have been cooked a minute or two longer, but it was a good dish.
We also had a beet salad, and it was by far one of the best beet salads we've had anywhere. 
It has almonds, and grapefruit, and small amount of burrata, (which is all you need of such a rich, creamy cheese.) The different flavors and textures were really unique, and incredibly delicious.

Service is friendly and fast, but it can be tough to ask any questions about the menu, our server lip read somewhat, but we had to point to order everything. 

Prices are reasonable, and I think their food is much better than other places with similar food that are much more hyped.
author: Amanda G.

description: 3 personal pizzas, 2 lemonades and a salad for $100 is a little outrageous even in San Francisco.
author: Perry V.

description:
Since I read the post on Mozzeria by friend who recommended on  Facebook, my partner & I have made a trip plan San Francisco from Portland, Oregon for family visit. We thought that we would stop by Mozzeria & eat dinner. 

The place was awesome, friendly, cozy, & energetic and the staff were all deaf. A waitress was wonderful. I'm deaf & my partner is hearing & we  communicate great.  We ordered the drinks - Lemonade with Thyme & Ginger Iced Tea with Lemon,  the special - Roasted Rainbow Carrots; Carrot-ginger soup, & Housi Pear pizza (pancetta, brie, roasted garlic, Spanich, & balsamic). Little later, the waitress informed that the Carrot-Ginger soup was out. It was certainly popular.  She recommend Spanich salad (roasted kabocha squash, pepitas, pomegranate, creamy Gorgonzola, maple-dijon vinaigrette). The drinks were so delicious & the food was wonderful including a great salad.  We enjoyed it & felt that the visiting Mozzeria was well worth!  We would love to come back again when we visit San Francisco again.
author: John S.

description:
Great restaurant! Amazing service with very accommodating & friendly staff. We had reservations for 8:30, but when some friends wanted to have another round at the bar first, Mozzeria did not mind pushing back our reservation.

We were a challenging group - a vegetarian, a vegan, a gluten free, and a "no deep fried foods" person. The Mozzeria staffed handled it like pros. The food was all delicious! I really loved the pizza crust (the gluten one) - so chewy and amazing! Just thinking about it makes me want more. 

Great wine selection as well - we had a bottle of Barbera d'Alba and it was delectable. 

Another awesome bonus is that it wasn't super busy, even though it was a Friday night in the middle of the Mission action! Not a huge place, but I bet you could  easily walk in and get a table. Go try Mozzeria!!
author: Jinja R.

description: This was a lovely place with great food and very nice staff. Unfortunately the service was very slow.
author: Cloud G.

description: I want to love this place.  Who doesn't with it's inspiring story.  But good food is good food and this place doesn't have much good food.  The flatbreads are ok.  I don't even remember my main dish.  The wine list is amazing.
author: Kamael S.

description:
Nice wood burning oven pizza. Authentic Italian flavors...simple, good quality ingredients speak for themselves.

Nice, attentive staff. They show that they care. The next time I'm in SF... I'll be back.
author: Jim M.

description:
We had dinner reservations for a Saturday night, and we were seated shortly after we arrived. They also promptly brought a high chair for our infant son.

We ordered the Margherita and the Farm Egg pizzas, and they were both delicious. The crust was thin with a perfectly chewy outer ring and even had a mild sweetness to it. I also like how their pizzas are not overloaded with cheese.

Service was friendly and attentive.

The restaurant is deaf owned and operated, which makes for a unique experience. After reading a previous review, I'm glad we learned how to sign "thank you" beforehand.
author: Amanda M. C.

description:
(See pics) Review #1284. It's said that body language is what expresses yourself 90% of the time. Sometimes facial gestures and eyes tell a story.

Forget about the bustling loud style of a restaurant and come here to enjoy some tranquil feel with some amazing delicious food.

Each dish was cutely decorated and was tasty, filled with flavors. Spring pea with green garlic and ricotta soup was very flavorful. The lasagna with braised lamb, chili paste, polenta, roasted tomato, goat cheese and spinach was quite a rendition that I have not had, especially with polenta that gave such a nice texture. Had a glass of Josh cab from Sonoma and it was a decent pairing that brought out the taste of the dish.

The chocolate walnut torte was rich with lots of dark chocolate, which paired well with the cap.

They also have a big pizza oven, definitely something to come back for as well.
author: T L.

description: Everything was great but our pizza was burnt on the bottom & on the end crust pretty bad. Surprised they allowed it to come to the table. We waited a half hour for it & my son didn't want to wait another so we picked through it. But there was a lot on the plate left. A little disappointing as I took myson there because we are both learning ASL & heard the food was amazing as was the service.
author: J M.

description:
This food truck that is worth going to either for looks or maybe try a slice of their gourmet style pizzas. Their choices are so rustic and sometimes artisan for every food diet group whether its vegetarian, vegan, gluten free, paleo, or normal (what most people eat - herbivore and carnivore).
GREat staff and they know what they are doing too. 
Food is 5 considering the choices, selections and how they cook their pizzas. This food truck is such an unique experience.
I also love their food truck shaped like a cable car but has an oven too for their pizzas - awesome.
If Mozzeria comes to an event - check it out!
author: Jade M.

description: The rich flavor and chewy texture of the pizza dough speak louder than words. The sweet tart acidic tomato sauce balanced nicely with the blobs of mozzarella cheese. I've had the Margherita pizza at the SF Street Eats Festival and the Eat Real Fest at Jack London Square in Oakland. The pizza was fantastic. Just be careful not to drip grease onto your clothes!
author: Liv K.

description:
Perfect (first or second) date spot.  Good Friday night chill and casual dinner with friends -- probably not a place for a huge group, perhaps just ~4-6 max.  Flawless service and good food -- pizza with mushrooms was so good as one of my foodie buddies stole a few slices!  The braised dish with gnocchi and the meatballs were also yummy.  We were too full for dessert, but would have liked to try something!

Quiet but a still warm ambiance.  There is ample time to enjoy and focus on the food - visually and taste-wise.  There is a bar area for those tables for 1 and this is a place where it's *not* weird to come in alone and enjoy food and a drink.  The hostess was so nice and taught us a few ASL signs and was so great in recommending dishes based on what we said we might like.  

From 16th Street BART, this is going to go on my restaurant rotation list of date night spots. :)
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Artisan without the snobbiness of other SF pizza places. Love the simplicity of the menu, atmosphere is unassuming and inviting. Had a lot of pizza and left feeling satiated but not stuffed. I will be frequenting this establishment!
author: Richard R.

description:
The customer service here is top of the line. 
Everyone here is so friendly! =)

I came with a group of friends and we sat at our table for hours and at no point we felt rushed. The staff team always have a smile in their face and are so eager to assist. 

The food was delicious, especially the gnocchi and the marguerite pizza.
author: Monique T.

description: Mozzeria was at the 2016 Eat Real Festival. $5 for a slice of margherita pizza. While it was good, I think it was overpriced.
author: D B.

description: Mozzeria was great on every level! Even though we had a reservation, we had to wait a little while since it was busy but it was well worth the wait. The staff was warm and friendly, the decor and ambiance was perfect and suited the cute restaurant but the best part was the marinara!! We enjoyed the eggplant parm, the meatballs and the margherita pizza which all had the unbelievable red sauce on them. We'll definitely visit Mozzeria again when we go to SF!
author: Megan S.

description: Fantastic pizza, and I love their unusual combinations. We've tried most of their pizzas, and my favourites are the vegetarian options. The staff is super-friendly.
author: Silje-Maria M.

description: This place is delicious! I came in here off hours on a Sunday afternoon to get a late lunch and was very impressed with the pizza. It reminds me of some of my favorite pizza in nyc which up until now I hadn't found in SF. hallelujah! I ordered the margherita pizza and savored every bite of the thin crusted goodness. It was pizza heaven. Definitely coming back soon for dinner to try the rest of the menu!
author: Alice H.

description:
This was a great casual stop after a long Saturday hike. Lovely pizzeria. Crusts are flavorful thin and crisp. We had spinach - nuts were a nice addition - and sausage, both were quite tasty. Loved that we were able to make a reservation. 

We did not know the staff was deaf so felt foolish when we arrived and asked about our reservation. The service was delightful and really enjoyed the experience.
author: Brad B.

description: this spot has been on my list for a while - so i was really excited when it appeared on the sf restaurant week list!  made a reservation for 5 on a friday night and the place was at a low hum - only a few tables left to be claimed! it was a really good experience interacting with the employees, albeit slightly challenging at times.  we got two bottles of wine (only $25 each!) and ordered mostly off the set menu (pizza!), though i got the meatballs (beef + lamb), roasted veggies, and peking duck pizza. meatballs were flavorful, but perhaps not as tender as im used to from tony's or italian places in iNB.  veggies had too flavor, but nothing spectacular.  the duck pizza though - crush was good and toppings were too! i was pretty happy with this.  my gf's tried it, and i also otried their rainbow chard pizza with a generous shaving of parmesan.  i would definitely come back here - great experience.
author: Christina L.

description: My friends and I came all the way from Sacramento just to come here The pizzas where delicious, even if you don't have any knowledge in ASL noooo worries, the employees where nice and welcoming, I only got frustrated when I forgot a sign aha but my experience was great, my friends and I can't wait to come again
author: Diana F.

description: great veggie pizzas and eggplant parmesan, and the fact that the entire staff is deaf makes for a pleasant and eye-opening experience. it was easy to communicate through none of us knew ASL, a lot of gesturing and writing down of orders.  a lovely experience and one i'd like to recreate again!
author: Archana P.

description: I've been here 5-6 times. Pizza is always amazing, definitely one of the best in SF. Service is great. Prices are very reasonable. Highly recommend if you're looking for casual good eats in the mission.
author: Pea N.

description: Staying around the corner, I moseyed over to Mozzeria for a margherita pizza. It was very well made - on a simple margherita there aren't a lot of ways to mask problems, so if the cheese, crust, or sauce aren't working, you'd know where the issue was and why. The crust and cheese were excellent, but I do wish the sauce had more of a punch. I think that would have pulled it all together and elevated the pie, but I would return to order a version with more ingredients to see if that gives me a fuller flavor experience to complement the solid base.
author: John M.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this restaurant!

I've been here twice now and have had a thoroughly amazing experience both times. The restaurant is deaf owned and operated, which is super neat. The service has been outstanding on both occasions.

A few menu favorites:

Buratta - seriously creamy and delicious
Sausage pizza - I don't eat red meat very often but this pizza was definitely worth breaking the rules

Honestly, I can't even think of the slightest negative thing to say about this place! The prices are comparable to Delfina and cheaper than Ragazza. People apparently don't know how great this spot is because I haven't encountered any wait (although I've only been on weekdays).

I'll be back for a third try soon.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
You may think it weird I'm writing a review for a place I've yet to experience, BUT, I am an interpreter and wanted to experience, first hand (no pun intended!!) this place. Another friend (Deaf; as well as my son (Hard of Hearing, but skilled ASL signer) and his girl friend) made reservations for this place. We went round and endlessly round, trying to find parking and FINALLY called it.  They were, via Sorenson (real time phone interp services) very sweet and I allowed we wouldn't be showing up that particular time. I told them we simply couldn't partake of the place as parking was impossible.  So...NEXT time, as I WILL make that effort, we will try to be somewhat inventive as to how to orchestrate this problem.  I think the most discouraging part of this is that we made the trip all the way from Fairfield/Vallejo area.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Have since been there (with a Deaf friend) and it was just so/so. I know SF is a high rent district and I guess we, its customers, absorb the cost. Although delicious, and well made, we left hungry and poorer! I try to support Deaf businesses but unfortunately I can't see fit with this one...and as stated earlier, I don't live there so it's really not feasible, anyway. I wish them luck, most certainly.
author: Chris G.

description: We really enjoy this place! Been here a few times and it's always delicious and the staff is very kind and friendly. Brought my fiancé here last night and he kept mentioning how much the pizza reminds him of pizza back at home in Italy. The eggplant parmigiana is so so good, the marinara sauce is perfect. We'll be back again and again!
author: Chauanh D.

description: Great experience here! The entire staff was friendly and the food was delicious. Had the veal pork meatballs and the Peking duck pizza.
author: Will F.

description: Wow! Very delicious pizza. My favorite pizza is duck Peking. Other pizza is good too.
author: Keith A.

description:
I think the place has a cool concept. It's run by a deaf couple and the employees are also deaf. It was great to experience the culture. The decor is nice - clean lines, bright, yet homey. Very San Francisco. 

I would give the food 3.5 stars. My friend and I split a pizza dish and the gnocchi. I wasn't impressed with the pizza - it was your standard thin crust. I thought the gnocchi was pretty good - soft and fluffy with a flavorful sauce. We ordered the ricotta coffee cake for dessert. I thought the cake was dry and there was too much caramel sauce. 

I was disappointed with the service. We waited over an hour to be seated and our waitress had a lot of trouble pouring our beer from the tap. I could tell that the owners and waiters/waitresses try hard and they were a bit stressed that night.
author: Caroline C.

description:
To begin, you should know that I LOVE authentic Neapolitan pizza. When we were planning a trip to San Francisco, I decided to look up VPN-certified wood-fired pizza places, and came across Mozzeria. They have a great back story (owned by a deaf couple), so we decided to check it out with a couple of friends who live in SF. 

We made reservations online for a Friday night, so we were seated right away. The pizza was exactly what I was looking for - perfectly chewy crust, sweet San Marzano tomatoes, and mozzarella di bufala (buffalo milk mozzarella) on my favorite - the Margherita D.O.P. 

The staff was great. I think our waitress was a skilled lip-reader, and between that and pointing at the menu, we didn't have any issues communicating. She also had a great sense of humor. While we didn't need it, there are little slips of paper and pencils on the table, in case you need to communicate that way. 

The one downside is that it was hot in the small restaurant. I'm told it was unusually warm in SF that weekend, and we were seated very close to the pizza oven, which bakes the pizzas at 700+ degrees. That said, I'd gladly sweat for this pizza again and again!
author: Amy K.

description:
The first time we went to Mozzeria, we didn't realize the staff was deaf.  The experience was definitely interesting and the food was great so we vowed that we would come back. 

Mozzeria ran a promotion through Gilt City so I purchased it for me and my boyfriend.  For $45, we shared a bottle of red wine, two appetizers, two pizzas and a dessert.  Perfect for a date night!

Also, the Quattro Formaggi pizza is our favorite!
author: Siv L.

description:
I LOVE this resturant! My favorite dish and I order it every time is eggplant parmeseana!!! It's crispy and creamy at the same time with the perfect amount of cheese and sauce.  Their pizza reminds me of when I was in Italy and would stop into a place for a slice.  Fresh and innovative recipes that vary with staples always there.  The desserts are always a pleasure and a surprise!!! 
It's fun to be with the Deaf world ~ very effecient and friendly and full of life ~ and oddly enough, they play nice music~!
author: Tura F.

description:
Definitely a-ok. 

love the fact the restaurant is owned and serviced by deaf people but i thought the pizza was mediocre. really small -- 4 slices.

when it comes to thin pizza i prefer Tony's at North Beach.

Shared two small plates & two pizzas with my gfs:
1. Roasted Japanese Eggplant - pretty good. eggplants were roasted nicely.
2. Crispy Pork - need more crispy pork! 
3. Margherita - Tony's is better :P but the crust was baked nicely but i just wish it was bigger!
4. Italian Sausage - Had nice flavor. 

Great but slow service -- i guess because there is only one oven?

Their sangria is good though. 

I wouldnt come here again because there are better options for pizza or maybe im just not a pizza lover because i wouldnt pay that much when i can go to LIttle Star or even Irving Pizza!
author: Carol Y.

description:
Was in a pinch so ordered from Mozzeria using Caviar, so this review is more about the food vs service.

* Veal-Pork meatballs were succulent. Tender and very savory for those truly into veal.
* House-Made Burrata was very good.
* Quattro Formaggi pizza is very addicting. If I could eat this for dinner everyday, I would as I am a fan of cheeses.
* Mushroom pizza was savory and very delicious.

Overall, the food was well worth the price. I will admit, getting Neapolitan pizza delivered is usually a losing crap shoot, but this was a win! I would def order from them again if I'm craving savory Italian food.
author: D M.

description:
Mozzeria was the perfect place for a last minute, large group (8) dinner on a Friday night during the holidays. My friends and I enjoyed the family-style service, which was far more food than we could eat. Our waitress Tiffany was friendly and thoughtful and even asked if we were celebrating a special occasion.

What I liked most was the atmosphere. Comfortable, casual, and not too loud to enjoy a conversation among old friends who needed a long catch up.

Oh, and as other reviewers have said, the food was delicious!
author: Robin P.

description:
Hands down the best pizza I've ever had! I am extremely picky about pizza - I love thin crust and the sauce has to be just right - not too sweet and full of flavor. Their wood-fired oven pizza is incredible. The crust is thin and perfect (Neopolitan style). The sauce is out of this world (pomodoro tomato sauce) -- in fact, you can order a side of sauce to dip your pizza crusts in for $3. We had the margherita pizza and charcuterie pizza. Both delicious, though my boyfriend and I both agreed that the margherita was better. Their wine selection is very nice too. 

The restaurant is deaf-owned and run, so you will interact with deaf waiters! Don't worry if you don't know sign language - they have paper & pen available at the table for you in case you need to write down questions or what you would like to order. You just need to gesture a bit with them - such as making eye contact, speaking clearly, and pointing to the menu what you would like. Do keep in mind that deafness varies - I am deaf and can lip read, so speaking clearly would help for me, but it seemed to me that the majority of the waiters/staff there were very much so deaf. So writing things down, gesturing and pointing will definitely help. Other than that, it's no big deal and an awesome cultural experience!
author: Allysa D.

description: Perhaps in-store dining is what gets this place a 4.5 star average.  But as a delivery option it is quite poor.  I ordered with Eat 24 and the order took solidly over an hour to arrive.  The store didn't answer the phone when called to check on the status.  The pizza itself was not delicious, and was quite cold by the time it arrived.  They also ran out of ingredients and so had to make a substitution.  For $45 for 2 pizzas, I would expect better.  They were small to boot!
author: Joseph G.

description:
Want a new dining experience!!  Go to one of the new SF businesses owned and operated by Deaf people.  There are paper and pens on the table to make ordering and communicating a breeze.  We did a bit of restaurant rubbernecking while waiting for our food.  We loved watching all the sign language in use around the restaurant. The people that  took sign language in school had a wonderful time showing off their communication skills.  There was an eclectic mix of hearing and deaf people in the restaurant.  It was a great  experience!

The food was wonderful and there was a varied selection available.  Pizza ranged  from meat laden to veggie specials.  The salads were fantastic and there were vegetarian pizza choices!  The place was clean and the staff was very friendly.  The prices were very reasonable for the food we received.  Our group enjoyed several different pizza's and salads along with some wine and beer.  We are definitely going back next time we are in SF.
author: Mary M.

description:
Yum! This was the last dinner of a romantic trip to San Francisco and Napa. My boyfriend looked it up online and found a lot of positive reviews, and we decided to give it a try. 

We were both surprised that the staff used sign language (we did not read the reviews, obviously), not only did it now bother us but made the experience extraordinary. The food was excellent (we had the meatballs as appetizer and margherita pizza as entree. They were both so yummy!! We even had dessert and coffee despite the fact that we were both stuffed - could not resist! 

The restaurant was very cozy and homy. The atmosphere was friendly and perfect for a simple and good dinner. We sat at the bar near the Brock oven and enjoyed watching the pizza being made. Fresh simple ingredients!

Overall, perfect ending to a fun, romantic trip!
author: Sara P.

description: Mozzeria has some of the best pizza in San Francisco, full stop.  The blistered crust is at the level of places charging $5-10 more.  Moreover, it's the kind of neighborhood place that you never want to stop visiting.  A few pizzas, a salad, an affordable bottle of wine, and some friends.  What more could you ask for?
author: Sam M.

description: I would say this pizza was delicious expect spinach pizza, it wasn't delicious as I thought it would be. The waitress and waiter I wasn't satisfied with their service. Didn't ask us if there were anything else or if we are good or ? And the dessert I was disappointed about the dessert and was hoping the dessert should be more food style and rich food. Overall, the pizza was good expect dessert and services. I came all the way from Washington, D.C. And was hoping to meet the owner and food and service and it didn't turn out what I expected.
author: Rita T.

description: This place is fantastic. All the staff are wonderful and kind, the food is out of this world good, and the ambiance is fun and classy. I can't recommend this place enough. Great for families.
author: The Tall One Y.

description: Service was good, but I didn't like the pizza. The ingredients were fine, but they were served in such a sparing amount. The pizza ratio is wrong. Too much bread and not enough toppings.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Interesting experience as the workstaff are all deaf. 
They do give you pen and paper to ask questions if you don't know sign language.
Their service was prompt and friendly.
Mozzerella sticks were yummy. The sauce was tasty.
Also their peking duck pizza was interesting, wished they gave me more green onions.
author: Tsu C.

description: Tasty and not super cheesy pizza. The burrata was ok - it had a film on it as if it was not fresh or store bought and placed on the platter. The chips with it were not evenly fried too so for one chip there were corners that were nice brown and white dough in other parts. We've had burratas at other italian restaurants so found this one ok. We didn't know about some of the servers being deaf so weren't sure if we weren't following any protocol while ordering and/or inadvertently offending anyone. Our server was v sweet and amiable. The place had a distinct smell - perhaps because of the cheese. Small place but overall decent experience.
author: Sea Turtle M.

description: I visited this restaurant without realizing it's owned and operated by hearing impaired people. My ASL skills are lacking but I was able to communicate with the waitstaff easily. The staff were incredible and so kind. The pizza was great. It was flavorful and not too heavy. I would definitely return to this restaurant on a future visit to the city.
author: Raquel E.

description:
Items ordered:
Margherita DOP
Peking Duck Pizza

Located in The Mission and boasting VPN certification despite several pies one would never see in Naples it was with high expectations that I approached Russ and Melody Stein's Mozzeria, the small shop having received plenty of attention for its all-deaf staff but according to many not nearly enough for the quality of its product.  Largely trattoria in concept featuring an array of pizzas plus a few small plates during counterside lunch with additional pastas and secondi appearing for table-service dinners it can rightfully be assumed that anyone importing a two-ton Stefano Ferrera oven is serious about their craft and with a minimalist décor of red, black, and wood as local arts decorate the walls the diners attention is squarely focused on the plate...or at least it should be after watching Russ expertly stretch, dress, and fire the rounds of '00' dough.  Burning around 850F on a combination of pecan and oak a pizza at Mozzeria begins with a smoky char to the pliable crust and featuring light saucing amidst pools of bubbly buffala mozzarella the Margherita DOP was a reliable classic while the crispy duck skin and supple flesh topping a crust flecked with sesame seeds that followed was simply stunning - a touch of hoisin and scallions served alongside added to outperform many more 'authentic' attempts throughout the United States.
author: Michael U.

description:
Can someone explain to me the big deal about this place? Had delivery through Caviar last night and was very unimpressed.

The romaine salad was 100% completely tasteless. Sure, I had it without cucumbers, but there's no way that one missing component could have sunk the salad. And if it did, they simply shouldn't have let it go out that way.

And then the pies--a huge "meh." The regular cheese pie was ok but definitely not nearly as good as Delfina, Gioia, etc. And the crust was super super chewy in a very difficult way. I had to power through just to finish one crust. I guess once these pies get cold you're not going to have an easy time with them.

The mushroom--major disappointment. Why do people think slathering things in truffle oil will make up for a lack in flavor? The mushrooms had zero earthiness, the goat cheese was pretty forgettable and the whole pizza just fell flat.

And the price tag--geez. Soooo much better pizza in the city--and this is a city that doesn't have a ton of good pizza in general, lol.
author: Paul C.

description:
I have been to Mozzeria several times, because the food is delicious!  My fiancee and I were searching for caterers for our wedding (rehearsal dinner), and when I learned that they also cater, I knew it was a no-brainer.   

We were so pleased with the outcome, everyone loved the meal!  Our meal consisted of a charcuterie platter, salad, stuffed tomato, beet tart, and lasagna.  Petit Fours for dessert.   I especially loved the beet tart and the buratta with honey/nuts!

Plenty of email communication to get everything just right ... Melody is not just an excellent chef, but also a wonderful person to work with.  If it matters, I am not deaf and I don't sign.   Emails to get everything setup just right, and pen/paper at the event worked out perfect.

I would absolutely choose them again for another party.
author: David B.

description: The burrata app is pretty gross. No clue what those fried things are supposed to be about, but they aren't appealing with the cheese or without it. Also, the burrata cheese itself is very disappointing and gross. It wasn't creamy and fresh; it tasted old and had an odd texture. The pizza is fine, but I feel there is better out there. Won't be back.
author: Christine H.

description: All the servers speaking sign language made for an intimate and unique dining experience. On top of that the food was delicious! The radicchio pizza is the best pizza I've ever eaten! The most interesting combination of flavors. Not too pricey either!
author: Jenni M.

description: Great pizza.   Nice room.  They were very understanding and patient with my son's freshman level american sign language skills.   We had a good time.  Nice people.
author: steve P.

description:
Whether you're like me, a student learning ASL, or Deaf, this place is perfect if you're craving some awesome Italian food. 

I've actually been here two times. The first time, I ordered the Margherita pizza (by the way, if you have time, go on Mozzeria's website, read their blogs and see how they got their brick oven and how it works). It was just pure perfection. The pizza is nice and thin, and the crust is soft. 

For dessert, I forget the name, but it was a coffee cake with apples and a caramel sauce on top.....holy goodness.. 
So we know the food is incredible. Enough said.

As far as the customer service, I was very surprised how even though all the employees are Deaf, they still have different ways of making all their customers feel welcome; hearing or not. So you don't need to be an ASL master to eat here (however, any efforts made are greatly appreciated). 

The only downside is that the food is a bit pricey. But considering the level of service and quality you receive, it makes it totally worth it :)
author: Mitchell P.

description:
Delicious, most authentic Neapolitan-style pizza I've had in the U.S. 

Along with a pizza margherita, had a rice ball or arancini [another southern Italian classic], as part of the Wed. $20 special--appetizer/pizza/dessert. It was lightly crisp on the outside and bursting with flavor, garnished tastily with basil paste etc, and very prettily, too. People sitting next to us had beautiful antipasto plates with an assortment of marinated vegetables including large fava beans--also v. southern Italian.

Nice atmosphere/decor. If you sit at the bar, you can watch the pizza making. The pizza chef is in charge of an enormous wood-burning pizza oven that reaches 1,000 degrees inside, but is just 79 degrees at its mouth. The pizzas go in and come out beautifully blistered with pools of melted mozzarella within minutes. Chef said they use almond wood for the flavor it imparts.

Deaf staff are welcoming and enjoy communicating with customers, whether via lip-reading, or hand signals or writing on scraps of paper--or a combination of all.

It definitely was a dinner to remember.
author: Barbara N.

description:
I had the pleasure of tasting their radicchio pizza this past weekend at a Centennial Celebration I attended.  The crust was wonderful, the radicchio was perfect.  The price was reasonable, and the portion size unbelievable.  

Their employees are deaf, and it was wonderful to see regular joe's ordering with sign language.  It was a great experience, and the pizzas were very good!
author: Denise G.

description:
Such a unique experience!
I'm not familiar with ASL, but my husband was somewhat knowledgable. 
There was no feeling of awkwardness because of the language barrier. It can be described like reaching out and working together to achieve a common goal. 
Anyways, our server was great and very attentive. Overall feeling was welcoming and calm. 
I ordered the brussel sprouts gluten free pizza and my husband ordered the margherita gluten free pizza with the thyme lemonade. 
Everything tastes wonderful and the red sauce was to die for!
The only "thumbs-down" was the prices. I don't know, maybe I'm just a typical out-of-towner, but I just feel like the food didn't necessitate the prices. 
I would recommend Mozzeria for the experience!
author: Emily R.

description: Both food and service were excellent. My personal favorite was the margherita pizza - it was so delicious and the crust was so soft. Do try out their crust dipping sauces especially the white garlic sauce - yummy!!
author: Jothi V.

description:
I've been coming to Mozzeria for about 10 times now. Aside from the awesome Deaf workers who communicate in sign language, Mozzeria serves great food.

After traveling to Europe and Italy in particular, I never thought I'd find an equal to their pizzas back in the United States. I was wrong. Mozzeria is legit especially with their italian-imported oven! It depends on your taste but any pizza on the menu is a good pick. Won't go away disappointed, that's for sure!
author: Joshua W.

description:
I'm from So Cal but was in San Francisco and ate here with some friends.  The ambiance was very good.  Casual, yet trendy; upscale, but not pretentious; intimate enough for a date, yet I saw one young child.  The centerpiece was a huge wood burning oven.  The owner said they bought it in Italy.  It was nice, inlaid with tile, and made for a really cool attraction while sitting at or near the bar -- anywhere in the place, really since it's a fairly small restaurant.

For the food...  for starters, I had the Mozzeria Bar...  basically fried mozzarella cheese.  It came with a nice red sauce, slightly chunky and was very good.  It was not your typical fried cheese stick from a frozen bag like they serve at TGIAppleChiliTuesday's...  You could tell this was fresh and made on site.  I don't normally get fried anything, but I'd have this again.  

Then I had the Duck Rilletes.  I had to ask what the Rilletes were.  I forgot what they were, but they were good.  

(I started this review three years ago and only now see it never posted.  I've since been to this restaurant about 5 times.  Always good.  Always good service, good food, and good beer.)
author: Eric F.

description: This place was amazing. We had two pizzas, a large salad, desserts and a nice bottle of red wine for under $100! We were raving about how good we felt and how good the food was all night. We want to make it our go-to date spot. We just wish it was bigger so more people could fit in the restaurant!
author: Courtney M.

description:
Pretty cool atmosphere, super small. 
Wait staff was super cool. 

Burrata was okay, wouldn't recommend.

Meatballs were super small- but good

Pizza was the best thing going for them- I would only go back for the pizza
author: F H.

description: Very friendly atmosphere.   Food is very good.  Unique from other pizza places and has a good organic variety including beverages.   Good for everyone including vegans, organics followers, and children.  Highly recommended.
author: Jeff A.

description: Delicious pizza and the burrata is to die for! I wasn't expecting all the employees to be deaf, so that was surprising, but great all the same. Our waitress was awesome and the customer service was excellent.
author: Patricia C.

description: Apparently there are some staff that are deaf but they are amazingly more attentive than 99% of hearing waiters at other restaurants.  This place has a service that connects, and it rocks with an oven imported from Naples, Italy.  They are also Napoletana certified and only one other place has this distinction in San Francisco.  Get the pizza margarita.  And go there or be square!
author: Juan J.

description: The food at Mozzeria is consistently great and the staff are friendly. This was my 4th time and I will return.
author: B A.

description:
it was fine, just fine.

We had the buffala mozzarella margherita pizza.  i thought it was great, but my companion didnt think it measured up.  The cheese was phenomenal.  The crust was delicious.  I also enjoyed the flavor of the sauce.  

Proscuitto charcuterie:  was adequate.  the crostini were a little too crispy, and there were not enough of them.  its always a pet peeve of mine when a restaurant does not acknowledge how many people are going to be eating a dish, and they give you portions that cannot be evenly split.  for instance, there were two of us, and they give us a pile of meat with only three crostini.  the pickled cauliflower was good, and the proscuitto was sliced paper thin.  

the pasta dish:  i dont remember what it was called, but it was really, really underwhelming.  the pasta didnt taste fresh, and as far as i could tell, it only had a really basic tomato sauce.  it just didnt measure up, and i could have made better pasta at home.

I had the pinot gris which was fine....nothing too memorable.  I also tried the pinot noir, which was also good, but not amazing.

the service was a little spotty.

all in all, there was nothing memorable about the food here.  you could get anything here anywhere else, and with the city currently glutted with established pizza joints, you are going to have to put a little more oomph in it, in order to stay on the radar.

now i will say that this is one of the most interesting dining experiences i have had.  the owners are deaf, and a lot of the people that work there are also deaf.  certainly, everyone there knows sign language in any case.  i knew this going into it, but what i did not expect (and i guess i am not sure why) was that 95% of the patrons here were also deaf.  you could hear a pin drop if it werent for the music that was playing!
author: Christian C.

description: The pizza is great! We are very picky about our pizza! The dough/crust is top notch--great flavor, beautiful texture and cooked to perfection. (The oven is amazing). We ordered three different pizzas: the Farm Egg, the classic Margherita and the Hosui Pear (so unique). All were delicious and a wonderful balance! The service was super efficient and professional. It is very cool that they bring together the deaf and hearing community and this is a solid pizza joint!
author: Lisa D.

description:
1st Deaf Restaurant in the Bay Area owned by Deaf owners which makes this place special. Been here a few times and the neopolitan style buffalo cheese pizza has always been my go-to when I'm here. I do wish the pizza itself was a bit thicker and more filling, especially for the price you're paying for.

Customer service is great! You don't have to know any Sign Language to come here since pen/paper communication is an option. It definitely allows people to explore a different culture and the atmosphere is pleasant and accepting of all people. 

**Reservations in advance are recommended via phone or on their website due to limited seating capacity.
author: Sunshine Z.

description: Really disappointed in the pizza here. We ordered the brussels sprout pizza and there was no sauce on it, and the brussels sprouts had no seasoning. The cranberries made the pizza extra sweet. I had one piece and left the rest for waste. And I LOVE all pizza, so this is quite scandalous. The only reason for the two stars is the service.
author: Dahlia M.

description:
Our party shared nearly the entire pizza menu, all of which were very good. My favorites were the curry lamb and the duck pizzas, which were more like over the top flatbreads. 

Fyi, sitting near the oven is pretty warm.
author: Huey N.

description:
I came here for brunch on Easter's Sunday. Pizza and brunch are a great combination. I love their Easter Ham Pizza with egg, thinly sliced potatoes and asparagus. I wish they can add it to the permanent menu. Their Arancini with pomodoro sauce (fried rice balls) are very good too. 

The service is very attentive. My coffee was always filled up. I'll definitely come back to try their margherita soon.
author: Saran R.

description: I cannot believe this restaurant gets as many stars as it does.  The service was slow throughout the whole meal.  I ordered a glass of prosecco that tasted like water.  We ordered the butter lettuce salad to start and it was terrible.  It was completely flavorless.  We ordered two gluten free pizzas.  They baked the crust in the oven and then took it to the back.  I'm not sure why they couldn't make the whole pizza in the oven at the front.  The pizzas were lacking in toppings and my meal basically consisted of crust and cheese.  I was very disappointed.  AND the price we had to pay for all of this...I can't even.
author: Emilia L.

description: A large group of us went to Mozzeria a while back for a friends birthday. Usually going to dinner with such a large group can be overwhelming but the staff at Mozzeria were incredible! My boyfriend are also vegan and even though we were with so many people they were incredibly accommodating. They even organized a couple of appetizers and an off-menu dessert. They really went above and beyond for us. Not to mention that the vegan options they organized for us were incredibly delicious. Overall, the experience was great! I even got practice my ASL a bit! If you're vegan and going out to dinner with non-veg friends I would definitely recommend going to Mozzeria for good food and a great dining experience.
author: Carolina T.

description: Update: came in 2 more times and was slightly less impressed w the quality of the pizzas. It's still very good - no question about it - but not 5 star good. For better pizzas go to Gialina's in Glen Park or A16 in the Marina.
author: Ruben K.

description: Wow. Small plates are awesome. Various house-pickled, spiced vegetables are like a party in my mouth. And they're playing "It's getting hot in here(...so take off all your clothes)." burrata with beets, hazelnuts, cress & arugula amazing. Crispy pork with Lima beans & different pickled veggies. Back in Black beer remarkably complex lager. Interesting aspect of the restaurant is that most or all of the staff are Deaf or hard-of-hearing. This is a bonus for anyone who knows ASL.
author: Cage H.

description: Great service and delicious food! Even the iced tea is amazing. It's tough to find a pizza with perfect crust and topping racios but they get it right everytime at Mozzeria. You truly can not go wrong here.
author: Anne L.

description:
I've been in restaurants in the US before where the native language was something other than English, but this was the first one in my experience where that language was ASL.  (Yes, they have spoken English too.)  As a result it was QUIET enough in here for our party to enjoy our mealtime conversation.

The food is boutique Neapolitan-style pizza and small plates.  Four in our large party ordered the pancetta pizza, in my case for the caramelized onions.  (There's also a pizza with arugula.  Arugula, on a pizza?  No thanks.)  Light, tasty, enough toppings, with a dark puffy crust edge just as I like it.

Praise for the reportedly exquisite carrot soup from the other end of the table.
author: David B.

description:
Been here many, many times. The whole staff is Deaf which is unique but should be more common.
Anyways, cool thing about this restaurant is that they have a real stone oven in the middle of the restaurant (do dress with as little clothing as possible as it gets warm). I really enjoy the wine, pizza and desserts. 
If you are a user of American Sign Language, try this place out! Or if you want to learn and have some great pizza while doing so, GO! It's a crazy amazing experience.
Be sure to bring some $ as it is not cheap.
author: Gen E.

description:
First off, this is quite possibly the quietest restaurant in the Mission.  That alone makes it worth visiting.  There was some soft music on -- not sure who it was for -- but that's it.

Second off, they have the same kind of pizza oven that Una Pizza Neopolotana does, and a pizzaiolo who is almost as talented.  So forget the whole deaf restaurant thing: go to Mozzeria just for the pizza.  It's good, it's "top ten pizzarias in SF" good.  The crust is chewy and tangy, clearly the result of a natural rise, and they offer dipping stuff for you to dip your pizza in after you've eaten the toppings portion.

Also, order the homemade burrata, you'll be sorry if you don't.

They also have a very nice, but short, "strong beer" list.

Now, the reasons for 4 stars instead of 5 are a few, and I'm writing them out here just because I hope the owner reads this.  These are not major detractions to the restaurant, just stuff that keeps it from being "amazing" rather than "really good":

1. lose the toasted almonds on the pizza.  They taste completely wrong and don't go with anything.  If you're dining there, ask them to hold the almonds (you'll need to write it out)

2. somehow redesign the menu to make it easier to point to things.  I'll freely admit that I have no idea how to do this, but with deaf servers, it's a requirement.

3. Offer more homemade mozzarella dishes.  The Mozzarella Bar in Rome offers a plate with 5 kinds of mozzarella (regular, burrata, smoked, straccino, and pepper); could you do that?  I'd totally come in and sit at the bar and get wine just to order that.

4. Do more simple, low-topping, traditional Italian pizzas, like a pizza bianca with just dabs of fior di latte and herbs.  It would be fantastic!

I repeat: the creative criticism above are just "enhancement requests"; this is a good restaurant with great pizza, and you should brave the deaf thing and try it.

And if you actually speak Amslan, you're in for a great time.
author: Josh B.

description:
I'm sure you know that this place is run by deaf peeps, and it was kinda like being in a foreign country when you don't know the language (unless you do know ASL).  I actually googled some ASL so I could say 'thank you' etc since I felt like a typical American by not knowing the language.  Funnily enough I had just seen a book about speaking with your hands in Italian.

Anyhow, I had the margherita pizza here as well as a pint of beer as part of a BBE promotion.  Loved the space, it's cozy and chill and of course the staff aren't talking so the only sounds are more the chatter of other diners and the ambient soundtrack.  The pizza was pretty good and since it's in my hood I def wanna go back and try more!
author: Gene X.

description:
I love that this restaurant serves the deaf community. Service was good, but it could have been better (e.g. took a long time to clear dishes, not asked for more to drink). I know maybe 5 words in ASL, but it came in useful (asking for milk for my kiddo and saying thank you and all done).  

I wasn't impressed by the pizza though. It was decent, but nothing to write home about.  The crust lacked a good texture and was pretty bland.  Toppings were fine though.  I had the pancetta and red onion pizza.  

The ambiance was odd.  There was no music on when we first got there, and it was almost silent since everyone was signing (save for us).  The lights kept getting dimmer then brighter throughout our meal.  Occasionally there would be a song playing, but when it ended it would be another 10 minutes before another song would play.  Having a large TV on the wall was distracting and seemed to clash with the atmosphere they were trying to create.  

I understand that they are new and still figuring things out, but I'm not sure I'll visit again (and I live less than a block away) unless there are more improvements.
author: Denise I.

description:
The pizzas are outstanding! The dough is so tasty and fluffy (almost like a pankacke!). The meatballs and the burretta are very good starters (small portions).
The staff is extremely friendly and the prices are reasonable. Highly recommended!
author: Mimi S.

description:
Tonight I attended the "Grand Opening" of Mozzeria. This little gem is located on 16th street near the 16th and Mission BART. Being deaf myself, I like to support deaf-owned businesses and this is the first deaf-owned restaurant in SF! 

I went with two other friends who also were anxious to try this new restaurant.

We started with the Mozzeria bar which is a large bar of Mozzarella topped with a tangy marinara sauce and a deep fried basil leaf. This was a very good teaser for what was to come. 

I ordered a salad (there is only one on the menu) and it was very good with a sweet vinaigrette and walnuts as well. 

Since there were three of us, we ordered 3 different pizzas then shared. What a great way to taste a few varieties! 

My friend John had the Smoked Salmon pizza with dill and Sonoma Fromage Blanc. It was good..but the dough was the best part, in my opinion. 

My other friend Janet had the caramelized onion, thyme and blue cheese pizza. Was very good. 

I had the Pancetta, caramelized onion and mozzarella pizza which was my favorite of the three. Janet and I disagreed as she thought hers was best. To each their own :)

I enjoyed the New Belgium Snow Day Ale and SF's Anchor Steam with my dinner while Janet and John enjoyed a Chianti. 

I rounded it out with a cannoli with candied orange peel and ricotta cream. Boy was I stuffed..just like the cannoli! :) It was good and not too sweet. 

Janet had the Torta dela Nona with Lemon sorbetto..light and not too sweet. 

The service could be improved (our waitress had trouble opening the wine and forgot our refill orders) but this is understandable on opening night. 

The staff overall was very friendly and they were all making an effort to make sure we had fun.  We did! You could tell Russ (and a few others behind the counter) were also having fun! 

I'll definitely be back! Go Mozzeria! Congrats to Russ and Melody on following their dream!
author: Ken A.

description:
Ok ok ok. LISTEN. 

This place is the shit. You should eat here. It is a nearly perfect restaurant. Priced well, excellent food. Short menu, and everything is fresh and attentively prepared. 

I live in Sacramento, but have eaten here 6 TIMES since discovering it earlier this year.
author: Wade C.

description:
If you have never eaten at Mozzeria, you NEED to!  I went there yesterday for the first time and will definitely make it a point to go back in the future.  I learned about Mozzeria in my ASL class, so I headed over to experience it and write about it for my semester project.  It was well worth the time and gas to get there and back from Sacramento.   

The food is absolutely spectacular.  We ordered 3 pizzas to share, and each one was amazing.  My favorite was the cauliflower, my boyfriend's was the Peking duck, and my mom's was the Italian sausage.  Then again, our favorites seemed to change and be determined by what piece was being consumed at that moment.  Doesn't matter what you order, it is going to rock your tastebuds.  

The owners are very sweet, funny and personable.  I had a blast chatting with Russ about the restaurant, why I'm studying ASL, family, etc.    

It was an all around lovely experience.  I cannot wait to stop in again next time I am in San Francisco!
author: Cassie B.

description: The Peking duck pizza is quite good.
author: Matt L.

description:
Came here with my friend and ordered the Tuesday feast, which gets you two appetizers, a pizza, a pasta and a dessert for $49. Great deal! However, I would have been much happier just ordering two pizzas. The pizza here is fantastic. The rest was pretty forgettable, unfortunately. 

Would absolutely recommend coming here for the pizza and the wine! Service is great as well.
author: Amanda D.

description:
I just love Mozzeria!  I've been here several times and keep referring friends as that's how much I enjoy it.   The food is excellent and well prepared, made and cooked.  The 90 second pizza's out of the Brick Wood Fire oven is to die for.  The menu changes often so there is always something exciting calling my name.  

The service is always top notch.  Now, it helps that I know Sign Language.  But would think the same if I didn't.  I love seeing people's eyes light up when they get the "deaf" discovery expressions also on their faces.  

I'll keep returning happily!

Janet
author: Janet M.

description: This is for their mozarella item at the SF Street Food Festival.  The cheese was good, and I liked the crostini and the little tomatoes, but it was too expensive for what was there. It was like 3 pieces of tomato, and well it deserved more. I guess I'll need to try their pizzas one day.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
We didn't feel like standing around for the long wait at Pizzeria Delfina, and Mozzeria was close and well reviewed.

I had no idea it was a deaf establishment. I felt stupid and awkward because I wasn't sure what was going on at first. There is no mention of it or "what you are supposed to do" in the menu or the website. I would have liked to know what I was getting into and how best to conduct myself. 

The pizza is way, way, way overpriced. $17 for a paper thin crust, a light brushing of sauce, 3 basil leaves and 5 mozzarella Ciliegine. It wasn't even that great tasting.

Sangria was needed to help make up for it, but was overly sweet and a big kick of alcohol. 

Not a ton of vegetarian options...

Dessert sounded great but left a lot to be desired. There were nuts in the coffee cake which wasn't mentioned in the menu. Ice cream came out mostly as a sauce. Tasted pretty good, but was heavy and overly sweet.

So there was this annoying hammering noise coming from somewhere in the restaurant that was louder than the music and giving me a headache, but how do you ask a deaf staff about it?

The taste and quality just aren't there for me at that price and feeling awkward about how to order and interact with the staff makes me not tempted to go back. I was irritated paying the check and happy to leave.
author: Zack F.

description: Wow...the Bucatini was amazing... next time not sharing!!!  Great pizza washed down with Drakes IPA ON AN amazing warm SF night!
author: Sean M.

description: The pizza was alright. We had a gilt city coupon and based on the reviews thought this place was gonna be along the lines of pizzeria delfina but it definitely wasn't. Wouldn't come back.
author: Yasi N.

description:
I wanted to like this place because it seems deaf people go through a lot of hardships and I wanted to support this deaf-run establishment... but my experience here was SO awful. All their employees are deaf and that would be great if they actually KNEW how to cook or wait tables! They should hire people based on their ability to do the job right not on their non-ability to hear! 

The service was terrible. Our waiter was unprofessional and showed NO respect to me and my friend. Later I heard that most deaf people are rude and nasty to people who don't know sign language. OMG really?? So everyone who dines there is supposed to know sign language? It's like going to a Chinese restaurant and being treated poorly because you can't speak Chinese. What BS is this?

Our pizzas were awful. We've never had worse pizzas before in our lives! Even a Red Baron frozen pizza would be much better than what we ordered from this place. The dough was UNDERCOOKED like to the point that  you can't cut it into pieces. The cheese was soggy and greasy and the veggie toppings weren't cooked at all! WHO PUTS RAW VEGGIES ON A PIZZA?! Obviously they do at Mozzeria. Maybe they sabotaged our food because we couldn't talk to them in sign language? To add insult to injury they STILL charged us for both of our pizzas even after we took only a few bites and sent them back. Really??? They couldn't even offer us an apology, just said "here" and threw a check on our table. Um thanks...

It seems as if this restaurant relies solely on a "deaf" gimmick, and it won't ever gain a reputation based on its food or service...
author: Monica R.

description:
Went to mozzeria on Saturday night at around 8:20 pm. There were a few tables available but unfortunately we got seated at the table nearest to the door -1 star as there were other tables available and we kept getting a cold draft of air every time someone else came in.

The communication between our server was a breeze, we got the mozzarella and meatballs as appetizers, and we got the marguerita pizza. Food was superb, atmosphere was great, bathroom was really clean, and we loved the authenticity. Will be coming back next time we are in the city!
author: Arian S.

description:
Stopped in for dinner to use a Gilt voucher. Overall we had a really pleasant experience and I was grateful for the opportunity to dine in a deaf owned and operated restaurant, the food just didn't wow me.  

We did have slightly limited menu options given we were using a voucher. We ordered the kale salad and burrata appetizers to start - these were both tasty and I loved the puffy wonton chips (?) that came with the burrata - nice change up from the typical bread you would get.  

Pizza-wise we went with the margherita and spinach.  Not bad, just kind of meh. I thought they were both on the bland side and lacking that crispy-thin-piping-hot crust one craves!  Donut holes for dessert which were tasty.
author: Brianna M.

description:
My wife is a recurring character in my reviews. Rarely does she urge me to write a positive comment, or anything at all, about a restaurant. In this case, she suggested to me I praise the establishment. So that is about the best compliment I can share: my wife was satisfied.

This place is written up from time to time, because it is owned and operate by a deaf couple. That means there are minor adjustments to be made: all of the staff used American Sign Language when we visited, and they had notepads and pencils on tables. (We know a bit of ASL, but not enough to do more than muddle through.) 

That is nice and a bonus. It's not enough to sustain a business in a competitive environment.This is a hip, happening neighborhood.

But even if this were a joint run by hearing people, it would warrant commendation to friends. The eggplant parmesan was the best we had ever had. The salad, with beets and candied almonds, was very good. The pizza, one GF and another on regular dough, were made in an authentic Neopolitan oven. That's the other claim to fame here: the wood fire gives the thin crust its perfect texture, though it also warms up the diners (good or bad depending on the season).

It's not the fastest place and parking is not easy. 

I urge you to check it out. We will return.
author: Frank W.

description:
Small narrow restaurant with hard workers. Definitely helps to know how to sign, but they're polite to everyone. The only deaf run establishment that I know of, and I don't agree with the other reviews that they're looking for a hand out. The family style option for parties bigger that six or eight provided tons of food at $25 a head and was less of a headache for large parties. Appetizers included a delicious fresh mozzarella with a tasty sun dried tomato spread and fresh basil leaves. Another was a deep fried, encrusted cheese with a marinara sauce. The arancini was delicious and is a must-have at this place. The sausage pizza with caramelized onions, wild mushrooms was quite tasty. Pesto pasta was not as flavorful as the meatballs with the straw pasta. Dessert consisted of beignet-like doughnuts with scoops of chocolate mousse to dip it in.
Sangria was decent and plenty of beers on tsp- who doesn't want squid ink?
The wait staff was excellent and they provide easy typed menus to point at, understand universal hand gestures (like drink), and are great at lip-reading. They even play background music for us auditory dependent beings. Best part is that you can be as loud and raunchy as you want, and won't necessarily bug your waitstaff. 
I recommend trying to get a table away from the insanely hot brink oven which is exposed toward the back of the restaurant, unless you naturally run cold or it's absolutely freezing outside.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Excellent neo pizza and the environment ambience. Servers were very attentive and served us very effectively! Strong recommended anyone to dine out at Mozzeria 

Gelineau-Gember Family
author: Corey G.

description: A group of 8 of us went for dinner. Our waitress alerted us to the family style meals they offer. I was so surprised to find out this wasn't a pick a couple of choices. The entire menu including 4 small plates and five different pizzas AND dessert. Everything was superb. One of our guests said it was one of the best meals he'd have ever. Another told her husband several times, "We have to come back here!". I'm sure we will!!!
author: Lucienne B.

description:
First, I want to talk about what an incredible experience it was to eat at Mozzeria. Most of the crew working is hearing-impaired, and they're absolute rockstars. Our server came up and introduced himself, and my date and I never had a communication problem--our service was stellar. It was very cool to be in such a quiet restaurant, and to block out other senses to focus on taste.

First of all, the veal pork meatballs were absolutely ridiculous. I wish I could have a constant IV flow of those into my body at all times. The gnocchi was probably one of the most interesting things I've ever eaten. It had some sort of sweet, dark sauce at the bottom of the plate, but on the other side of the plate was a soft ricotta cheese that totally cut the acidic flavors of that dark, sweet sauce. 

The Italian sausage pizza was some of the best pizza I've had in the city. Everything was perfect, from the red onions to the fennel. I can't wait to come back for this. For desert, we had another VERY intense, yet super complex dish--the brownie. It was sprinkled with walnuts, fried bananas and had a very tangy--but spicy--fruit glaze. I wasn't anticipating the spice and was totally surprised.

Go for the food, the experience and the service. You absolutely will not regret it.
author: Tyler H.

description:
Still good, but it has fallen off a bit in excellence, while the prices went up a bit.  I was a huge fan initially, but the last couple times I've been, it hasn't had the same quality all the way through.  One dish or another seems to be a little off, or the portions are smaller.  
I live a block away and was coming in maybe once a month, but I'm not feeling it's as reliable.
author: Christian W.

description: This review is for the food trolley.  We had the awesome trolley cater a party recently.  The servers were super nice, quick, and attentive.  The pizzas were really delicious and made to order.  I would highly recommend them for any event!
author: Nicole D H.

description: This place is the real deal. The dough is outta control good. They use the real wood burning oven and everything. If you're looking for real neapolitan pizza joint, look no further.
author: Josh H.

description: This review pertains to delivery via grub hub. They apparently don't allow public reviews on their site. Would not recommend ordering delivery as all the food was room temperature and the salad came without any dressing. After microwaving the pizza and fried mozzarella it was mediocre and definitely not worth the $50 to have it delivered. If I ever eat there again it will be in person.
author: Luke R.

description: Their food truck is amazing - discovered it at the Fremont Festival of the Arts and now I cannot wait to go to the restaurant. The crust was light, crisp and perfect and the cheese (I had the Quattro Formaggi) was out of this world. Check it out!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Yes, Ok, you have every right to be a little thrown off or awkward feeling until you realize everyone that works here is deaf, but then you need to be wowed and go with the flow. I thought it was pretty damn cool.

I was curious what reviews might look like on here after visiting the restaurant today (because of the deaf service aspect). Not surprised by some people reviewing harshly for it and being kind of dicks in their reviews, and also (especially?) not surprised those reviews come from people who live outside of the bay area/california.

Anyway, to the actual review!:

I loved Mozzeria. I heard about it, knew it was owned and operated by deaf people - which is awesome. The service was great, the server we had checked in with us often, made sure we were happy, and the hearing issue wasn't a problem. It was lunch time, so it was a bit quiet in there, but they had pretty cool music playing quietly. I found that the atmosphere made me more quiet and appreciative of the environment and the food. Reflective and peaceful, with light banter with my boyfriend sprinkled in.

We split the signature pizza, Peking Duck, and it was phenomenal! The crust was amazing (almost naan-like to a degree) and the ingredients were so simple, but with amazing flavor. 

The atmosphere is good, and the wood burning oven is beautiful. It's so cool to watch the fires be tended to RIGHT THERE before your eyes.
 
We will definitely be back to try all the other pizza flavors!

All you have to do is realize you need to point, or mime, for what you want, and you're golden. Be a little open minded, people, this is a fantastic thing here. :)
author: Jane H.

description: A couple of friends and I came here with a Giltcity deal. The food was very good (pizza margherita, four cheese pizza), and the deal made it even better as we got a bottle of wine, and appetizers and dessert. Service was excellent too. I would definitely come here again. The place is small and intimate.
author: Dani P.

description: I found this place kind of dirty for being as expensive as it was. The cork fee is ridiculous and the pizza didn't taste good. I did like their beet salad, that was definitely worth having, probably the only thing I should've had.
author: Nikki S.

description: We came as part of a project where we had to sign in ASL. Lucky because not only was the service great, the pizza and papparadelle was SO good! We will be back.
author: Dave R.

description: Great food. Great atmosphere. Absolutely get the dipping sauce for your crust. The little piece of paper and pen is for you to write your order on.  The only turn off is that the place is pretty small and the pizza oven is right in the middle, so it was a little hot. But I will be going back for sure.
author: Sara W.

description:
Pizza was fine - nothing special. Pasta COULD have been great but it was served luke warm. For the price it was NOT worth it.

Also, learn points of service guys...you asked us if we wanted dessert while we were still eating and then promptly brought the check. That is so wrong.
author: holly B.

description:
A bit too brightly lit, the long, narrow space of Mozzeria is modern and sparsely decorated, seemingly constructed around the immense Italian pizza oven.

The owners and many servers are deaf, however their enthusiasm and desire to do a good job more than overcome their hearing limitation. Deftly taking orders on his iPad, the waiter accurately recorded my selections despite the overly loud classic rock (Stones, Clash, and Beatles) emanating from the sound system (didn't seem to bother him; oh, he was deaf ...).

The limited menu features two salads, two small plates, a selection of charcuterie, two pastas, and four desserts.  The stars are supposed to be (emphasis on "supposed to be") the five pizzas--from marguerita to wood roasted Italian eggplant with red onion, yellow and green peppers, and pesto.

The minuscule pieces of salmon seemed an after-thought in the otherwise unspectacular wild arugula salad with sherry-shallot vinaigrette and (deep fried) bread crumbs ($9).  Its crust cooked beyond pleasantly blistered (read that "burned") in places, the pancetta, fresh mozzarella, and caramelized onion pizza ($14) was a little soggy in the center, indicating that the pizzaiolo does not yet have full knowledge of the oven.  The lemon ricotta gnocchi with sage butter and orange zest was good, but certainly nothing to write home to your nonna about.

Four beers on tap and a small, selection of wines are available.  Again, nothing that will set the world on its ear (hearing enabled or not).

Tony's and Gialina need fear not: the newcomer, Mozzeria, is certainly not a contender for the SF pizzeria Napoletana crown.
author: CJ G.

description: This place is AMAZING!!! I was introduced to this Deaf owned/worker eatery through school because of my teacher. This food is just mouth watering and down right perfect. We always try something new off this menu and ask the staff what they recommend.  I love the fact that everything is communicated through ASL. The staff are all amazing and super patient. I speak sign language but my fiance is still learning they staff are great with helping him practice and are just super inviting! I have actually meet both the owners and WOW! These people are AMAZING!! The watch the quality in the food and make sure everything taste perfect. This place is a staple in our diet now! This place is a must try!!!
author: Savannah K.

description:
Mozzeria us one of my favorite restaurants in the city. It's perfect for a casual dinner with friends or a date night. 

The interior of the restaurant is comfortable and welcoming. They have a cozy feel to the place but it doesn't feel cramped or like you're sitting on top of other patrons. You can see the pizzas being fired behind the bar, adding more personality. 

When it comes to the food, I can't say enough good things. These chefs absolutely know shat they're doing. I have been here several times and have never failed to be impressed by how excellent the food is. Pizza, pasta, salads, appetizers, it doesn't matter what you order because everything is amazing. 

Service is great as well, all of the staff is friendly and knowledgeable. Attentive without being annoying. 

Whenever anyone asks if I have restaurant recommendations, Mozzeria is always my first and most emphatic suggestion!
author: Kyle M.

description: We loved Mozzeria -- we ordered the Margarita pizza and Peking Duck pizzas which were both fabulous.  We also shared the meatballs and burrata to start -- both excellent.  We brought a great bottle of wine -- the corkage was extremely reasonable at $15.00.  We loved the service and atmosphere.  We will definitely be back.
author: Lance K.

description:
This is must-try SF restaurant as far as I'm concerned. Not only is the pizza super good, but the staff and atmosphere give you a dining experience you won't get anywhere else.

As other Yelpers have established, the restaurant is owned and operated by hearing-impaired staff. Seriously, no big deal. I organized a birthday dinner party for myself with ten friends last summer; I coordinated via email (which I prefer to the phone anyway), and everything was set. Ordering at the restaurant was super easy too: if you don't know sign language, just point to what you want, or jot it down on a note pad. I can't stand when people ask 900 questions about a simple pizza anyway, so this actually made ordering a breeze. (The only difficulty encountered was when my boyfriend tried to secretly get them to put a candle in a cake for me, but even that worked out.)

The food is solid too. I like to keep it simple with pizza so I liked the margherita the best, but even the funky ones are good. And the sangria is super strong and spot-on. I think Mozzeria is an eye-opening experience for many people like myself who don't encounter folks with hearing impairment regularly. I think Mozzeria is awesome, it tastes great, and it makes you think twice about something so simple as the ability to hear.
author: Emilia S.

description: Yummy pizza my favorite  Brooklyn bomber very good. Enjoy communicate ASL and meet deaf people! Top experience eat yummy pizza and associate chit chat with friendly workers! The boss very nice. Meet me and my friends chat really enjoy.
author: Kira I.

description:
Very serviceable Italian food and a great deal if you go in on Tuesday or Wednesday nights when they have their 3-course meal specials.

Pros:
Value
Blocks from Dolores Park
The owners and staff are very nice
You will have a dining experience unlike you have had before
I learned a few signs - ASL

Cons:
The food is good but not great
Limited menu options
author: Frank J.

description: Simply awesome pizza.  Note that the restaurant is owned by deaf proprietors and the staff does not interact with you though sound. We had the  di Bufala and the vegan spinach. They were both authentic Neapolitan and fantastic.
author: Joe H.

description:
This place has the best pizza in San Francisco; it's baked in a beautiful, tiled oven right out in the front. If they've got it on the menu, order the duck hoisin pizza. It's phenomenal. Their margherita pizza is the best in this city because the sauce is light and not too sweet, the cheese is melted but not liquid, and the crust is just perfect. It's crunchy in places, but still doughy and chewy the way you want a pizza to be. We haven't had a bad pizza here, yet.

Their salads and non-pizza items are similarly excellent. I particularly love the beet salad, which comes with golden and purple beets, goat cheese, candied walnuts and a really great spring mix. 

For Valentine's Day, we got the prix fixe, which was $85 for two people. We ate so much food. It came with two first courses, two second courses, a heart-shaped margherita pizza, two desserts, and two glasses of Prosecco! 

If you don't sign, do NOT be turned off. Yes, the servers, owners, cooks, and other employees all sign and use ASL with each other. But there's a pad of paper and pen on every table, and one of the servers speaks English as well. What I love about this place is that they're patient with me while I try my pidgin signing; they're so great while I mangle their language. I always feel welcome here, and it's great to see a place where Deaf and HoH folks can feel at home. I love seeing that there's no negotiation of communication when a signer walks in; s/he just walks up to the bar and starts signing with the bartender or pizza-cook. It's a great place to go and be reminded how much a little patience and good will can help someone who doesn't speak the main language (a nice reminder for me to be similarly patient and friendly when I meet people whose English isn't perfect).

All in all, I love this place and we go here about three times a month. The pizza is excellent, the salads and entrées are delicious, the service is top notch, and the ambiance is really exciting. It'll be your new favorite pizza joint!
author: Athame E.

description: Loved eating there. Food felt home made and not fancy restaurant like (had burrata, salad and mushroom pizza)  and service was great. Loved the energy and communication in ASL.
author: Me M.

description:
This pizza joint is legit! 
My ASL professor recommended this place to me.
I actually had to go here to write a report on attending a Deaf event since it's ran by the Deaf community but not a lot of deaf people were there, well besides the people working.
I wanted to make friends but instead, I got great food and service.
Fine by me!
The server was really nice from beginning to end.
My classmates and I really enjoyed the appetizers and pizza.
We got Italian sausage pizza and Peking duck pizza.
I got the beet salad and my friend got the house made burrata and they were both fantastic.
I loved how they make the pizza in front of you and put in the giant dome looking oven and ta-daaa comes back out.
Never tried this style pizza but I ate the crust! 
I normally don't eat pizza crusts.
I'll be back the next time I'm in the area.
I'm not sure if they still have the sangria but I didn't see it in the menu, and I wanted to try it.
I got too lazy to finger spell to ask hehe or (shy)
author: Christina P.

description:
This was stop #2 of 6 on our "Crawl" through the Mission, and while totally different from #1, it was equally enjoyable.  This is a pizzeria, plain and simple. They have an impressive wood burning oven right in the middle of the dining room, and you can sit at the counter and watch the pizzaiolo make the pizza.

We split their duck pizza, which was absolutely fantastic!  In fact, it was good enough, I plan to try it at home. The simplicity is genius.  It is a hand tossed thin Italian style pizza crust, topped with a bit of hoisin sauce, then liberally doused with shredded duck breast, and then finished with some rosettes of green onion.  Imagine a Peking duck on a pizza, and you've got the taste pretty well nailed.

The staff was lovely.  When we walked in, we were a bit surprised at how quiet is was in the restaurant, especially after leaving our prior bar, but after a few minutes, we realized that all the staff were deaf and were communicating with ASL or written notes.  Not that it made any difference in how pleasant or efficient they were!  I did find it interesting, though, that those of us who were speaking all seemed to feel that we needed to speak in hushed tones in the restaurant.  Not sure why.
author: Frank W.

description:
Wonderful food, attentive and friendly staff, and a great ambiance.

I'd rate this as one of my best dining experiences ever.
author: Michael B.

description: This place is a must try in San Francisco!  Not your typical pizza place.  One of a kind experience.   Fabulous food!  A+ service!
author: Stefanie O.

description:
Pasta was a bit on the greasy side, while the pizza has a deliciously thin crust and great mozzarella. I would pass on the fava leaf salad. 

FYI all of the waiters are deaf
author: Amin S.
