description: My sister and I took ASL in high schiil for 3 years so it was fun to come to this place. Great atmosphere - the host and waitresses were so nice! Meatballs were delicious!!
author: Nina S.

description: The Margherita was vastly disappointing:  sauce with no character; and, stingy with the cheese and with the basil. I've had better at Round Table.
author: Thomas B.

description: Pizzas, apps, and mission make this a great pizza joint.  Definitely worth checking out!  Stands up to the stiff pizza competition in this neighborhood.
author: Aaron W.

description: We tried Mozzeria after my daughter's ASL teacher told the students about the restaurant.  Parking was a nightmare, but once we got through that disaster and showed up 30 minutes late for our reservation, everything changed!  The staff was great, and our daughters enjoyed using their ASL skills to communicate.  The food was very good.  We tried the spinach salad that had a nice, fresh lemon juice dressing, and 3 different pizzas--the 4 cheese, the duck, and the pear pizza.  My favorite was the duck.  A great experience, and we will be back for sure.  But we'll take BART in from now on!
author: Jodi M.

description:
Food was great, service was great and overall experience was wonderful!
Drove from So Cal to eat here, worth the trip!!
author: Tee W.

description: Was in San Francisco last week and got a chance to try this pizza.  lets just say I was absolutely not disappointed.  One of the best pizzas I've had EVER!
author: Rafael H.

description:
This is a unique restaurant in that the owners and staff are Deaf.  With that said, I love that I can apply my limited ASL and not be criticized for it.  I also like how the restaurant environment is comfortable for the hearing people. 
Now I've been here only 2xs (and wish I was here more often); the first time I ordered the duck pizza with hoisin sauce, recommended by people who were here prior to my attendance.  Having had experience enjoying hoisin sauce, I was a bit hesitant to such sauce being on pizza.  To my surprise, the pizza was rather good.  The uniqueness of Chinese ingredients in pizza made my meal that more enjoyable.  It's been a while since my last visit so I will need to patron them in the near future
author: Jessica S.

description:
Pretty good pizza. Chewy tasty perfectly cooked crust. 

Started with house made burrata and a chicory salad with bleu cheese and blood oranges.  The salad was fine, a little weird to have it dressed in a sort of vinaigrette with a blob of bleu cheese dressing on the corner of the plate along with many nice chunks of cheese, pomegranate seeds and bits of blood orange. The burrata as okay, served with won ton type chips. Big serving.

Star of the show was the mushroom truffle oil pizza. Smelled amazing, tasted even better. I went on a little too much about the crust.

No dessert, in and out in less than an hour which was perfect.

Had no idea some of the staff is deaf/hard of hearing until I noticed the pads of paper on all the tables and the hostess wrote us a note asking about our reservation. Not a big deal unless you are unable to read the menu.

Would def. visit again.
author: Poppy C.

description: This place definitely has some of the best pizza around.  I particularly love how the dough holds up the toppings in a way that many of these quick fire pizzas place tend not to (I'm looking at you Zero Zero). My only ding would be the disappointment that was the Mozzeria Bar. The cheese should have definitely been far more melty and gooey.  That said, I would certainly come back for the pizza.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I wanted to like this place, but I was pretty underwhelmed. My friend and I were rather hungry so we split a duck pizza, bucatini pasta, and bombolini dessert.

Duck pizza ($18): The duck on the pizza was very tasty, and there was a lot of it. However, the pizza crust was rather chewy, dry, and a bit too blackened for my taste. I think if it were thinner and crisper, I would have enjoyed it a lot more.

Bucatini pasta ($16): Very interesting pasta. The meatballs were tender, the pasta was very al dente. The al dente pasta was an interesting texture that I've never quite experienced with pasta before. It wasn't bad, just different. The portion size was on the small side though, especially for $16.

Bombolini ($7): Lots of small, lemon cream filled donuts accompanied by cinnamon, whipped cream, and chocolate anglaise. The donuts were too gummy for me; I prefer my donuts to be lighter, I guess.

Service was nice. It was also interesting talking to the servers via hand motions and head nods (the restaurant hires from the deaf community)! 

All in all, not a terrible meal, but I wouldn't really want to come again.
author: Wendy S.

description:
I love this place! My favorite is still the margherita pizza. I usually order a margherita in different pizza establishments for comparison and rate each place by that.  I love the pizza dough here it's crispy and just the right amount of chewiness.  
Also love their Wednesday $20 special which includes appetizer, pizza, and dessert!
author: Ro B.

description: After having lived in Italy for almost 7 years, I thought it'd be impossible to find a good pizza in SF. I was wrong. Mozzeria is where to go for excellent food & exceptional service! We had the ginormous mozzarella sticks, pizzas & desserts. All super yummy & fresh. Will definitely be going back!
author: Ann S.

description: Veal pork meatballs were delicious and so was the Margherita Pizza. We also had the Spinach Pizza which is Vegan but I ordered it with fresh mozzarella and it was absolutely fantastic.
author: Michael S.

description:
Super good pizzas and even better ambiance. Prices are reasonable for the food and experience; everything is fresh and made to order. 

Stumbled into this place and didn't realize what a treat I was in for. 

The bombolini are tasty too.
author: Brooke G.

description:
Guys, this place is DOPE. 

My mouth was loving every bit of  the deliciousness Mozzeria had to offer. Every dish is so evidently prepared with the utmost care.

The gnocchi was just YUM. The meat was so tender. I wish there were more potatoes in there, but other than that it was heaven on earth.

We also order the margarita pizza and mushroom pizza (substituted goat cheese with mozzarella). Both were awesome. We also ordered the dukkah dipping option for our crusts, which included a combination of different sweet and salty herbs and spices. Very interesting flavor and very good. Must try! 

It was also a really cool experience to eat a restaurant where the waiters only speak with ASL. Neither boyfriend nor I know ASL but we communicated with the staff just fine!
author: Chloe G.

description:
The food was delicious.  We had quite a number of dishes.  

We started off with the Buratta which was probably the best I've had in the bay.  
Next, we had the Spinach pizza.  No cheese, no sauce, strange...but tasty and light!!!
We then had some sort of pasta (don't remember what it was called) but had lamb in it, there were generous portions of lamb, and we were pleased.
Lastly, we had this brownie, chocolate, ice cream, caramel type dessert and it was heavenly.

The service was very good and very pleasant.  I was caught off guard that everyone who worked there was signing, because I didn't know going into it, but I was so very happy to support the community.  

Definitely would recommend and I can't wait to go back again.
author: Ghizal A.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to come here after reading the stellar reviews on Yelp, and we were not disappointed! It was definitely a different experience, but such a very good one! 

Our waitress was so sweet and attentive, and the food... just amazing. We ordered the gnocchi and a margherita pizza to share, and we also got the spiced apple cider. I was sad when we finished our food :P

We will absolutely be back!
author: Wendy T.

description: When I lived in the Bay Area I went there twice.. AMAZING food and AMAZING service! I tell all of my friends who visit SF and the Bay Area to go here.  The owner and his wife are very nice, also the owner's mother works there I believe as well.  I love that it is very family oriented and a staple for the deaf community in the Bay Area!
author: David K.

description: Nice location, warm atomsphere, open view of the kitchen, and the prices are fair. I liked the burrata appetizer, it was very delicious! Unfortunately I can not say the same for the pizzas. They were okay. As I proceeded to take my slice, the whole toppings fell right off... repeatedly. Otherwise, it was a nice experience!
author: brianne c.

description: Yum. Delicious thin crust pizzas. The salads looked interesting (more like cheese with lettuce rather than the other way around). Will have to be more adventurous and try one out next time. Staff is great! Will definitely be going back.
author: Heather R.

description:
Don't order a salad from the appetizer expecting a good sized portion. 

However, the pizza is to die for. The bread is perfect and the variety of options is awesome. 

Try the lamb curry pizza if you're looking to try something unique that you won't taste anywhere else. 

Also, learn how to say please and thank you in sign language :)
author: Catherine B.

description:
Wow wow wow! I cannot say enough good things about this place. The Napoletana Pizza here is amazing and verified!!! SO authentic and the dough is unreal... I love how you can see the workers make the pizza right in front of you so you know it's truly fresh. The Burrata cheese was also one of the best I've had. The house made pastas are also very unique and delicious.
The service was great and efficient. We had no difficulty communicating with the workers.
author: Sejin J.

description: Visited on a Saturday night at 6:30. Had a reservation for two but also could have gotten a table without a reservation. My friend and I ordered the Radicchio and Margherita pizzas to share. Both were delicious and the Radicchio is unlike anything I've had before. I also splurged on the Mozzeria Bar as a throwback to my childhood where I ordered the cheese stick appetizers at every restaurant. The Mozzeria Bar was a delicious version of my childhood appetizer of choice. I will definitely return to Mozzeria.
author: Angela C.

description:
Staff is really great, and it was such a cool experience communicating with them.

Food is excellent, though a little pricey.

Edit 1.5 years later:
I've had Mozzeria catered to work a few times and my office LOVES it. Their pizzas are wonderful.
author: Marcella D.

description:
I recommend the Italian Sausage pizza. 

This is an interesting spot to check out. They baked the pizza in a large oven by the bar! Super cool seeing the process and our freshly made pizza come to life. Also, everyone on staff is hard of hearing so remember that when you come in and order. I forgot and started chatting away. Just point your order on the menu. The servers are super nice and even joked around with us when we were served. 

Charming vibes, I'd go back if I was in the area and craving a fresh pizza.
author: Pam M.

description:
Their pizza is pretty good! The crust is the best part.

 Also, I love the feeling when waitress use ASL for once.

Workers are friendly. 

It is worth if you are visit San Francisco. :)
author: Samantha L.

description: SCAM!  Used my Guilt City voucher and brought a friend.  Understand that they don't want 3 people eating from one certificate, they forced our guest to order a starter as well as her main.  What???  If she was dining at a another table they wouldn't make her do this.  Why now?  Oh yes to rip her off.  While the food is good their business practice is a scam and they should be ashamed of themselves. I was embarrassed for bringing her there.
author: Kim K.

description:
I would give it 6 stars if I could! 

I didn't expect the pizza to be that good. I had a margarita as I always have and it was better than anything I had in the east bay so far, and better than most places I tried in the city (including Regaza on Dvis, Barreta on Valencia.. Delfina is still my favorite, but it was a pretty close battle:).

So the pizza definitely worth 5 stars on its own, but the additional star would go for the feeling you get when eating at Mozzeria. This place have the smthest, most pleasant operation I have witnessed in a while. The people that work there love each other and you can feel it on every delicious bite you take. It's been a while since I enjoyed a place atmosphere and flavor that much.

If your trying to impress your date, or just want a really good pizza, try them out. You won't get disappointed:)
author: Foodie F.

description:
The food was so tasty. We loved the salads and the bombolini (fried donuts) the best, but the pizza was well executed too. Went with a large group, larger than what we reserved for and the staff accommodated us with the utmost professionalism and grace. I highly recommend going for the family style menu ($25 per person) if you have a large group, makes decisions and splitting the bill much easier. The mushroom pizza was the tastiest on the menu. 

I like the black and white modern aesthetic of the space. My only complaint is having the brick oven so prominent among the dining space. It got pretty hot in there. But that is just a minor setback because the staff was so great and friendly, they made the meal even more enjoyable!
author: Farah S.

description:
No words.

Accurately describes the pizza oven. A 5,000-pound beast you can read more about here http://www.mozzeria.com/about and here http://goo.gl/rnvuU.

Did you catch the other no words part in the second link? Owners and much of the staff are deaf.

My review is biased as I find this to be an incredible story of perseverance, courage and passion. Five stars even if the food wasn't.

Fortunately there was no letdown.

Started with roasted eggplant with ricotta alongside homemade burrata and tomato. Former was bite-sized and brilliant. Latter was indulgent and refreshing.

Homemade mozzarella and caramelized onion pizza continued the trend. Rich and powerful. Should have stopped at a slice. Had two.

Pumpkin ravioli finale was the standout. Balance of the two textures was sublime. Fit each other like a glove. Left me wanting more and completely satisfied. Perfect.

Space is dominated by the pizza oven. Whimsical touches of red throughout. Service rotates among a cadre of attentive, willing and earnest servers.

Found myself looking up proper sign language to properly convey a deep feeling of thanks and appreciation for the meal.

Hope they got the message. Especially since I was at a loss for words.
author: Jason B.

description:
Mozzeria is:
   - Incredibly inventive and delicious appetizers
   - Yummy wine
   - The best pizza in San Francisco (for sure)

I think everyone should go here every day.  It's good.  REAL good.  Just go eat it.
author: Kevin F.

description: Pizzas are off-the-charts good, they have a great selection of wine, the staff is perfectly attentive.  Next time I'm definitely leaving room for dessert :)
author: Ram C.

description:
I called ahead to pick up pizzas for take out -- pizzas were ready in exactly 15 mins from when I called, hot out of the oven, grabbed it in 2 minutes while double parked. 

Their dough is PERFECT to me -- I like Neapolitan pizzas on the more cooked side vs. wet in the middle.

My favorite pizzas:
-Peking duck (w/cucumbers, scallions, hoisin sauce) -- ridiculously good
-Radicchio w/honey, gorgonzola, mozzarella 
(Margherita is solid too, but not remarkably different from other pizzerias') 

I didn't eat at the restaurant but it was cozy, cute and quiet -- good for couples who want to grab a bite and a glass of wine.
author: Chao W.

description: Great pizza great service but expensive for what you get ($7 for anchorsteam).  Dough was a bit thick compared to the amount of sauce/ingredients so "meat to bread ratio" was not ideal. Their $20 meat pizza was fantastic taste wise.
author: reza n.

description: We had the sausage pizza and cucumber salad and what is a petty typical meal turned out to be a really great dining experience. Probably the best pizza I've ever had. Service was heartfelt and authentic. The owner even chatted with us and told us some funny stories. Next time you go in ask Russ what he wore to the Selina Gomez concert! Ha!
author: Jason S.

description:
How to say "thank you in sign language": Take the right open hand. palm facing in, and touch the lips with the fingertips and then bring the hand down with palm facing up as though indicating "you" without pointing the finger.

Why is this important? Because Mozzeria employs a number of individuals who are hearing impaired or deaf and of course you want to be able to say "thank you" when they bring you your delicious food!

I really loved this place. My friend and I had a Blackboard Eats deal that allowed us to try a five course meal (two appetizers, one pizza, one pasta dish and dessert) and everything was delicious. I'm still thinking about the pasta and homemade burrata weeks later. Heck, I'm even thinking about the eggplant dish I had and I normally don't like eggplant! The wine list was also nice with nothing being overly expensive. 

Great experience and I recommend that everyone go there at least once.  Just be sure to practice your "thank you" in sign language before walking in the door.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Seldom do diners have the chance to dine or even find servitude at a hearing impaired establishment. From the host, to bartender and the owners, Mozzeria is run and operated by some really sharp deaf men and woman. It truly is delightful to dine here just for that reason alone!

The design of the restaurant is intimate without being crowded, modern without the stuffiness and the food is superb. I've been to Mozz a few times and can safely say that I have never been disappointed with any single item on the menu. Each dish is better than the next. I'll say 3 of note: 

First, the pizza's from their wood burning fireplace are light, thin, paired with fresh and incredible toppings. They are as good Delphin's and better than Farina's. 
Second, the burrata cheese is mandatory to order when I sit down at Mozz. Everyone enjoys the mild and delicate simplicity of this incredible cheese. 
Last, the meatball appetizer for some odd reason is something I think about and crave on a regular basis!

Obviously, the chef and the staff know what they're doing. Here, you can get an entirely unique five-star Italian super meal for two dollar signs. Much success to the team at Mozzeria!
author: Jessica f.

description: The best pizza I have ever had! I went with some friends and we all know asl so it was nice to communicate fully in asl here! Love the staff too!! Absolutely wonderful!
author: Addie E.

description:
Had a great dinner here tonight, we had the Italian Pizza and the Gnocchi, both were excellent but the Gnocchi really stood out.  I suggest sharing the dishes, the pasta was pretty rich but balanced nicely with the pizza so I didn't leave feeling too full.  We both had the house wine which was good and reasonably priced.  Over half the diners were speaking ASL, as did our server, which made for a nice mix in the restaurant and the volume level was perfect for conversation.  

Only downside was the decor, but the food is what really deserves your attention anyways.
author: Nicole A.

description:
One of my two favorite thin crust Naples-style pizza places on the east side. 
Bronx Bomber + Margherita Pizza - the BEST!!
author: Luna R.

description: Fantastic, adorable, delicious. Stylish and cozy decor, generous service, excellent food. Had the Arugula Salad (thinly-sliced fennel! and strawberries! and currants! yum!), House-Made Burrata (I am a whore for burrata, what can I say), and Hosui Pear Neapolitan-style pizza (with pancetta, Brie, roasted garlic, fresh spinach, and balsamic). All were _delicious_. Go try them! What are you waiting for?!
author: Alison N.

description: Great food, great service, such a cute ambience. Definitely recommend but make a reservation!!
author: Haley P.

description: My boyfriend and i came here last night as a Chanukah gift to me, as i am a big ASL freak and i am studying to be an interpreter and have always wanted to come here but never got the opportunity or anyone willing to go with me. He took me, which meant a lot and the food, and service was amazing! I had this pizza that had peas, lettuce, 2 types of cheese and honey truffle oil. It sounded different but really good that i had to try it! I loved it! It was so good! The beer special was really good and so was the wine cocktail/sparkler they had. I would recommend to anyone! If u dont sign, thats okay, they havw paper and pen to write back and forth. I sign but my bf doesnt, so i did all the ordering and communicating with the staff. Our appetizer was really good too! I will definitely be back!
author: Ruthe Ann G.

description:
We came so that our son could practice his ASL. That's not the reason for this review. I'm writing this review because the restaurant is fabulous, and the food was fantastic, and the people are great.

Our server was Megan, and she was a joy. We ordered a margherita pizza for the boys (loved it) and the daily special pizza for the two of us (loved it), plus some kind of Japanese eggplant small plate as an appetizer - yummy. Note -- the pizzas are thin crust style. Extremely. And my two teens, who can eat a large thick crust suburban pizza no problemo, loved it.

This place makes a person with hearing think different. Together with the great people and the great food, please escape from the "real world" and come to a better one -- Mozzeria.
author: CW E.

description:
"90 seconds per pizza pie in a 1K degree oven" is really all it takes when you're making a super thin crust pizza with buffala and tomato. The people at Mozzeria have perfected this process making their pizzas absolutely marvelous. And yes, the eggplant crostini as well, and the ravioli, and well, almost everything else in the menu. 
I definitely enjoy coming to this place. Had a chance to stop by their booth at the SF Food Fest this year. They never fails....food is decliously and people are always warm and full of smiles.
author: Claude C.

description:
Definitely would go back!! Loved the food and the wine was delicious :-) enjoyed the unique experience of working with a deaf waiter and even picked up ways to say a few words in sign language!

We got the dinner meal for $39. Absolutely the best option for 2 people who didn't know what to get because got to try 3 appetizers plus a pizza and a yummy dessert.
author: Sara G.

description:
Such a gem!!  Love this place.
They provide job opportunities for the deaf community - how cool is that?
The staff is super friendly and the food is spectacular.
HIGHLY recommend it and I can't wait to go back again!
author: Mindy H.

description:
What a pleasant surprise Mozzeria turned out to be. I have been meaning to write this review for a while. I was unaware that there were so few wood fired pizza restaurants in the city.  But this one takes the cake. When the owner writes down the addresses of the other places that sell wood fired pies and tell you to go and try them and let her know your feedback you have one confident owner.

The story of this place is almost as good as the pies. They pizzas come out of the 5,000-pound Stefano Ferrara oven perfectly. The owner had brought this oven over from Italy so you know she means business about making your meal enjoyable.

We tried a the Roasted Japanese Eggplant salad and the Margarita pizza and it was so good we ordered a Margarita pie to go...

The wine parings are wonderful. I love the fact that I can brush up on my sign language as well since all the employees need to be able to sign with the cooks and  some of the other customers who are deaf. 

I love this city and all the different types of places like Mozzeria.
author: Christian A.

description: What a great experience we had last Friday night.  Could only get a late reservation but showed up a little early and we were seated in 5 minutes.  The staff was friendly and very prompt.  The 3 meatball side was to die for, in fact, so good we ordered another one.  The beet salad (x4) was delicious and went well with the goat cheese.  The in-house made burrata was also very creamy with a hint of sweetness, didn't like the wontons though - would change that up.  Pizza was cooked in 90 seconds and to perfection.  Just the right amount of ingredients to tantalize your tastebuds.  Got the meat pizza and it did not fail!  Would definitely go back.
author: CLB B.

description:
I had low expectations because we dined at Delfina pizzeria a few days ago & I was ready to die happy, smiling. It was raining, making Mozzeria was quiet on a Wednesday evening. We were ushered in by a woman that was pointing & smiling. OK this was confusing but whatever, it took me a minute to realize she was deaf. Then I noticed our waitstaff was deaf too. I start looking around and then I saw the chef signing in ASL. This made me smile. One more reason why SF is a magical city and how Mozzeria is a special place.

The food was amazing. We started with the house made burrata with roasted red peppers & basil oil for $10, it was really big in portion better for a group of 3-4 people. Burrata mean 'buttered' in Italian and the creamy texture of this cheese lived up to its name. 

The soup of the day was vegetarian minestrone with roasted tomatoes & kale, it was smoke & had a rich, layered broth. My dining partner swears this is the best minestrone he has ever had.

We split the Japanese pumpkin ravioli with walnut gremolata, it needed a splash of salt but then it was mouth magic. The dish was topped with a few salad greens which contrasted nicely with the sweet, soft fresh pasta. Topped with a sprinkle of crispy, dried onions & the bed of pesto in which it laid upon all gave an extra burst of color & flavor. 

The margherita pizza for $15 was good, it was on par with Delfina in terms of the quality- the crust was a bit softer but had a more wood-fired taste which I liked, the mozzarella di buffala cheese was good but the sauce was not quite Delfina worthy. 

The hazelnut panna cotta with a homemade biscotti, topped with aged balsamic vinegar & a small strawberry. The dessert was a perfect ending, there is a trick to this dessert- on their own each item is good but not exciting but then you take a small bite of each at the same time, it really makes you realize the genius of flavors set before you.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Great pizza, Great service. 

Try the meatball on the specials, its awesome as well.

Prices are better than a lot of other places close by, especially for beer and wine.
author: Dan B.

description:
Loved this place. We ordered 5 different pizzas for our table of 6 and the Margherita pizza was by far my favorite. It is delicious! The dessert options could be stepped up a bit. None really jumped out at me.

The service is great and I love that they have a hearing-impaired staff. It somehow makes the experience more special. We had no problem communicating what we wanted, sending back the sangria that wasn't to our liking or asking for anything else we needed.

I'll definitely be back!
author: Tina T.

description:
After all the friends on FB egging on me to stop by this fabulous restaurant when I'm in San Francisco (I had planned on going there regardless)   Dined with friends and the food was out of the world!  Hubby and I agreed it was excellent and we came back again three days later with other couple.   I got the opportunity to try different pizza (Italian Sausage)  Simply divine.

Yes, it's owned by Deaf people but it's not relevant here.  The food is what I'm focusing on.  EXCELLENT!   

Definitely coming back when I'm in town.
author: Michael K.

description:
The pizza is really great here. Their thin crust is cooked in a wood burning oven placed in the center of the restaurant. The ingredients are locally sourced, and you can tell, the quality is there. Our table tried the Margherita, Roasted Asparagus, and Pear & Brie. Compared to the delicious richness of the first two, I'd skip the Pear & Brie next time. Overall the crust wasn't annoyingly crispy, it has a nice chewy thickness with a good balance of salty and sweet. I'd definitely stop by more often if I liven nearby.

Atmosphere is small, and a little crowded - but you could frame it as intimate. The restaurant is deaf owned and supports jobs for the deaf community. It's really nice to see that.
author: Suzanne P.

description: Mozzeria was great! I thought it was cool that everyone who worked there was deaf or hard-of-hearing, it allowed me to be able to practice my signing. I got there and they asked if I had a reservation, which I didn't but that wasn't a problem we had a 10 minute wait and then got to sit. Gladly they sat next us at the window, because it was piping hot in there. The restaurant is really small and they have a big oven so it gets hot easily. I got the Magherita pizza only because they apparently don't have pepperoni... but the pizza in all was really good. I'd be happy to come back another time.
author: Kayla M.

description: Four of us split the Hosui Pear, Italian Sausage, Mission Figs and Farm Egg pizzas. All were amazing. I didn't want the Farm Egg, but I was outvoted. SO GLAD! That was the best one. Sorry, no pictures. We ate everything too quickly. Great space and wait staff. And if you haven't heard, it's Deaf friendly. Would strongly suggest this place. We head back to Minnesota tomorrow from our vacation here. This was a highlight of our week long trip. Both desserts were a great way to end too.
author: Adam F.

description:
Last week I was reading the Wall Street Journal and they had an article on Mozzeria and the owner. Decided to check it out on a Friday because they had the Roast Duck Pizza. 

Came here and was seating within minutes. When the pizza came I was a bit disappointed because what good is a pizza without cheese...but wait. This pizza was GREAT. It didn't need any cheese at all. It reminded me of Peking duck you would normally get at Chinese restaurants. The pizza was layered with hoisin sauce instead of the tomato sauce for traditional pizzas, then topped with roast duck and green onions. The crust was a little chewy for me as I prefer thin pizzas. But the pizza was still great regardless.

I will definitely come back when I'm in the area.
author: Sean W.

description: This place was quite a memorable experience. The service was amazing and the food was so good. The language barrier might be an issue for some people, but it was not something that really made the dinner experience a problem. I'm glad I found out about this place. It's a true gem in San Francisco.
author: Brian F.

description:
All the pizzas were creative, with ingredients I've never seen on pizzas before. Got the farm egg pizza and pear pizza - delicious! Actually the pear was a bit on the salty side with the pancetta, but still really good. 

I've never really had to wait that long for seats here (been twice), and service is good. Takes a bit longer perhaps than normal, but worth the wait!

Would go back again!
author: Victoria K.

description:
Mozzeria has wonderful pizzas - the kind you get in Italy. Crispy, chewy crust and the best toppings. It's open for lunch now, with a smaller menu but all the good pizzas and salads you need. The owners are always there and are exceptional. 

Mozzeria is just a lovely, local restaurant with delicious pizza and a warm environment.
author: Suzie C.

description: OMG : GLUTEN FREE CRUST option now available for an extra $3! And it is SO GOOD... Just had the mission fig pizza w gluten free crust. Light but super tasty - so hard to find GOOD tasting GF food (much less pizza) at restaurants! Service was very friendly - no complaints - will definitely be back again! (This was actually my 3rd time here but first time since gluten free has been available.)
author: Kim M.

description:
I have been to Mozzeria probably 5 times. I have to say that the last time I came, it was the most positive experience. I came with a group (I think there were 5 of us) and we were offered a special group menu where we could each pay $25 and we had a taste of a good portion of the menu. The dessert was probably my favorite but you can't beat the amazing pizza that is cooked in their class wood stove which sits in the middle of the restaurant. 
I am an ASL user and I just love coming here. Even if you don't know any ASL, I promise you won't regret the cultural experience. 
I recommend making reservations ahead of time. 

p.s.
I wanted to add one person to our party last minute and I called to ask if I could do this. While no one answered, I received a call back through an interpreting relay service and the staff member said it was ok to add that person. I was really impressed that they even called me back. So amazing and such a lovely local spot to support.
author: G E.

description:
Everything about this place is terrific. Been a couple times now and all of the dishes are great, it's an amazing deal, and the staff is incredibly nice and friendly. 

While I don't know ASL, they make everyone feel warm and welcomed. 

Can't wait to keep coming back. A new, reasonably priced, delicious, Italian resto is in town!!

Yum.
author: Art A.

description:
Came here after church on a rainy Sunday evening. We had made a reservation beforehand (not sure if this is required). Overall the experience was wonderful. My bf and I shared a salad and lamb curry pizza, both of which were excellent. It is a little pricey and the portions are not big, so if you have a larger group expect to order maybe 2 or 3 pizzas. 

The atmosphere is quieter than other restaurants since there isn't blasting music that makes it impossible for you to hear your friend sitting right across from you. I enjoyed watching the owner and other employees sign to each other. Being hard of hearing, I definitely appreciate this gem of a restaurant.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
Love the food at Mozzeria.

Nice selection of all things Italian, with a nice wine list to match.

Pizza could not have been more crispy, tasty and delicious. 

Thank you to our server Roxy for making sure our first visit will not be our last. Next time we're bringing our good friends.
author: Dirk W.

description:
I love this place!

The pizzas are made to perfection. Hubby loves the burratta app and I'll second that. The salads are delightful and soo fresh.. 

I try to come once a month or more - it's that good!
author: Monica S.

description: We had a great dinner experience at Mozzeria.  We had a large group, but our numbers kept changing,the servers were super accomadating of our last minute deletions and additions.  I really appreciated that.  I had the mushroom pizza and it was very good. I shared the bambolino dessert as well and I would also recommend it.  We had an early show to see on 16th street and the restaurant was open at 5pm on a Saturday which allowed us to make our event.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Whatsnext M.

description:
Look at the oven and the wood being burned in it.  This is as close as you will get to Vera Pizza in the US, I suspect.  Friendly people and attentive.

Similar to 'una pizza napoletana' in quality, but does not have the strict , spartan service and menu I perceived there.
author: Eric L.

description:
Mozzeria and I have to have a tough talk.
For months I've been excited about this place, primarily because it was advertised as "the rival to Una Pizza Napoletana, with the same oven."  Big shoes to fill straight off the bat!

I made reservations, and we showed up a few minutes early. Thankfully, there was a table available, and we were immediately seated. I began to notice a lot of the staff and even customers were fluent in ASL, which was a pleasant (albeit unexpected) surprise.

Ugh, now for the service and food:

S E R V I C E
We were seated, given menus, and waited 30 minutes for someone to take our drink order. Because we didn't know when someone would be back to take our food order, we gave the server our food order all at the same time.

It's RIDICULOUS to wait that long for drinks, especially for a restaurant who has a) such a positive fan base so far, and b) major competition to deal with. And not one apology for having to wait this long, I was appalled.

F O O D
Meh. Bland. Dry.

Margherita Pizza - on the oily side, the crust was crispy and charred. The dough was nothing special...again, comparing this to Una Pizza.

Prosciutto Pizza - topped with arugula. We were warned: it comes with no sauce. I immediately was curious about whether this would make it dry or not. I knew the server would respond with a "not dry at all" response, so I withheld my inquiry. I was right, dry as none other.

Sadly, I will not be back. Mostly because of the service rather than the food.
author: Alyssa G.

description: This restaurant is really good. Even when I knew little sign language I was still able to communicate what I wanted to order. There was a very little wait time when I came on a Wednesday night around 7:30.
author: Courtney G.

description:
Great dining experience. Service was so efficient and the Pinot noir by the glass was perfectly aired and delicious. The charcuterie plate was yummy and we ordered three pies. My rundown

Pancetta: good but the onions were a bit too sweet but good
Lamb curry: good but again just slightly too much sweetness but very good- tho kids didn't seem to like it as much
Margherita: this was good but unfortunately not as flavorful as delfina and nowhere near the extraordinary crust of pepes or Sally's in new haven,

But it was such a lovely place with good food made with great ingredients.
author: Madison W.

description:
A la mode Napotelana which means....successfully luring hungry customers with a sexy, sleek brick oven imported from Italy, now erected next to the restaurant bar like a holy shrine - Mozzeria is, without a doubt, a super peachy addition to the Valencia Corridor hotspot! After years of shameless experiments (which has occured all over in the world during the past decade) with freaky fusion fiascos, Mozzeria hasn't only redefined fusion, but it also has redefined the Pizza itself...which is a tricky trick because savory pies can be easily bastardized, becoming sacrilegious to the very existence of pizza.

This place is nicely compact, elegantly casual and SUPER delicious!  The crust, the cheese, everything is perfect about the pizza here, along with side dishes and pasta specials. Almos wafer-thin, crispy, smoky, chewy crust, excellent sweet and tangy sauce, and excellent cheese. Dare you enhance it with mozzarella di buffala (buffalo milk). It does tend to be a slightly messier pizza, but the flavor will impress the most criticizing Sicilian grandmamma-mia. It is definitely a 'knife and fork pizza' until cooled off. 

Sometimes, you do have a rare (if not frequent) dilemma between Italian and Chinese.....like deciding between eating mu-shu duck at a Chinese eatery AND a darn decadent pizza, just step into Mozzeria for their super yummy roasted duck pizza with hoisin sauce and garnished with spring onions. Well-executed :)

I've yet got to sample their recently unveiled brunch menu. Can't wait!  Mozzeria seems to be savvy enough...by being in the loop on what kind of tap beers that the city locals really like. 

Yes so it happens....to humbly be the first ever Deaf-owned/operated dining establishment in the whole history of SF ever-thriving restaurant industry. The service and the food, by far, do deserve the infrared crimson spotlight! Along with other equally amazing local pizzerias as such as Beretta, Delfina, Ragazza, and Gialina...Mozzeria has already earned its own place in the top league on this hilly peninsula. Oh, why do the name of pizzerias usually end with an "a"? Yeah, I could definitely taste a lot of vowels on the pizza.

Last, but not least, this charming pizzeria has apparently manifested itself into an awesome haven where sign language users and the greater hearing public would be able to interact comfortably.....in harmony and sharing the universal love for the food :)
author: Jesada P.

description:
I just got home from a fabulous meal at Mozzeria. We were greeted at the front desk and enjoyed communicating with the staff.  

We ordered a few appetizers and split 1 pizza. We had the Fried Mozzarella, Chicken Parm and a shrimp dish with a spicy sauce and rice that was recommended by our server.  Our pizza was the prosciutto, greens and Mozzarella.  

We enjoyed being close to the oven and watching the chefs, the great food and warm and welcoming staff.
author: Sandi L.

description:
Pizza is amazing.
Thin crust.
Gastronomic delights.
Quiet atmosphere, naturally.

I'll be back, often.
author: Heidy S.

description: Went to Mozzeria for a quick dinner yesterday. My mom and I weren't that hungry so we just split a margherita pizza. The pizza was delicious albeit a bit salty. I liked the dough's texture and the chew was great. Good sauce. I wish there had been more cheese and fresh basil. But overall, a solid dish. Friendly service and a great cause. I was shocked to see the place was empty -- I'll be coming more often to support the joint and have delicious pizza. I wanted to try their pasta but didn't see any on the menu. Next time I'd like to try their duck pizza!
author: Michelle K.

description:
Two things you should know before you walk into Mozzeria for the first time:

1. The food is amazingly delicious
2. Everyone is deaf. 

It takes a second to adjust because the atmosphere is very quiet. The occasional dish clatter will seem disruptive, but don't let that throw you off. Conversations are encouraged albeit quietly. Because of that, I wouldn't recommend bringing children. It would be a great place for a date. 

However, the food is to die for. Quality ingredients, well-crafted entrees, and great service. You order by writing (paper and pen provided) or simply pointing at the menu. I had the margherita pizza, which is simple and perfect. 

Beyond the food, the owners are incredibly kind people. I'm all for supporting local business, but they make it easy by being such thoughtful individuals who happen to serve fantastic food.
author: Stephanie T.

description: I went here for a birthday celebration with a group of 10 and absolutely loved the experience, the ambiance, the food and the friendliness of the waiters! We got the Family Dinner Set A Menu and there was so much food...all of it was super delicious! I would highly recommend this place for all the things you get a great restaurant plus the experience of dining in a place that is entirely run by very talented deaf staff. You will never feel you had any less of an experience than dining at a place run by non-deaf staff.
author: Aprajita J.

description: I love this place! The staff are wonderful - so nice and patient. And the pizza is great. I will definitely be back. And am inspired to learn sign language!!
author: Julia B.

description:
I ate here with my girlfriend on a BlackBoard Eats deal, after eating a small dish from them at the La Cocina street food event. What a great deal! We truly had a feast, as described by the restaurant.

As good as Mozzeria's pizza was, and the margherita was very good with so much fresh cheese, basil, and sauce, the most memorable item for me was the burrata dish. It's made in-house, and I found myself scraping the small plate with a fork once the crostini was finished. Everything about the dish was so fresh and flavorful.
author: Mike H.

description: Food was over priced.  Pizza was burnt.  Would not recommend.  Had to serve ourself.  Burnt myself when I picked up my pizza at the counter. Not busy at all. Not worth the time or effort .
author: Mark S.

description: The pizza and salads here is just amazing! We were looking for a restaurant after hearing a concert at Mission Delores. We did not know that the wait staff and chefs were hearing impaired. Great experience watching them sign to each other. Wonderfully friendly customer service--everyone seemed to enjoy their jobs. And..the place is quiet--that was a bonus! We will be back for sure.
author: Margery N.

description:
We went here on a Friday night for a party of four. We didn't make reservations but hoped that we'd be able to get a table if we showed up opening time. It all worked out and we were seated at the first table near the entrance. 

The pizzeria is modern looking yet classic too. The hardwood floors are apparently from way back when. The owners were excited to uncover the beautiful old wood when they tore up the top floor. The hardwood was part of the original building it seems and is very old and not something that can be found easily so I thought it was really cool that they tried to keep true to the aesthetic of their building's history while incorporating modern elements like bright white walls and retro red chairs and cool lamp fixtures. 

The big ass Napoletana-style brick oven stands near one end of the bar and is a humongous shining luminous thing. Very cool. I know Una Pizzeria has the same oven so I was excited to see that Mozzeria carried this brick oven as well. You can see the fire-burning wood and the heat in the oven as the staff is popping in their pizzas. 

Overall, ambiance is cool, now on to the FOOD and DRINKS! I loved the house red. I forget the exact name but you just tell the waitress that you want the house red and you're set for the night. It's affordable but very lovely red wine that goes down smoothly. Juicy (not dry) red wine goes best with pizza. We ordered margharita pizza, onion and pancetta pizza, and duck pizza. We four LOVED the duck pizza hands down. That's the best! It's only available on Friday nights so we were relieved we came at the right time. I love hoisin sauce and on a pizza, ooooh la la! 

The margharita pizza was delicious and puffy and crispy and dripping olive oil and herbs in the middle, just the way it is done in Naples. For those of you who complain about a soggy inner crust, that's actually how it's done in Naples and it is divine. If you prefer the American sort of pizza, find the nearest Dominoes. I will say that the onion and pancetta pizza was nice but not a wowser like the margharita and the duck. I felt something was missing in the onion and pancetta. My friend who loves onions was obsessed with the onion and pancetta pizza so I guess to each his/her own. 

We ordered the Mozzeria bar and that came with an unexpected but exciting heat! It's an appetizer of a large Mozzarella bar panko crusted and fried with a light tomato arrabiata-style sauce to dredge the bar in. It's delicious if you can handle the heat. It's not recommended for those who want the typical mozarrella cheese sticks with tomato sauce because this appetizer really packs a kick. Consider it a grown-up version of the mozzarella cheese. 

Then desserts! We ordered the chocolate cake with vanilla bean sauce. I think we overdid it at this point. I was way too stuffed so it's hard for me to tell just how good the cake was. Sure did look very pretty though with the vanilla bean glaze drizzling down the cake! But if I were to come here again, I'd just get the margharita or the duck pizza and a glass of house red and I'm set for the night. 

This restaurant is one of the more unique restaurants in the sense that it is owned by a Deaf couple (capitalized 'D' is a big deal to convey the culture and pride of their community) and it employs or brings in the works of Deaf carpenters, Deaf waiters (including hearing waiters who can sign), Deaf everything. You see hands flying in the air moving in all sorts of intricate shapes and motions. Their expressions and body language is fun and entertaining. It's just a very neat environment to be in and I recommend you learn some ABCs or a few signs to try communicate with the staff here. It's just a really unique experience for folks who aren't familiar with sign language and it's cool to see it in action. Definitely a locally-owned family business and with a lot of heart.
author: Pamela L.

description:
Mozzeria might have the greatest pizza known to human kind but I will never know.  Their total lack of availability via phone and ridiculous online reservation system for groups over 5 is so unbelievably unhelpful and cumbersome that I just don't want to try to give these people my business.

We used their website reservation system for groups, which is separate from their normal online system.  You need to submit a form to request a reservation for 6 people, so we submitted one at 10:00 am hoping for a reservation that evening at 6:00.  I realize that it was unlikely as it was a Saturday night, but we just wanted to check since this place is right across the street from where were attending a concert that evening. 

I don't begrudge a place that has no availability on a weekend...fine.  Just tell me that you're full up and we'll try again another night.  But when we hadn't heard anything by 2:00, I just thought I'd call there to check so that if their answer was the expected "Sorry, no room for you!" we might still have a chance at arranging some other nearby place.   I called the number on the website 3 times and kept getting what I thought was a wrong number...a random person answering who said nothing more than "That line is ringing for you." or "We're waiting for a connection."  No identification of the restaurant, no introduction as an answering service.  When I finally realized that I had reached the right place, I asked about our reservation request and the response from the service was "They aren't answering right now...would you like to leave a message?"  I did.  And someone called back about 30 minutes later....3 times.  The first two times, the phone rang once and disconnected.  The second time I called them right back and they were unavailable again.  When they finally rang through, a supremely bored and unhelpful guy said "You left a message?"...much to my consternation since, presumably, he had received the e-request and should have had all of that information. But I described yet again what we wanted, and he just said "Oh.  Huh. Hang on and I'll check." And then left me on hold for several minutes.  At which point he came back and said "How many people, again?"

Whatever, dude...sorry to interrupt your busy schedule of slacking, but there are too many other restaurants in the mission that would be more than happy to answer their own phone and give us a simple yes or no answer.  

Done.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Like what David N. already said... I wanted to really like it, but in the end the food was only "meh".

Mozzeria is the first restaurant owned and fully operated by a deaf couple. I had no idea until we first walked in and were greeted by sheer silence and lots of ASL, or in our case, nodding and pointing. About half the staff we're deaf, but about all the staff were fluent in ASL. They've really tailored the restaurant to the hearing impaired and have thus built a great community-like feel with lots of ASL patrons. Mozzeria is therefore probably home to the quietest restaurant you'll ever find anywhere, and its a really cool place to just sit back and appreciate life and the sheer skill+hard-work that goes into making a restaurant work. Kudo Mozzeria.

But to the food... 
We wanted to order the roast duck, but they were out... so we opted for the porcini salame/sherry jelly charcuterie. We also ordered the prosciutto/wild arugula/fresh mozzarella pizza, but somehow our waitress interpreted our pointing to the pancetta/fresh mozzarella/caramelized onion pizza instead. The owner nicely gave us the prosciutto pizza on the house, and had the chefs whip up our pancetta pizza... so I suppose orders lost through translation still have their perks?

The salame/sherry charcuterie was an utter disappointment... the sherry jelly left an awful taste in our mouths. And the pizzas - both pizzas were okay, nothing special - all the ingredients/toppings tasted fresh, but we're unmemorable. The worst part was the pizza crust - it was extremely soggy in the middle, not holding up the toppings well; bits were burnt and inedible; and overall it was very bland and kinda doughy/chewy. I appreciate what they we're going for, with the wood-burning oven and classic Italian pizzas, but their execution was just not good.

And though the service was kind, they could use a few changes to how they run their establishment to better cater to both ASL and non-ASL patrons. Either provide menus with larger text (for pointing) or actually assign non-deaf/English-speaking waitstaff to the non-ASL patrons... I'm happy that the deaf-community now have a place to go and enjoy their dinners out, but yes... work is still needed to be done here.
author: Lana N.

description: Excellent pizza. Great service. So glad to have a reservation because they did get busy. Also it is a deaf-owned business so communicating might seem hard but it was so easy. Such great energy and good staff. We will be back!
author: J H.

description:
I went here a few weeks ago with a good friend.

I ordered the margherita pizza and loved it. The crust is DELICIOUS and, somehow, fun to eat.

I don't sign at all but had no trouble ordering.

Waitress was adorable and attentive. Food was solid. I've already gone back, and plan to go back again.
author: Danny A.

description:
I've heard about Mozzeria since its establishment and despite the fact that every single person I've met who has gone to Mozzeria has raved about its food, I was a bit skeptical for one reason only: I'm a really fussy eater. 

I was impressed by the operations and how clean it was. I also met all of the staff, and loved how friendly yet business-like they were; they were all committed to giving top-notch service without sacrificing customer service. 

I had the Mozzeria Bar - THE. BEST. EVER. The sauce is just unbelievable, and is made in-house. I hope they start canning/selling the sauce, because I'll be first in line to buy a case. I then had the Margherita pizza, which is basically a cheese pizza. I wasn't sure if it'd taste good--and it was so good, so unbelievably good. It was a welcome change to the pizza I usually have back East. On top of that, it kind of had traces of NYC-style pizza, which is always a plus in my book.

The owners, Russ and Melody, recommended that I get family-style food next time so that I could sample more and have more. I will definitely be back, and I'll be bringing a carload of people with me this time.
author: Trudy S.

description: A different type of pizza all on its own! Amazingly unique ingredients, freshness you can taste and a warm decor.  My husband and I have been here 2x in the last 2 weeks! My favorite so far is the duck pizza and my husbands is the farm egg one. If you haven't been here yet... Please do... It's awesome!
author: Chantelle G.

description: Interesting experience transactioning non-verbally.  And as far as la boca, eating the delish concoctions was most certainly a pleasure.
author: Robert L.

description:
A charming y definitely unique little restaurant. 

The wait staff is friendly y knowledgeable about their menu y the food is tasty! I really enjoyed this appetizer they had called la Mia something that I can't remember but it was like a cheese spread with roasted garlic, pepper jam, y toasted baguette. Delicious!!! Their pizza was also quite good. I must say though the thing I enjoyed the most was the ginger iced tea with lemon! My goodness it was perfection in a glass! 

I also love that this place is right up the street from the 16th mission Bart station which makes it very easy to get to. Give it a go!
author: Maya-Luisa G.

description: My wife and I come here often, we love it! The pizza is amazing, and you don't have to wait for an hour like in Delfina. The appetizers are maybe even better, we love the charcuterie platter and the burrata. A great place to escape the crowds and still get top-notch food.
author: Greg D.

description: We dined here for a 'How About We, Couples' date. This was by far my favorite one so far! Perfect margherita pizza and excellent wine. We also got the gnocchi dish and we couldn't get enough of it! The service was on point too. Mozzeria won me over despite being up against some heavy hitter favorites of mine like Regazza and Delfina. Definitely try them if you haven't,  you won't be disappointed!
author: Erin W.

description:
The appeal for this place is without a doubt the accessibility that the restaurant provides to the huge deaf community in the bay area. Outside of that, it's a good pizzeria with a nice atmosphere. As a CODA (child of deaf adult), I am fluent in ASL and came with a hearing friend. She had no problem ordering on her own and the service was excellent... I had a great time chatting with the owners and servers. They're very pleasant and friendly. :)

Although I am giving 4 stars instead of 5 as the pizza is a little overpriced for what it is ($16 or so for a pizza fit for 1 person). Especially when the Mission boasts a plethora of other tastier and cheaper options. However, if you're looking for a quiet meal (yes, they still play music in the background) with great service, I would recommend this place anytime.
author: Kristina C.

description:
We made reservations for 7:30p, and I'm glad we did - it was totally packed by 8p.  We had 1 app, 2 pizzas, beer, and wine.  The food was not amazing (and unfortunately came out in the wrong order, pizzas first then the app) but the service was great.  And, since this place opened up about a month ago, we're sure they'll get their groove together in no time at all.

We'll definitely be back.  We love supporting this husband/wife team (who are deaf) and we love the fact that everyone who works there knows ASL.  It's inspiring and makes us want to learn the language.
author: Carol S.

description:
Best Italian-style pizza I've had in the United States....and parts of Italy.

Of the hundreds of pizza places I've personally tried, only 3 in Florence and 2 in Rome are in the same league as Mozzeria.

If you're looking specifically for American-style pizza, GTFO. There are plenty of other great places in the Mission. If you don't know what the difference is, try the pizza with buffalo mozzarella. You're welcome.

Why is Italian-style pizza so hard to nail? Mozzeria's oven runs at 1,200 degrees and cooks each pizza in 90 seconds. Nbd.

Mozzeria has other good qualities too, but I'm a repeat customer because of the pizza.
author: Will C.

description:
I've been learning ASL for the past several months and have recently heard quite a bit about Mozzeria.  My friends and I happened to be traveling through SF tonight, so we decided to stop by Mozzeria for dinner while we were up there. 

Oh boy, were we pleased!  First of all, the atmosphere was great.  Very friendly and cozy.  The serving staff were really good, fast, and efficient.  I was laughing at our server at one point, because she managed to refill my water glass before I even had noticed that it was empty!

The food.  OMG, the food.  I ordered an asparagus pizza, just to try something different, and it was certainly interesting.  Not the most amazing pizza int he world, but good, for sure.  My friend, however, got their Margherita pizza, and WOW.  That was like eating pure heaven.  But the best part was the Japanese Pumpkin Ravioli.  That was one of the best things we've ever eaten.  It was so good, in fact, we had to order a second helping!

The only thing we forgot to do was order desert!  Ooops!

Can't wait to go again!
author: Joyce M.

description:
Had res, seated right away. 
Good wine selection and reasonably priced too, but all italian so I was lost. Waitress was pretty young and sounded like she didnt really know about the wines either, but pulled through in the end and got me what I was looking for. 

Pizza was so good. Super thin, but perfectly baked. It was awesome.

Also, apparently loads of hearing impaired go there. Didnt know that at the time, I thought they were just being all italian, waving their arms around and such.

Anywho, ill definitely be back when i get the hankering for thin crust pizza, or wrangle another date!
author: Gerhart H.

description:
Seriously?! Wow I've definitely found my new favorite Pizza spot PLUS BOTTOMLESS MIMOSAS!!!!! 
If you know me you know that I LOVE the bottomless mimosa option and this restaurant was just the ticket. 

Walking down to the Castro thinking that I want something loud and hectic I instantly feel a grab from my friend saying, "oo this looks good!" It took me one glance and I say sure! We were greeted by a lovely lady who could only sign. She was completely adorable! She sat us down in the mildly busy restaurant and my friends and I were hooked. Bottomless Mimosas... AND They are ACTUALLY GOOD! Something you won't find too often with that kind of offer! My friends had Margherita Pizzas and I had a Sausage one. All were cooked with a crisp and delicious in flavor! We walked out with a hefty bill but that was A OK. It was well worth it. 

Definitely 5 stars for sure. The service was great (not into your face like some restaurants) the food was fantastic, and the atmosphere was perfect. I'm definitely coming back with more friends.
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
My son and I, along with a couple friends, went to Mozzeria for a fundraiser benefitting CSD and Deafhood Foundation, a couple days prior to their Grand Opening.  Naturally, being a new restaurant, they needed a bit of time to find their groove.  

Mozzeria is family-owned and run by wonderful Deaf folks, as are many of their staff who use American Sign Language.  However, if you come with an open mind and heart, I can guarantee you communication will NOT be an issue (in fact, it'll actually be fun).

Ordered the house red - smooth and delicious!  A great choice.

The quality of the food is evident at this restaurant - the owners do not cut corners. The olive oil was one of the best I've tasted.   I'd suggest that they provide a small bowl of the olive oil along with the bread when we are seated.  

The signature Mozzeria Bar oozed deliciousness, and the tomato sauce was delicate and flavorful.  

As for the pizzas, we had the Neapolitian and roasted eggplant.  Both were delicate and sparsely topped (I would have liked a bit more but that's just me), and the texture was wonderful.  

The chocolate cake....literally melted in my mouth. My tummy left the restaurant quite pleased.
author: Stefanie E.

description: Don't get delivery. Will cancel your order on you 30 min in... can't review the food as it never arrived.
author: Baracs S.

description:
Tiny, well lit pizzeria with a beautiful brick oven. It is a family owned restaurant which I love. The service was excellent, run by members of the deaf community. Our waiter was friendly, attentive, and communication was not an issue. Come with an open mind and heart-- and an appetite!

The pizzas were good-- we had a large party and tried them all :) The house red wine was delicious. That is a must!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
CA can't do pizza, simple as that.  So we went during opening night, and I'm not going to diss them for the administrative fumbles on a night like that.  However, the food is the food, and that was eh at best.  

For the administrative fumbles: by 9pm they ran out of their signature dish which the place is named after, and the gnocchi.  Sat down about 15 min after the reservation, and took a while to get the menus.   But, it was the opening night, and I wouldn't have cared for any of that if the food blew me away.

The food: the pasta dish and pizza were on par with going to friends house for dinner...you know, it's fine cuz you're at your friends place, but if you paid for it you'd be disappointed.  The pasta was under cooked, and had nothing to it that warranted amazement or made it stand out...kinda tasted like warm pasta salad (read: bland)  Note that all the dishes were very cheap though.

Now the pizza.  No way no way no way.  Seems like every place buys a brick oven and throws dough in it assuming magically a gem will be produced in 10 min.  The pizza was just all doughy and plain, below average...like I said, felt like we could have made it at home.  There is something to be said about east coast pizza that the west can not replicate.  Why eat pie here when you have Little Star around the corner, and (new dive find) Arinell for the most NY tasting pizza I've had so far in this pizza idiotic city.
author: A A.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

Maybe I'm Neo Pizza'd out. This was proper and good and certainly better than the slop center over at Delfina. But it could have used a bit more heat and char. Then again maybe it's because I had the Margherrita (yes, I try to spell it differently each time) with no special toppings.

Beet salad could have used a little more acid or salt.

I'd try it again to see how it shakes out but a return Pauline's is probably next in the Mission rotation.
author: Bob R.

description:
For an unique dining experience with a special friend, this is where u really hit the spot with great company, great Italian food, and great staff with incredible kindness and hospitality, not to mention the site is "ASL" friendly. Excellent selective menu that owners prepare with taste and passion a multitude of small temptations not heavy with ingredients! Recommended: Beet Salad, special of the day Eggplant dish, and their Margherita pizzetta (with buffalo cheese nowhere u can find). A great way to spend minutes of gastronomic pleasure! Only regret I have is I was too stuffed to try their desserts. As the saying goes, "Always next time!" Do make time to go there!
**ASL = American Sign Language
author: Tina jo B.

description:
Went to dine at this Neapolitan restaurant last night with a co-worker friend.  It's snugged tightly between houses with a sushi bar next door.  Nice! 

The first thing you'd notice is the tight space around in the restaurant.  It was obvious they went for the location that's on the 16th and Guerrero St. over space availability and you will not have that much of space if you are going to install a cavernous pizza fire oven in the middle of the area and they also had a bar countertop too, so there wasn't that much room right there.  The interior design reminds me a bit of Chipotle mexican restaurant with a strong affinity towards white and black, and some steel to give it a modern look.

If you haven't figured out yet, the restaurant is family-owned as well as deaf-owned, with a deaf couple running the business.  Quite naturally, about the half of patrons were deaf and it was clear they were quickly making themselves comfortable at the restaurant, with the ease of communication and an understanding in deaf manners and culture.  I knew almost each of them, so it was nice to be saying hi to them in sign language and had some small talk.  My co-worker friend, hearing, seemed amused by the whole experience and remarked that it is like traveling to another country with a different culture and different language.  Exactly.

It's pretty ironic that the best service came not from adult waiters but by the very young waitress whose age was 14 years old.  She's the daughter of the deaf couple owner, a CODA, and she also has a younger brother who's working as a busboy, although not as interested as his sister was.  She quickly swiped through an app on the iPad and placed orders while another waiter seemed to have some problem figuring out how to use the app or maybe he's just counting his tips and made sure that it got accounted for.  I couldn't help but wonder if she'd follow in the footsteps of her mom who worked very hard to open the first ever deaf-owned restaurant in the whole city of San Francisco.  Maybe she'd go to college and get an MBA, then she'd be able to take the restaurant to the next level, perhaps with a larger space and more staff.

OK, enough with external lull observation, what about the food?  my co-worker friend and I ordered two pizzas -- mozzarella cheese with red tomato and another with eggplants/onions.  They were very good and I realize there was more emphasis on the taste of toppings and red sauce, along with the dough.  That's what neapolitan pizzas are, I suppose.  We also ordered an appetizer, red cabbage brusetta, which was awesome.  It's the olive oil that was a key ingredient, really bringing the flavor out so we enjoyed the appetizer very much. They have a couple of beers on draft and one of them was Fat Tire and it tasted really fresh.  I had another beer too, a black on black, which was yummy.

I'd highly recommend to make a reservation beforehand so you'd be ensured you'll have a table ready, since they don't have a ton of space to accommodate patrons with hungry stomachs.  If you happen to know some sign language, you'd have a fun time being able to talk to them and ask what they'd recommend.  Don't miss out this cozy restaurant!
author: Nathan K.

description:
I will preface this with, "we went on opening night"
(couple of understandable little glitches but nothing to cry home about)

Overall:
* Table was ready before our reservation time. awesome. 
* Waitress was very helpful and food was served quickly
* Pizza defiantly weighed in on the better half in this city.  
* Our bill was about 65 for two people, two pizzas, wine and an app. not bad

AND to top it off...

As running a restaurant is not challenging enough, 
the couple who opened the place are def. totally amazing and impressive!! 
well done.
author: GILLIAN J.

description:
We were very excited to eat at Mozzeria because we had heard so much about it in the social media. When we were finally in the area we thought we would try there. The first impression: cozy, cute restaurant. Parking was hard to find (it was a Friday night, go figure). The hostess was very nice and welcoming. 

Upon arrival we learned that it was important to have a reservation- we did not have one, and the hostess said the next reservation was coming in about 45 minutes and asked us if that would be enough time for us to eat. Kind of odd to be told how long we had the table for but we went for it anyway. Make sure you have a reservation before you go.

The food was okay. House wine was fine for, er, house wine. The whole time we were there, our server seemed distracted and flustered. Perhaps it was because it was a very busy night and they were new in the restaurant business. 

The main issue was food which could be greatly improved. What we ordered: the duck pizza that is only available on Fridays, the prociutto/mozzarella/arugula pizza, and the only salad on the menu. The pizzas were really just toasted flat bread with few speckles of toppings. We were really excited about the duck pizza but were disappointed that there was almost no visible sauce on it. You could literally count the number of duck pieces. For 18 dollars I would like to see a more generous portion- give me more ducks, pour more hoisin sauce, and put more green onions on it! Our pizza literally had no sauce at all and it was a very bland pizza. 

The prociutto/mozzarrella/arugula pizza was also just okay. We had expected there to be more cheese, but there were only about 7 dollops of mozzarrella about the size of a quarter. It would be a better pizza with more mozzarrella.

Please remember to cut all the pizzas before you bring them to the table- the kitchen forgot to slice our duck pizza and we had to cut it ourselves.

Both pizzas were so soggy in the bottom that when we held up a slice it wilted and all toppings just rolled over and fell off. 

For 15-18 dollars per pizza, I expect the food to be a lot better than what I got here...

Service was friendly but rather slow. 

We know this is a new restaurant so they are probably still figuring things out. Hopefully they can take the feedback and improve their food and service. We noticed that most of Mozzeria's 4- or 5-star ratings are given by members of the Deaf Community. While it's understandable that they want to help promote this deaf-friendly venue, which is a rare find in and of itself, it's just as important to give an unbiased review that reflects the actual quality of food and service.
author: BlueSky Z.

description:
Awesome pizza and service! You need to understand the foundation of this new business in San Francisco to truely appreciate this, they have Imported the wood burning stove from Italy! Their menu is very well written and fit perfectly for the upscale version of Italian eatery. The Mozzeria Bar is definitely to die for!!! This I would highly recommend along with the duck pizza. It's worth trying, its one of a kind!!! Great beer selections as well. 
Great friendly and warm staff, Deaf family run restaurant in SF.
author: Lonnie T.

description: Really yummy - awesome pizza and awesomer meatballs (veal with ricotta and an excellent savory tomato sauce). Cool space. Acoustics made it hard to chat. But, good music mix!
author: Andrew K.

description: Yes, it's true.  San Francisco is becoming a pizza mecca.  With the neapolitan style covered and mastered, we need more breadth of styles.  Una Pizza has this covered.  Mozzeria will be a welcome addition to the scene, and very well could insert itself into the SF pizza canon.
author: Ethan R.

description:
I loved this place.

We made reservations, but arrived early.  We were seated right away!.  The hostess was deaf, but greeted everyone and held up a clipboard that asked if you had a reservation.  The place is definitely small, but once we were seated we didn't mind the coziness feel.  

The decor is nice and sleek.  Dark hardwood floors, cool light fixtures, black tables, a white (marble?) bar with industrial-style bar stools.  The coolest part is the oven.  It is beautiful!  

We ordered the Mozzeria bar which was delicious.  The tomato sauce they make is so good I wanted to lick the plate clean.  We also ordered the prosciutto plate with pickled cauliflower.  That was delicious as well.  I know its a small plate, but I wanted more!  The servings were just right.  I was ready for our pizza and didn't feel stuffed by the appetizers.

For the pizza we tried the margherita with fresh mozzarella.  No complaints here.  We also had the pancetta with caramelized onions.  There was just the right amount of pancetta.  The flavor was great.  We finished the meal off with the tiramisu.  So creamy and good.

With all of that food and a beer and a glass of wine the whole bill was $60 so not bad at all.  

We loved the food, ambiance, and the staff!  I know some ASL so there were no problems there.  The owner came by and was showing us some signs which was very kind and great to interact with her.
author: Aimee L.

description:
I have to say this is probably a 3.5* place. I really wanted to think highly of this place after reading about who it employs.

But given who it emplys and given we were here with a decent sized group for a birthday dinner- the experience was less than optimal. there was a gap in communication with the wait staff. I think we much have asked 4 times if the pizza could be cut into 6 pieces instead of 4 but that never happened. So it was a little messy trying to share amongst the group. 

Overall, the food was good enough, but I don't know that I would return here on my own
author: Komal B.

description:
This is a total "tough love" review, since we went on opening night and really wanted to like the place, but I found they have some work to do to get it into shape.  Here's my constructive criticisms:

I was well aware it was going to be a hectic night as they waded through the kinks so I came prepared to be extra patient.  We actually sat down nearly on time for our reservation after being moved around a few times.  They were out of the wine and beer we wanted. #1: Stock your bar!!

15 minutes after sitting to get a menu: no bueno.  They were just printed on paper, nothing fancy.  #2 Print 100s of menus and hand them out as you seat people.  As soon as you walk away you get distracted and forget them.

Wanted to try to mozzarella bar and the lemon gnocchi, but out of both!  #3 Stock your kitchen!  This is an excellent way to lose business!  You must have enough mozzarella especially if your name is Mozzeria!

I knew the owners were deaf but learned so is most of the waitstaff.  On a busy night this makes communication difficult.  We worked around it, writing 'vegetarian' on a piece of paper...

The pesto pasta was so al dente it was crunchy, and wasn't pesto so much as just chopped up basil on top.  It was definitely missing salt and other seasonings.  I didn't care for it.  

Pizza dough was bland and chewy, I think missing again salt and olive oil in the dough.  Sidekick didn't like his salmon pizza (toppings were sparse) but I really liked the blue cheese, thyme, caramelized onion combo I got (once I added plenty of table salt to it).  Just the right amount of cheese and a good mix of flavors. But #4 season your food!

The good news is the price was right ($60 for two) and I might be enticed to come back in about 6 months if they get things rolling and good reviews come in on Yelp.  Fingers crossed because this could be a really cute joint.
author: Monica R.

description:
The fried mozzarella app was average and I liked the eggplant pesto pizza, I just don't like it enough to crave it knowing Little Star's in the vicinity.  I was also disappointed that the lemon ricotta gnocchi was not on the menu for the evening, as I was looking forward to trying it.  It sounds delicious.  The interior is also a bit cramped and brighter than I'd like.  

I love that they are welcoming to the deaf community (it is a segment that I admit to not being very cognizant of), but in hiring deaf servers, it obviously makes it harder, but not impossible, to communicate.  Other than the alphabet, I am not versed in ASL, and was resigned to pointing and gesturing, such as nods and thumbs-up for acknowledgements.  We almost ordered a pasta dish without the meat, and wondered how to communicate that (point at the meat word of the menu item and give the "no" gesture with a wave of the hand or shake of the head, then point to myself and the word "vegetarian" that's listed on the bottom of the menu?).  If anything, I am now more inclined to learn signing.

Everything in consideration, I had a good experience, which is usually not the case in trying a new restaurant.  I'm not sure if they rotate their menu, but it'd be in their best interest to.  Keeping things fresh and new will be attractive to diners in the midst of not only a neighborhood, but a town full of competition.
author: Marsha Z.

description: I can't visit San Francisco without going to Mozzeria a few times. Luckily many of my friends love it as much as I do and so its a great meeting spot for a fantastic gourmet italian dinner.  When I go with my friend Ken we always order several things and share all in order to taste as many different things as possible. The panorama of tastes is truly impressive.  I have had a roasted pulled pork pasta dish and also a lemon dessert both were out of this world delicious. I LOVE that the entire staff is ASL fluent and friendly.
